HEADLINE: A Lyricist Unknown Sings of Key Rates

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Would you rather get your monetary policy explanations from Alan Greenspan or Bob Dylan? Well before the Federal Reserve announced its decision to raise interest rates yesterday afternoon, the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland had posted on its Web site the June issue of Economic Trends, a publication that normally reviews economic data in a traditional, if not particularly interesting, manner. This time it took a different approach. 
 ''The Rates They Are A-changin''' was the headline, and what followed was a parody of one of Mr. Dylan's most famous songs:
 Come gather 'round people wherever you roam
 Recognize that inflation around you has grown
 And accept there's a chance it could rise through its zone
 Price stability is worth preservin'
 So less stimulus from the Fed don't bemoan
 For the rates they are a-changin'.
 Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pens
 Who are so confident in your opinions
 But don't speak too soon for the data still spins
 And there's no tellin' where it is goin'
 The theories out now could later be in
 For the rates they are a-changin'.
 The parody continued for several verses, ending with:
 The line it is drawn, the course nearly cast
 The risks we face now appeared small in the past
 But with measured steps the expansion will last
 Futures markets are anticipatin'
 A considerable time will be comin' to pass
 For the rates they are a-changin'.
 For those who may have wondered, the Cleveland Fed added a disclaimer:
 ''These lyrics are a Dylanesque take on the current situation; they are not an official statement about the likely course of monetary policy.'' 
 It did not identify the author, and a Cleveland Fed spokeswoman did not return a telephone call.
 As word of the parody spread yesterday, one economist, Robert J. Barbera of ITG/Hoenig, suggested that it was good the Cleveland Fed had not chosen to take off on another Dylan song.
 ''Can you imagine Greenspan singing, 'The sky, too, is falling onto you, and it's all over now, Baby Blue?''' he said.

LENGTH: 1050 words

HEADLINE: Showing Candidates, as They Praise Themselves and Bury Others

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
The scariest campaign ad in modern presidential history is not the ''Willie Horton'' commercial that George H. W. Bush used against Michael Dukakis in 1988 or Lyndon B. Johnson's legendary ''Daisy'' ad of 1964 that fanned fears about Barry Goldwater.
 It is the one with Nancy Reagan, in a demure red suit and navy ruffled collar, staring frostily into the camera in a 1980 ad against Jimmy Carter.
 ''I deeply, deeply resent and am offended by the attacks that President Carter has made on my husband,'' she said in a tight, reproachful voice. ''I would like Mr. Carter to explain to me why the inflation is as high as it is; why unemployment is as high as it is; I would like to have him explain the vacillating, weak foreign policy so that our friends overseas don't know what we're going to do, whether we're going to stand up for them, or whether we're not going to stand up for them.'' 
 Even the harshest of President Bush's ads this year criticizing Senator John Kerry's voting record on defense are not as chilling.
 Wives are so often used to soften a candidate's profile that it is easy to forget that 24 years ago Mrs. Reagan was sometimes deployed as a Bob Dole-style attack dog. And it is that kind of amnesia that ''The Living Room Candidate,'' an online exhibition on presidential campaign ads (movingimage .us), was designed to combat. 
 Created four years ago by the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, the updated 2004 version, which is scheduled to go online today, allows Internet users to browse through a far richer collection of TV and Web campaign ads from 1952 to the present. 
 It is a truism that political campaigns nowadays are fought and won on television, but it is also true that at this point in the campaign some of the most talked-about ads are being shown only in swing states like Ohio or Florida. The Web site allows New Yorkers and Californians to see how the other half are being wooed.
 It also gives Internet users easy access to the current campaign's Web ads, which are more prevalent and troubling this election year than ever before. The Web site, for example, has the original version of a recent Bush Internet ad, ''Coalition of the Wild-Eyed,'' which blended Democratic figures like Al Gore and Howard Dean with images of Hitler. After the Kerry campaign and others complained last week, the ad was re-edited by the Bush campaign to make it clearer that the Hitler images were taken from an anti-Bush ad posted on the Web site of MoveOn .org, the political advocacy group. (The Bush ad does not explain that the attack ad with Hitler's image was not adopted by either the Kerry campaign or MoveOn.org, but was posted only as one of hundreds of entries in an Internet contest seeking anti-Bush commercials.)
 The Bush campaign Web site now includes only the amended version, but ''The Living Room Candidate'' allows viewers to link to it and compare it with the original.
 ''The Living Room Candidate'' is more than just a helpful tool for news addicts and journalists. Campaign ads are ''mini-movies,'' as David Schwartz, the museum's chief curator of film and a co-curator of ''The Living Room Candidate,'' put it: they do not just deliver the message of the moment but also reflect the mood and tastes of their era. 
 A 1968 Nixon ad reveling in Democratic Party chaos, for instance, is a wordless montage of the Chicago convention, Vietnam and civil unrest, set to a daffily jaunty rendition of ''Happy Days Are Here Again.'' It is a strange, and strangely effective ad that Mr. Schwartz described as ''very avant-garde'' and stylistically close to a popular variety show of the time, ''Laugh-In.'' 
 The ads for John F. Kennedy's 1960 campaign are very much of their time, too -- cinema verite-style glimpses of the candidate explaining his positions to admiring crowds. But one ad is more unusual: Jacqueline Kennedy asking viewers in Spanish to vote for her husband: ''Que viva Kennedy!'' Mrs. Kennedy's accent was quite good, but her voice was as breathy in Spanish as it was in English, and she seems quite stiff reading a cue card while standing in front of surprisingly ugly wallpaper.
 The Web site has a search option, so that users can, for example, search for the word ''sex'' from 1952 to 2004. It does not come up, though Bob Dole did mention Paula Jones's ''sexual harassment lawsuit'' in a 1996 attack ad against Bill Clinton. (Like Michael Moore's ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' with its film of President Bush on the links encouraging reporters to ''watch this drive,'' the ad uses a shot of President Clinton swinging a golf club to suggest dereliction of duty.)
 This year's ads are far fiercer and more negative than those from 2000. Then, one Al Gore ad showed the vice president politely endorsing his opponent's views: ''George Bush and I actually agree on accountability in education.'' And reflecting the spread of the Internet, MTV, cable TV news crawls and other attention-dividing forms of communication, today's ads cram much more information into ever shorter spaces. A seemingly soft and fuzzy Kerry ad titled ''Optimists'' uses split screens and quick cuts to flash a wide array of issues, from jobs and education to health care and national defense.
 But it is remarkable how unoriginal so many of today's high-tech, tightly honed ads really are. Just as Hollywood cannot resist a remake -- anything from ''King Kong'' to ''The Parent Trap'' -- political ads also cannibalize the past.
 A 2004 Bush ad called ''Defense,'' specially made for Florida voters, shows a sepia-tinted battleground. As the narrator lists weapons that Mr. Kerry voted against -- ''Apache helicopters, C-130 Hercules and F-16 fighter jets, components of which are all built here in Florida'' -- tanks and missiles vanish through the magic of computer graphics. The ad ends with the image of a forlorn-looking soldier and a narrator's voice intoning, ''Kerry even voted against body armor for our troops on the front line of the War on Terror.''
 In 1972, the Nixon campaign ran an ad about Senator George McGovern's proposed defense cuts. As a narrator warned -- ''He would cut the Marines by one-third, the Air Force by one-third. He'd cut Navy personnel by one-fourth'' -- a hand swept toy soldiers and miniature tanks and ships off the screen.


GRAPHIC: Photo: A new exhibition on the Internet shows Jacqueline Kennedy speaking Spanish in an ad for her husband's 1960 presidential campaign. (Photo by American Museum of the Moving Image)(pg. E5)

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* ''BETWEEN PAST AND FUTURE: NEW PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO FROM CHINA,'' International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, and Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 327-9276, through Sept. 5. This perspective-altering exhibition, divided between two institutions, gives a panoramic glimpse of China's continuing cultural revolution after the Cultural Revolution, picking up where Asia Society's 1998 survey ''Inside/Out'' left off. The work ranges from documentary-style shots of avant-garde performances in the mid-1990's to identity-searching photographs and videos, to images of old cities being demolished as new ones rise. The 60 artists represent a mere tip of the creative iceberg in a country changing with breathtaking speed. One way or another, those changes will effect the world. An important show. Center's hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+. Asia Society hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

* ''THE DOUGLAS DILLON LEGACY: CHINESE PAINTING FOR THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710, through Aug. 8. With treasures from the 8th through the 18th centuries, the Met is celebrating its comprehensive holdings in Chinese art, built up largely through the support of Dillon (1909-2003), a museum official for more than 50 years. Landscapes, bird and flower images, narratives and calligraphy fill eight galleries, punctuated by appropriate sculptures and ceramics. The highlights (everything here is a highlight, really) include a wonderfully stylized portrait of a fat and sassy horse, ''Night-Shining White,'' a favorite mount of the Chinese emperor Xuanzong, by the Tang painter Han Gan; ''Summer Mountains,'' attributed to Qu Ding, a visionary landscape in which travelers wind their way toward a lofty temple complex; and a scroll from a series of 12 by the 18th-century painter Xu Yang, recording in amazing detail Emperor Quianlong's tour of south China. Even for those unfamiliar with the complex cosmos of Chinese art, this show has a high enjoyment quotient. Hours: Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, and this Monday (July 5) only, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Grace Glueck).

* ''FIRST AMERICAN ART: THE CHARLES AND VALERIE DIKER COLLECTION OF AMERICAN INDIAN ART,'' National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, (212) 514-3700, through October 2005. That Native American art can provide the same aesthetic and emotional pleasure as European and American Modernism is the premise of this show, made up of 200 objects from the Diker collection. Masks, baskets, pots, clothing, baby carriers, painted hides, drawings and other treasures are displayed here not as ethnological artifacts, but as objects of art. The works are as beautiful as any you are likely to find in a private holding. The show affirms the distance achieved in allotting Native American art a worthy aesthetic place in world culture. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Glueck).

''FROM THE CLASSROOM TO THE WORLD: HINE, ULMANN, STRAND, ARBUS AND THE ETHICAL CULTURE FIELDSTON SCHOOL,'' New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400, through July 18. A persuasive pitch for the influence of the high-minded, progressive Ethical Culture Fieldston School on four famous photographers: Lewis W. Hine, Doris Ulmann, Paul Strand and Diane Arbus. As a young teacher there, Hine (1874-1940) discovered his own photographic talent and went on to become one of the great documentary photographers of the poor and oppressed in the United States. Ulmann's tenure at the school strengthened her budding social consciousness; Strand was directly mentored by Hine; and Arbus, who received all her formal education there, developed her own vision of the outsider side of everyday life. Along with rather dull photographs of the school, examples of their work are displayed. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

''CHILDE HASSAM, AMERICAN IMPRESSIONIST,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Sept. 12. A grossly inflated retrospective of this immensely popular American Impressionist, he of the candied views of patriotic, flag-draped New York during World War I. Retrospectives are supposed to change one's notion of an artist, so I suppose you could say that this one succeeds by definitively ratcheting Hassam's reputation several notches downward. The show is full of Hassam's cheerful, nostalgic views of Americana; skillful, high-keyed scenes full of flickering light, which, while occasionally brilliant, look especially facile brought together by the dozens, as they are here. Hassam could do almost anything technically in a variety of media: a night scene, the glint of water on the side of a horse-drawn carriage, dappled sun through a scrim of autumn trees, people massing in a canyon of tall buildings, a Seville courtyard in the slanting light of the late afternoon. Anything except what mattered most, which was offer up something deeper and daring. Hours and admission: See above (Michael Kimmelman).

* ''LIVING LEGACIES: THE ARTS OF THE AMERICAS,'' Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, permanent installation. In conjunction with its new facade and lobby, the museum has opened its revamped Hall of the Americas, the spacious display arena for objects from its collection of North, Central and South American art. Redone in vibrant colors, the hall offers three thematic shows as Phase I of its new installation. ''Enduring Heritage: Art of the Northwest Coast'' is the fiercest and most startling, with dramatic animal masks and a giant totem pole. ''Threads of Time: Woven Histories of the Andes'' presents 38 textiles and related materials from ancient times to now and ''Stories Revealed: Writing Without Words,'' the smallest, conveys how Indian cultures used graphic art rather than words to record their histories. A fuller account of the museum's collections will appear with Phase II, planned for 2006. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Glueck).

* ''MODIGLIANI: BEYOND THE MYTH,'' Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, through Sept. 19. The first big New York retrospective of Modigliani since 1951, believe it or not, this is an overstuffed show that includes predictable duds, but also a select group of his best sculptures and paintings, which belie the stereotype of Modigliani as an impulsive lunatic, hellbent on self-destruction, doing poster-ready work. The good works indicate someone of worldly intelligence, patience, discipline and steady concentration. Modigliani's huge popularity has always depended on his risque reputation and on his languid, pretty, easily digested and unmistakable brand of delicately abstracted Modernism. As with the work of Chagall or Ben Shahn, Modigliani's could frequently tip over into kitsch or parody. But at its best, it is original and exquisite and suggests someone beyond the bohemian cliche, clearly wrestling with issues besides the formal felicity of elongated shapes, who died prematurely. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 9 p.m.; Fridays, to 5 p.m. Admission: $14; $11.50 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* ''MOMA AT EL MUSEO: LATIN AMERICAN AND CARIBBEAN ART FROM THE COLLECTION OF THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART,'' El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272, through July 25. The first broad-scale exposure of the Modern's extensive holdings from Mexico, the Caribbean and Central and South America, the 150 or so objects here are a small selection from the more than 2,000 it owns. But they form an arresting show, from the powerful Surrealist-influenced ''Jungle'' (1943) by the Cuban artist Wifredo Lam to an untitled 1995 sculpture by the Colombian Doris Salcedo that invokes the political violence in her country. The sardonic humor of Marisol (Venezuela) and Fernando Botero (Colombia); the geometric tweakings of Jesus Rafael Soto and Gertrude Goldschmidt (Venezuela); the Conceptual hatchings of Felix Gonzalez-Torres (Cuba) and Cildo Meireles (Brazil), among others, remind us of the artistic richness south of the border. This show joins the strength of the Modern's resources with the growing importance of El Museo as a showcase of Latino culture. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., Thursdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $7; students and 65+, $5 (Glueck).

* AUGUST SANDER, ''People of the 20th Century: A Photographic Portrait of Germany'' and Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Sept. 19. Although only a sampling of his vast inventory of portraits of German society, the show, naturally, is too big: the prints are vintage but uneven, and the best pictures are not given enough breathing room. But genius is genius, and you may leave nearly overwhelmed by the breadth and depth of Sander's obsessive ambition and humanity. An accompanying display, ''Indexing the World,'' is a gem, providing a brisk, buoyantly eccentric overview of the dubious role of photography in the quest to index the world. It is often remarked that Sander photographed one era turning into another, Weimar Germany into Nazi Germany, which is true. His work, despite its scientific pretense, is suffused with the unconscious melancholy of a world he could see was already fading. But another way to describe him is to say that his project was both deeply reactionary and revolutionary, and this tension became the central, illuminating paradox of his achievement. (Through July 9 a selection of Sander's photographs of women is at Yancey Richardson Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (646) 230-9610.) Museum hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

''SHOCK OF THE OLD: CHRISTOPHER DRESSER,'' the Smithsonian Institution's Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400, through July 25. The first full-scale museum retrospective of this great 19th-century British designer reflects the career of an astoundingly busy man in tumultuous times. One of the first designers to embrace industrial fabrication, Dresser introduced innovative techniques and materials, helped ignite the Western craze for Japan and the revival of ancient styles and presaged much that we call modern. His career, eclipsed before he died, is still being explored. This show's profusion of vases in porcelain, earthenware or glass; silver-plate tea services, toast racks and decanters; wallpaper and textile designs; chairs, cabinets and cast-iron hall stands seems more like the survey of an epoch than the work of a single individual. Hours: Tuesdays to Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $7 (Roberta Smith).

* ''TOOLS OF HER MINISTRY: THE ART OF SISTER GERTRUDE MORGAN,'' American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040, through Sept. 26. If you wonder what it really means to say that art is a calling, see this ethereal show. A self-appointed prophet and street preacher, Sister Morgan was called by God to paint in the 1950's. Untutored but full of an uncanny grace, her vivid, high-key works have a plain-spoken ecstasy and inborn eloquence, both formal and literary, that can lift the soul. The mix of text and image relates to many modern artists and poets, none of whom she ever heard of or cared about. Her pictures are talismans of mystical devotion derived from inner necessity, conceived as teaching tools for lost souls. In heaven works like these would be eternally before our eyes. The world not being heaven, this is your opportunity to see them. The day has come, as Sister Morgan might say. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., Fridays until 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

JORGE PARDO, Lever House Lobby Gallery, 400 Park Avenue, between 53rd and 54th Streets, there is no phone through July 31. If Ikea sold sculptures, they might look like the ones Mr. Pardo installed in the lobby of this famous Modernist high-rise: squat wooden constructions resembling the skeletons of biomorphic chairs, with attractive colored glass lights nested like eggs in the depressions where you sit. Curiously, the plywood elements that touch the floor have been cut into the silhouettes of animal feet: hooves, bear paws or tentacles (Ken Johnson).

GUY PENE DU BOIS, ''Painter of Modern Life,'' Graham, 1014 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 535-5767, through July 9. Pene du Bois (1884-1958) made some of the more appealingly peculiar paintings in early-20th-century American art. With a sensuously refined touch, he painted luminous, gently satiric pictures of doll-like, well-to-do people in situations of Henry Jamesian intimacy. This enchanting exhibition presents more than 50 paintings and works on paper from the first half of his career, 1905 to 1924 (Johnson).

STANLEY SPENCER, CDS Gallery, 76 East 79th Street, (212) 772-9555, through July 27. Religion, sex and his hometown (Cookham-on-Thames) preoccupied Spencer (1891-1959), who expressed his visions in robust paintings that combined the influences of Italian Renaissance masters and Modernist European movements. His powerful draftsmanship is seen in this show of 26 sheets from the early 1920's to the mid-1950's. Particularly evident is his adroitness at complex figural compositions. His softer, erotic side is evident in a study for ''Leda and the Swan,'' and there are a couple of wonderful portraits. This catchall display, in which some of the works are faded and faint, lacks the oomph one expects from a Spencer drawing show, but it gives a taste of the artist's superlative skills (Glueck).

''WEEGEE'S STORY,'' Ubu, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444, through July 23. Wielding his 4-by-5 Speed Graphic with a master's touch, the New York tabloid photographer Weegee probably shot more murders and fires in his heyday, the 1930's and 40's, than anyone in the business. But his passion for the city also drew him to its many other photo opportunities: the strivers and the homeless, festivities and freaks, politicians and celebrities, posh avenues and mean streets. This show of 220 Weegee vintage photographs, culled from a collection assembled during 30 years by the Berlin dealer Hendrik Berinson, reveals his remarkable range (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

''WOODWORK,'' Anthony Grant, 37 West 57th Street, (212) 755-0434, through Aug. 27. Highlights of this 22-artist show of wooden sculptures include George Stoll's wooden sponge painted yellow; a big, lovingly smoothed, upright log by Jene Highstein; a bark-covered sphere like a giant cantaloupe called ''Tree Ball'' by Lars Fisk; a bearded man nicely carved in lime tree wood and hung upside down by Paloma Vargas Weisz; an improbably bent 2-by-4 by Matt Johnson; and a big human hand with many little hinged doors built into it by Los Carpinteros (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

''MARILYN,'' Sean Kelly, 528 West 29th Street, (212) 239-1181, through July 23. Marilyn Monroe is the inspiration for works by more than 20 artists. It starts with a small grainy close-up photograph of the young actress's worried face by Andre de Dienes and includes photographs of Andy Warhol-style Marilyns copied in crushed rhinestones and red liquid by Vic Muniz; a Marilyn-like self-portrait by Cindy Sherman; Zoe Leonard's photograph of a bearded woman in the famous nude-on-red-satin pose; and a sound piece by Jonathan Horowitz with the self-explanatory title, ''Talking Without Thinking (in the Voice of Marilyn Monroe)'' (Johnson).

''PSYCHIC LANDSCAPE,'' Yvon Lambert, 564 West 25th Street, (212) 242-3611, through July 30. Works in various media by six cosmic fantasists include Vidya Gastaldon's pod sculptures of yarn-wrapped wire; Mamie Holst's hypnotic painted circles; Jean-Michel Wicker's video meditation on the Cologne Cathedral; Ki'Wa's psychedelically colored video of a ghostly grafitti artist; Carlos Amorales's sharply graphic paintings of red-eyed crows, skulls and a giant spider; and, best of all, Alex Rutterford's hyperactively percussive animated video of mechanical elements, rapidly morphing to the music of Autechre (Johnson).

''PUBLIC.EXE: PUBLIC EXECUTION,'' Exit Art, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 966-7745, through July 31. This group exhibition is all but invisible at Exit Art itself, where another, long-running exhibition takes up most of the space. ''Public.ex'' has just two installations on the premises, along with some handouts, including a funky newspaper and a CD. But the bulk of the work consists of politically inflected events, video screenings and activist Internet sites. A result is a show that as far as possible sidesteps the institutional authority and moves out into the everyday world, where art and life, equally silly and serious, seem to interact on the random, non-linear model of the Internet itself. The exhibition's Web site is www.exitart.org/public.exe (Cotter).

''SOMMER SHOW,'' Lehmann Maupin, 540 West 26th Street, (212) 255-2923, through July 30. Works by five artists represented by Sommer Contemporary Art, a Tel Aviv gallery, include Eliezer Sonnenschein's wooden guns with corporate logos painted on them; Rona Yefman's wry photographs of young people, like one of three topless women in Groucho Marx masks; Doron Solomon's percussive, gridded video projection, in which brief scenes of newsreel violence flicker on and off; Sharon Ya'ari's large, dreamlike, black-and-white photograph of a grocery store closed for the night; and Yehudit Sasportas's faux-technical drawing of fallen trees in a forest (Johnson).

* ''TERRORVISION,'' Exit Art, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 966-7745, through July 31. Terror comes in all sizes, shapes and degrees, and this show runs the gamut, with exhibits by about 50 artists facing up to their most ''extreme fears,'' from the general threats posed by Al Qaeda and its franchises to the traumas of personal catastrophe like breast cancer and heart operations. The gallery's multidisciplinary emphasis is manifest in film, video, audio and computer-generated creations, along with media as simple as prints and photographs. It is a mix of successful efforts and some that don't quite make it, the lightweight with the more substantial. But it is alive and kicking (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

''PLAYPEN,'' Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166, through July 24. Process, the notion of art as action, is a fundamental dynamic in this mildly experimental show. Much of the work is site-specific and finished, including David Brody's mural-like wall drawings and a suite of sculptures by Gedi Sibony. Other pieces are both stationary and interactive. The exception is across the street in the annex gallery called the Drawing Room, where the collective Red67 has a project titled ''New York Public Archive,'' to which visitors can contribute material, on the utopian principle that everyone is an artist and everything can be art (Cotter).

GERHARD RICHTER, ''Two Sculptures for a Room by Palermo,'' Peter Freeman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-5154, through July 31. Here is one of the very few sculptures made by Mr. Richter, the immensely influential German painter. It consists of two plaster heads cast from life, slathered in gray paint and mounted on pedestals. One head is Mr. Richter's; the other is of his fellow German painter Blinky Palermo. Facing each other with closed eyes, in a gallery that is empty but for a small study version in a shadow box on the wall, the faux classical sculptures create an ambience of dry existential ennui (Johnson).

* ROBERT RYMAN, ''Works on Paper, 1957-1964,'' Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441, through Sept. 25. Although Mr. Ryman is usually referred to as a Minimalist, he began his career as something more like an abstract conceptualist, making paintings at least as interesting to think about as to look at. This stimulating, richly varied exhibition of 30 works on paper catch him at a pivotal point in his career, which coincides with a fertile one in American art. They include paintings, drawings and collage, often in combination, and show an artist using abstraction's strangeness and uncertainties to think his way into his creative place in the world (Cotter).

Other Galleries

''ARCHITECTURE BY NUMBERS,'' Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453, through July 9. Although the premise of this show is promising, an investigation by architects of ''architecture and its essential relationship with the numerical,'' its theory load is heavy and the visual quotient is low (Glueck).

* FELIX GMELIN, Maccarone, 45 Canal Street, Lower East Side, (212) 431-4977, through July 31. Utopianism, time-faded and tinged with doubt, is the subject of the spare but trenchant New York debut show of this Swedish artist. The centerpiece is his re-creation of a 1968 video shot by his father, who was at the time a teacher in Berlin. In the original, students carry a large red flag in a kind of marathon relay jog through the city: one figure taking the banner from another. In 2002 Mr. Gmelin recreated the performance, using his own students as runners, and the two videos, old and new, run side by side in the gallery. The ideas conveyed are contradictory; the juxtaposition very moving (Cotter).

* ''LASTING IMPRESSIONS,'' Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690, through July 31. Regarding books as visual treasures, the club's library is an awesome repository of the history of printing and collecting in the Western world. The more than 150 objects on view here include not just bound rarities, but also manuscripts, prints, drawings, paintings, photographs and statues. Treasures range from a collection of tiny printed volumes going back to the 17th century, some so small they could fit on your thumbnail, to a handwritten inventory of the library of Madame de Pompadour. This is a show that's worth its weight in quality time (Glueck).

SZE TSUNG LEONG, ''History Images,'' Storefront for Art and Architecture, 97 Kenmare Street, Little Italy, (212) 431-5795, through July 31. A photographer who divides his time between New York and Bejing presents extremely detailed, medium-large color pictures of construction and demolition sites in Chinese cities. Taken from elevated distances, the images convey a sense of the awesome scale of development in that huge, rapidly modernizing country (Johnson).

* ''THE REALITY OF THINGS,'' Triple Candie, 461 West 126th Street, Harlem, (212) 865-0783, through July 11. Some things in this intriguing, 12-artist show are just what they seem, and some are not. Seemingly real cantaloupes by Martha Friedman are made of cast and painted urethane foam but Tony Feher's stacked brown and black milk crates involved no deception. Most stealthily surprising is Hans Accola's plastic jug of carpenter's glue. Tara Donavan's cube of straight pins, Robert Gober's fake newspaper advertising fliers and Shinique Smith's thrift store overcoat with added silver pinstripes further compound one's sense of existential slipperiness (Johnson).

''WORLDSCAPES: THE ART OF ERRO,'' Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through July 17. The career of Erro, a prodigiously productive Pop-style painter and an acclaimed Icelandic artist, is featured in a nearly 50-year retrospective at the Grey Art Gallery. It will not persuade you that he is a great painter, but you may be taken by his manic graphic activity, antic humor and promiscuous sampling from popular culture. If so, you may also want to see ''Femmes Fatales'' at the Goethe Institute, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 439-8700, through July 17, which offers 10 colorful paintings from an Erro series devoted to female comic-book superheroes (Johnson).

Last Chance

* ''BYZANTIUM: FAITH AND POWER (1261-1557),'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Monday. This vast and humblingly beautiful show about the waning centuries of the Byzantine empire reminds us that political decay does does not necessarily mean artistic decline. Full of amazing exotica -- manuscripts, miniature mosaics, textiles, drawings, paintings -- the exhibition ends with a room of great Northern Renaissance art indebted to icons that proves Byzantium's continued reach. People who are not Eastern Orthodox believers can enjoy the earthly pleasures of aesthetic spectacle linked with historical enlightenment. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

''NEXUS: TAIWAN IN QUEENS,'' Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows Corona Park, Queens, (718) 592-9700, through Sunday. Twenty artists, all Taiwanese, are assembled for an exhibition about immigration, assimilation, isolation, cultural identity and related issues. Many works are straightforward illustrations of the theme: Lu Hsian Fu's installation of red paper Chinese lanterns threaded with strings of Christmas lights, for example, is about the immigrant's bicultural experience. Some works, like C. J. Yeh's cybernetic translations of Mondrian paintings, resonate more broadly. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission, $5 (Johnson).

* ''PETRA: LOST CITY OF STONE,'' American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, through Tuesday. Petra, an ancient city in what is now the Jordanian part of the Negev Desert, was at its zenith from the first century B.C. to the third century A.D. Prosperous, safe and abundantly supplied with water, it was a center of bustling trade in incense, ivory, textiles and other precious goods, which flowed through it by camel caravan from points east to the Mediterranean. And it was a highly sophisticated cultural crossroads whose inhabitants carved from rock not only a lively metropolis but also a necropolis of monumental tombs for their kings and leaders. While learned diggers are still uncovering its ruins, this show, said to be the first cultural collaboration between Jordan and the United States, offers a generous glimpse of Petra's vibrant civilization through art objects, architectural elements, photographs and film. The installation, set up with the museum's usual expertise and helpful graphics, is one of the busiest around, but undaunted, Petra comes through. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Timed tickets to the exhibition: $19; students and 60+, $16.50; children under 12, $13 (Glueck).

* ''FRED WILSON, OBJECTS AND INSTALLATIONS: 1979-2000,'' Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, through Sunday. Mr. Wilson, who represented the United States at the 2003 Venice Biennale, made his reputation with conceptually pointed, technically polished and visually engaging installations and objects that focused on excavating American racial history and illustrating the exclusionary power of cultural institutions shaped by social, economic and ideological domination. Elements of his subversive museum projects appear in this traveling show, along with sculptures and a fine, short new film. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; students and 62+, $3; children under 12, free (Cotter).

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Auto Sales Plunged in June At Both G.M. and Ford
General Motors and Ford Motor reported double-digit declines in United States sales in June, as Detroit continued to lose ground to Japanese and Korean rivals.
 Over all, auto sales in the United States were down 6 percent from a year ago. G.M.'s sales fell 15.4 percent and Ford's sales, including Volvo and Land Rover, were down 11.9 percent. Sales suffered in part from strong results in May, which could not be sustained, as well as from difficult comparisons to June 2003, when incentive programs buoyed sales. [Page C5.]

Stock Investors Await Jobs Report
Stocks fell with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 101.32 points, to close at 10,334.16. The S.&P. 500-stock index dropped 11.90 points, to 1,128.94, and the Nasdaq composite decreased 32.24 points, to 2,015.55. [C5.]

The Institute for Supply Management's gauge of manufacturing held close to a 20-year high in June, reinforcing forecasts that the economy is expanding. In another report, construction spending rose 0.3 percent in May, to an annual pace of $988.5 billion. [C2.]

Inflation Worried Fed in May
Minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee on May 4 indicated that nearly two months before the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates on Wednesday, some board members were more worried about inflation than Alan Greenspan was. [C2.]

InterActiveCorp Is Victor in Dispute
A Delaware judge has ruled in favor of InterActiveCorp, run by Barry Diller, in a tax-related dispute with Vivendi Universal. [C5.]

Clinton Memoir Selling Briskly
Knopf Publishing said that ''My Life,'' former President Bill Clinton's 957-page memoir, sold more than one million copies in the first eight days after its publication on June 22. Knopf said that it had already ordered a third printing, raising the total to 2.6 million. [C3.]

I.B.M. Tried to Counter Oracle Bid
Oracle's hostile takeover bid for PeopleSoft caused I.B.M. to consider making investments in other software makers. [C5.]

Chairman Leaves J Sainsbury
The chairman of J Sainsbury, Sir Peter Davis, left, stepped down after criticism of his $:2.5 million ($4.55 million) bonus, which was awarded despite the company's poor results in 2003. Sir Peter will be succeeded by Philip Hampton, who was the chief financial officer at Lloyds TSB until the beginning of this year. [World Business, Section W.]

No Rate Increase in Europe
The European Central Bank decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2 percent -- a decision as widely expected as the Federal Reserve's rate increase had been on Wednesday. [World Business, Section W.]

No Decision Yet at Adelphia Trial
Jurors in the fraud trial of the founder of Adelphia Communications, John J. Rigas, and three other former executives completed their fourth day of deliberations without reaching a verdict, after requesting transcripts from two days of testimony. [C2.]

Testimony Ends in Tyco Case
Testimony in the trial of Mark A. Belnick, Tyco's former general counsel, ended after prosecutors offered a rebuttal. [C4.]

2 HealthSouth Executives Charged
Two former HealthSouth executives were indicted on charges of conspiracy in connection with a bribery scheme in Saudi Arabia. [C9.]

SECTION: Section E; PT2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 1531 words

HEADLINE: Windows on the Many Chinese Revolutions, Political and Personal

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
Few new worlds are brave. Even those that come with a plan, an ideal, some kind of vision thing, are cautious, expedient, accident-prone affairs, cruising from crisis to crisis, consolidating nuggets of political and cultural power and letting everything else, including the past, fall where it may, often on the trash heap. 
 That's one impression generated by the several exhibitions of photography from China that have converged in Manhattan this summer. A large survey of contemporary Chinese work at the International Center of Photography and Asia Society sets the tone, with images by a generation of young artists who are watching an urbanized, digitalized, McDonald's-ized culture lurch into being before their eyes. 
 But other shows contribute valuable information. A two-part exhibition at China Institute and a pocket-size archival display at the International Center of Photography together look back to an older China in the grip of different but no less shocking revolutions. And in an outstanding New York solo debut in a Chelsea gallery, the Beijing-based photographer Hai Bo weaves cultural and personal history together with a sadness so profound and restrained as to seem heroic. 
 Cultural history is the focus of ''China and the Chinese in Early Photographs'' at the International Center of Photography, a contextualizing footnote to the contemporary survey. It includes portraits of Manchu nobility, their imperial days numbered, by the late-19th-century Scottish photographer John Thomson, as well as shots of landscapes that emulated, with peculiarly glassy serenity, ink-and-brush painting. 
 This was the China Europeans wanted; these pictures were for them, though at least one odd-duck entry was intended for Chinese eyes. It is a photographic facsimile, dated 1842, of the document known as the Treaty of Nanjing, signed that year by China and Britain after China's defeat in the First Opium War. The agreement forced China to open ports to Western trade. And to further sharpen the humiliation, British authorities sent a photographic copy of the treaty to the Chinese government as evidence of the powers of Western technology.
 The chronological story picks up in the two-part ''China Fast Forward: Photographs of Daily Life, 1917-2002'' at China Institute, or at least in one of the shows installed there, a selection of pictures by the American social scientist Sidney D. Gamble (1890-1968). The earliest picture is from 1917. By then the Qing dynasty was gone, replaced by a republican government, but a centuries-old social structure and a predominantly agricultural economy were more or less intact. 
 Gamble, a Princeton-trained heir to the Proctor & Gamble fortune, arrived in China with an agenda, a utopian Christian capitalist belief that an application of science and religion might lift a backward culture up. It is Gamble the scientist who shines forth in the show, which is organized by Nancy Jervis, vice president of China Institute, and has been seen in various versions and different places, including China, in the past 15 years. 
 Gamble was an avid statistician, a connoisseur of quantity: he knew, for a given year, how many rickshaws there were in Beijing, how many ounces of opium had been confiscated and burned, and what percentage of women had bound feet. To supplement his fact-finding, he took pictures. A few he used in books he published; most he stored away. Some 5,000 negatives were found in a closet after his death. Prints made from 57 of them are in the show, and they're wonderful. 
 In line with Gamble's omnivorous appetite, the range of subjects is wide: nobles, peasants and pilgrims; coffin makers and silk-weavers; Yangtze River boatmen; university students in Panama hats; Taoist priests. Gamble gave equal attention to productivity and poverty and had no interest in the fantasy of a ''timeless Orient.'' He saw activity and change everywhere, and documented it. 
 He was in Beijing in 1919 when word came that European powers had handed Chinese territory over to Japan, and he photographed the protests that followed this betrayal, culminating in the great demonstrations that turned into the generation-defining May Fourth Movement. And just as he acknowledged the emergence of a new China, he recognized an old China on the wane. His 1918 picture of a wealthy dowager, swathed in silk, feet bound, cigarette holder clamped between her lips, is a classic embodiment of an antique culture that Maoism and Western modernism would sweep away.
 The second show at China Institute, ''Documenting China: Contemporary Photography and Social Change,'' considers the consequences of that sweep. Organized by Gu Zheng, a Shanghai-based photographer, for the Bates College Museum of Art in Lewiston, Me., it includes seven photographers with distinct approaches to an immense theme. 
 One, Liu Xiaodi, in his ''Village'' series from the late 1970's, focused on rural peasants, extolled by Mao as the spiritual elite of his ''People's China.'' This old-time orthodoxy is undercut, however, in another series, Zhang Xinmin's ''Besiege the City by the Country'' (1998). While the title refers to a strategy for a peasant revolution, it is applied to images of peasants who have migrated by the millions to cities, looking for work, only to find themselves on the lowest rung of the socio-economic ladder. Once social role models for a China-to-be, they are victims of the China that is. 
 Jiang Jian takes this subject in a different direction in tender 1999 color portraits of peasant families in their homes. But Zhou Hai's pictures of industrial workers caught in an inferno of smoke and grime return to other realities. A young man haloed with steam and staring defiantly at the camera could be the advance guard of a new proletarian revolution in a country every bit as explosive as it was in Gamble's day. 
 In fact, the only predictable thing at present is a continuing hybridity, evident in Luo Yongjin's photographs of new architecture in wild Chinese-Internationalist styles, and in a panoramic shot by Zhou Ming of Shanghai, with its Disneyesque skyline and boomtown energy from which at least some residents are in retreat. These Shanghailanders are themselves subjects of photographs by Lu Yuanmin: sepia-toned portraits of middle-class residents who have made their apartments into sealed environments to which manageable doses of past and present are admitted.
 Indeed, following a decade of extroverted work, many Chinese artists are looking inward. One is Mr. Hai, 42, who is seen both at Max Protetch in Chelsea and in ''Between Past and Future,'' the survey at the International Center of Photography. To the survey he contributes much-noticed older work. It include pairs of photographs of family and friends, with one picture taken during the Cultural Revolution and the other, of the same sitters, or those who survive, 20 years later. Although the work clearly has a political edge, time and memory are its real subjects, as they are of the recent work at Protetch. 
 His series titled ''Dusk'' (2002) literally resurrects the past by combining pictures from years ago in new, triptych-style formats. In one example, two head shots of the artist's aged, bedridden grandmother are followed by a coppery image of a landscape at sunset, a view she regularly saw from her window at the end of her life. The pictures date from 1993, the year she died, but were assembled as a unit two years ago, as were others of Mr. Hai's father and son. 
 The expressive dynamic here, at once valedictory and restorative, reappears in a quartet of pictures titled ''Four Seasons'' (2003), in which the artist himself is seen as a diminutive figure seated under a magnificent tree in a park. The series riffs on the Taoist theme of mutability that suffuses classical Chinese painting: the tree changes appearance from picture to picture; the seated figure remains constant, though with each change of season he has aged. 
 Characteristically for this artist, the series also has specific autobiographical content. The park is the one in which Mr. Hai played as a child; it is also where his brother accidentally drowned. And the memory of private tragedy haunts these pictures just as surely as the public tragedy haunts the group portraits, real and reconstructed, from the Cultural Revolution. 
 In fact, public and private meet in almost all of the most interesting Chinese photography concentrated in New York this summer, work that both engages with the brilliant, volatile, dangerous history it is part of and creates a morally incisive world of its own. To do the first requires breadth of vision; to do the second requires courage of a quiet, generous kind.

The two-part show called ''China Fast Forward: Photographs of Daily Life, 1917-2002'' remains at China Institute, 125 East 65th Street, Manhattan, through July 31. ''China and the Chinese in Early Photographs'' remains at International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, through Sept. 5, and travels to George Eastman House, Rochester, Dec. 11 to Feb. 6. ''Hai Bo'' remains at Max Protetch, 511 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, through July 30.

HEADLINE: Powell Meets Foreign Minister Of North Korea to Discuss Arms

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, July 2 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met with North Korea's foreign minister here on Friday in the highest-level meeting between the two nations in two years to discuss proposals intended to induce North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, according to Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman.
 Mr. Powell and the foreign minister, Paek Nam-Sun, along with their delegations, met for about 20 minutes, Mr. Boucher said, and tried to clarify their positions on proposals advanced last month, in the last round of six-party talks on North Korea. 
 At those talks, the United States and four of North Korea's neighbors -- Japan, South Korea, Russia and China -- laid out a series of incentives for North Korea, including the promise of a significant infusion of foreign aid.
 That was seen as a softening by the Bush administration, which had previously insisted on complete disarmament as a first step to improved relations and aid. Washington was prodded by China, South Korea and Japan to abandon its hard-line stance.
 Mr. Powell, who was in Indonesia for a security conference of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, said there was an opportunity for ''concrete progress,'' Mr. Boucher said.
 The encounter was the first opportunity for American officials to register a reaction from North Korea, which until now has said it was studying the new proposal.
 That reaction seemed guarded.
 A North Korean statement quoted Mr. Paek, who referred to North Korea by the abbreviation for the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, as saying that ''if the United States is of the position to improve the bilateral relations, the D.P.R.K. also will not regard the U.S. as a permanent enemy, and that the prospect of the D.P.R.K.-U.S. relations entirely depends on the switchover in the U.S. hostile policy on the D.P.R.K.''
 The statement added that North Korea would ''maintain its goal of denuclearizing the Korean peninsula and reaffirmed that there is no change in the D.P.R.K.'s position to resolve the nuclear issue peacefully through dialogue.''
 In a news conference on Thursday night, Mr. Powell spoke of the evolution in the administration's stance.
 ''We want a denuclearized Korean peninsula,'' he said. ''It's in the best interest of the world, the region, the peninsula and North Korea. We showed flexibility in our position last week because we wanted our colleagues in the six-party talks to recognize that the United States was seeking a peaceful, diplomatic solution.''

HEADLINE: Can Rising Rates Stimulate Housing? Fed Makes It Happen, for Now

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
RISING interest rates are supposed to slow the housing industry, but no one looking at the home sale numbers would think that any such thing is going on.
 The continued strength of the housing market, months after the bond market began to raise interest rates -- and just as the Federal Reserve begins to follow suit -- says interesting things about the state of the economy.
 First, it reflects the popularity of housing as an investment. The stock market has come back, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is almost 50 percent above its lows of October 2002. But the index is still about 25 percent below its peak, and it is not representative of the tech stocks where many made and then lost so much money. For many in America, housing remains the only investment they've made that has worked without fail. 
 Second, the strong housing market reflects the confidence of buyers that their jobs are safe. It took longer than usual for job growth to arrive in this recovery, but it has done so. Economists may worry about excessive consumer debt, but consumers do not.
 But there may also be a third reason, one that is in some ways perverse. It relates to the Federal Reserve, which stimulated the housing market by pushing interest rates down as low as they could go. That seemed wise at the time, what with talk about deflation and very weak technology and telecommunications sectors that had to work off the overcapacity caused by the technology stock bubble.
 After that crisis passed, the Fed gradually concluded that rates had to rise. But Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, remembers all too vividly what happened in 1994 when the Fed decided higher rates were needed. Hints were ignored, and it turned out that some prominent investors had placed huge bets, via derivatives, that relied on rates staying low. This time, Mr. Greenspan wanted to be sure that everyone had time to unwind such positions. A lot of positions were unwound, although it is hard to know whether it was Fed talk or bond market action that led to those moves by traders.
 But the prolonged talk about raising rates, including the widespread belief that there will be a series of increases, may have done the exact opposite of what a rise in rates is expected to do. Rather than depress sales, it is now stimulating buying and pushing prices higher. 
 When inflation is rampant, as it is in home prices, an increase in prices becomes a reason to buy now, before they go even higher. The apparent certainty that borrowing costs will rise has contributed to that frenzy. 
 If the price of homes were counted in the Consumer Price Index, as it once was, inflation would appear higher than it does -- and it is already so high that the real, or inflation-adjusted, federal funds rate is farther below zero than it has been since the days when G. William Miller was running the Fed in the 1970's. But the government instead measures rental prices for the Consumer Price Index, and those have lagged home costs, making overall inflation seem lower than it really is.
 Home prices are perhaps the only market where buyers and sellers measure prices quite differently. Sellers see a price of $500,000, or whatever it might be. Buyers see a price of so much a month. As rates fell, the seller's price could soar while the buyer's price did not. As mortgage rates rise, the reverse will be true, and those whom Mr. Greenspan is encouraging to buy now may suffer the most.
 Rather than focus on a gradual rise in interest rates, the Fed should be trying to set the appropriate rate given the strong economy and rising inflation. That rate is not 1.25 percent; it is probably above 3 percent. The Fed's policy of gradualism may be politically popular, but its economic effects may prove to be unfortunate.

HEADLINE: Ex-Dancer With Briefcase Runs Ballet Theater

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
RACHEL S. Moore, the new executive director of American Ballet Theater, pauses to get her bearings backstage at the Metropolitan Opera House. Which way to turn? Ms. Moore has just stepped out of the main rehearsal room, where dancers are practicing their steps for the market scene in ''Romeo and Juliet,'' a production that will end the dance company's spring season tomorrow.
 It's not that she is merely a few months into her job, which she began in mid-April. The backstage area is a cavernous place with corridors leading into the vast bowels of the opera house. At one far end, there is an elevator the size of a large living room to move sets. 
 ''I still get lost,'' says Ms. Moore, a former member of Ballet Theater's corps de ballet.
 This moment of hesitation is a rare uncertain move for Ms. Moore, who comes across as supremely sure-footed during a long conversation on a recent afternoon.
 The chat begins when she strides into sight from the shadows of backstage right, setting down a leather briefcase and flashing a smile. She has just returned from a luncheon at Tavern on the Green for high-level donors. A look at those turned-out legs in black patent-leather pumps, and it's not hard to peg her former life. She danced in the company under the direction of Mikhail Baryshnikov from 1984 to 1988.
 Ms. Moore's performing role now is to bring stability to a premier company that has seen tumult in recent years, with questions raised by former trustees about the company's financial health, and a high turnover of executive directors. She is the fourth executive director in four years.
 And she thought she had it tough as a dancer, performing eight times a week, her poor feet taking a pounding on hard floors. It led to injury, surgery and the end of a dancing career at the age of 24.
 What a comeback. At 40, she is cheerfully optimistic about the challenges ahead. ''We are aiming for a balanced budget for this year; that's an absolute expectation,'' she says. ''I think it's very achievable. ''
 Ms. Moore previously directed the Center for Dance Education at the Boston Ballet, and also served as an interim leader for Boston Ballet during a similarly tumultuous period. 
 American Ballet Theater, which has a budget of $35 million this year, gets half of its annual revenues from donations, and the rest from earned income like ticket sales. Ms. Moore says the operating deficit in the last fiscal year was $1.1 million.
 On this afternoon, it is easy to be distracted by the merriment on the grand stage. Dancers, resplendent in costumes and makeup, are twirling and flitting high off the floor in a full-dress rehearsal of the comic ballet ''Coppelia.'' The orchestra warms up in a cacophony of sounds.
 Her arms folded, Ms. Moore peers through the curtains. Does she miss being out there? ''It certainly brings back memories,'' she says. ''You're always primed and gearing up for a show, so it's very high energy. The pressure now is very great but vastly different.''
 Ms. Moore is somberly dressed in a slate-blue Calvin Klein suit. As she talks, she is no-nonsense, her hands clasped. She chooses her words carefully. No juicy tidbit about Mr. Baryshnikov will be elicited on this day.
 So what are her plans for Ballet Theater? ''My challenge will be how to build a business model to allow us to have financial stability and continue to tour,'' she says. ''The key is the A.B.T. is one of the finest classical ballet companies in the world and when there is excellence, I believe we will find a way to make it thrive.''
 Is there any chance of American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet merging? ''I'd be surprised,'' she says. Are there any plans to find a permanent home for the Ballet Theater? ''It's not something that is at the top of the heap of what we're looking at,'' she says.
 MS. MOORE had been director of the Boston Ballet's dance schools from 2001 until this year. She also held administrative posts at a classical music school for minority students in Boston, at the Ballet Theater of Boston and at arts organizations in Washington. When she danced with American Ballet Theater, she was a member of the dancers' union committee and chairwoman of the Dancers' Emergency Fund.
 While in a cast from her foot surgery, she took college entrance exams and was accepted into Brown University, where she graduated with honors in 1992 as a philosophy major. She also has a master's degree in arts administration from Columbia. She is married to Robert Ryan, the chief executive of a pharmaceutical services company in Milwaukee. They see each other on weekends.
 The daughter of economists, Ms. Moore grew up in Davis, Calif. She began dancing at age 11, becoming hooked immediately. ''I danced from the heart,'' she says.
 There is time for one more peek on the stage. The renowned choreographer of the ''Coppelia'' revival, Frederic Franklin, spry at age 90, is putting the finishing touches to the performance with Kevin McKenzie, the company's artistic director. Mr. McKenzie breaks away from dancers to lope over to Ms. Moore's side. ''She's one of us,'' he says. 
 She looks pleased. She is home. ''Because I believe in this company and this art form,'' she says, ''it was not a risky proposition to come here.''

HEADLINE: Realism Aside, Now Is the Time to Savor Next Season's Goodies

BYLINE: By John Rockwell

 BODY:
It isn't often that journalists write about news releases; doing so will only encourage more to fill up our mail slots and clog our e-mail queues. That said, I was struck recently by a 15-page release from the theatrical press agents Boneau/Bryan-Brown trumpeting their ''fall preview 2004,'' meaning shows they are representing.
 I was not struck by the belle-lettristic quality of the prose (we belle-lettrists, or at least those of us who don't work for Variety, try to avoid the verb ''helm'' as shorthand for ''direct''). Nor does this release represent anything like the entirety of the forthcoming theatrical season, in New York or nationwide, although Boneau/Bryan-Brown has a pretty good list.
 What I began thinking about was the thrill, illusory but palpable, of anticipation. Every year in the late spring and early summer not just journalists but ordinary arts-loving mortals start noticing seasonal announcements in their newspapers, and brochures in their mailboxes. Browsing through this material provides its own kind of pleasure, sometimes even more pleasure than attending the actual events or, certainly, laying out the money for tickets and subscriptions, often for locations or dates that are not your first choice. 
 We live in an era (and, in New York, in a city) in which there is much fretting about the health of the theater. Broadway is cheesy. Off Broadway is underfinanced and ignored by the Tonys. The classics are woefully represented. There's little money for bold new productions on a grand scale (even if you broaden the concept of theater to include opera), and hence little experience of such productions, and hence philistine hostility against them. Hidden among the dross are gems, to be sure, but it takes a lot of effort and sophistication to find them.
 But that's just the experience of having suffered through a lot of shows in the past. With news releases and advertisements and brochures, we can live in a roseate future in which all that's been broken has been fixed, all that's been tawdry has become shiny and new. Looking at Boneau/Bryan-Brown's list, we see oldies like Arthur Miller's ''After the Fall'' and Reginald Rose's ''Twelve Angry Men''; maybe, all unexpectedly, they will speak to us with a fresh relevance, will be revealed as timeless masterpieces that have transcended their dated trappings. Tennessee Williams (''A Streetcar Named Desire'' and four early one-acters) will be back, too, as will Sam Shepard (''Fool for Love'').
 Or maybe it's stars you look forward to. I don't know if even Melissa Errico can get me to Frank Wildhorn's ''Dracula,'' but maybe, maybe. I will definitely be there for Mary-Louise Parker in Craig Lucas's ''Reckless.''
 Some stars lurk backstage. There are playwrights, aside from Mr. Lucas: new work by Bryony Lavery and Michael Frayn (his ''Democracy,'' a hit in London) and Neil LaBute (with an even more LaButian title than usual, ''Fat Pig'') and David Mamet and Charles Busch and Elaine May and Woody Allen. Wallace Shawn is revamping the book and lyrics for ''The Threepenny Opera,'' and there will be still more Stephen Sondheim (yet another staging of the eminently stage-worthy ''Pacific Overtures'').
 In the West End, but no doubt heading our way, the director Richard Eyre and the choreographer Matthew Bourne will try to pump life into ''Mary Poppins.'' Mike Nichols and Eric Idle are staging the film ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' in Chicago with an eye toward moving it to Broadway, under the perhaps unfortunate title of ''Spamalot.''
 Those are just some of the items on one agency's list. Beyond theater, there are seasonal announcements of exhibitions at our major museums. The big opera and dance companies tempt us with their wares. There are concert series at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center. Jazz at the flashy new headquarters of Jazz at Lincoln Center in the Time Warner building. Preview lists of forthcoming films.
 It's enough to dizzy the mind, but it's almost as much fun, or more fun, than the actual effort will be next fall of schlepping off to the events you've chosen, paying for parking and dinner and a babysitter, and then being sleepy or bored or both.
 What's fun about anticipation, even if your rational mind suspects that the real thing may be not so hot, is that you can zero in on one aspect of a forthcoming event and ignore, for now, all the other elements. This is known as the Melissa Errico trumps Frank Wildhorn phenomenon.
 The 2004-5 Metropolitan Opera season, for example, looks grimly conservative and unimaginative, presumably reflecting timidity in the wake of the company's recent falloff at the box office. There are only four new productions: Mozart's ''Zauberflote'' (in a Julie Taymor production) and Gounod's ''Faust''; the other two are star vehicles, Handel's ''Rodelinda'' for Renee Fleming and Alfano's ''Cyrnano de Bergerac,'' which, with all due deference to its undoubted, if heretofore well hidden, genius is clearly another sop to Placido Domingo.
 That duly grumbled, delicious, delusory anticipation can still reign. The opera lover can look forward to individual performances: Barbara Frittoli in ''Don Carlo'' and ''Otello,'' for instance, or Karita Mattila in ''Kat'a Kabanova,'' Anne Sofie von Otter in ''Pelleas et Melisande,'' Deborah Voigt in ''Tannhauser,'' and a bunch of Russians (not always the best Russians from the Kirov Opera ''Ring,'' but Russians nonetheless) in ''Die Walkure'' led by Valery Gergiev. And then, for fun, there is the new-music specialist Dennis Russell Davies conducting ''Cav'' and ''Pag''; perhaps he'll do so brilliantly, but on the surface this doesn't sound like playing to an artist's strengths.
 Such are the musings that bedazzle the brain as news about a forthcoming season drifts in and gustatory speculation gets going in earnest. Of course, the very word gustatory should sound an alarm bell. Bertolt Brecht railed against bourgeois ''culinary'' culture. Not culture as confrontation or moral or spiritual or political enlightenment, but culture as good eats. We in New York know all about that kind of gorging. What could be closer to the culinary metaphor of an overweight culture vulture waddling down a table full of promised goodies, pecking away at what might be particularly tasty, salivating over a brochure like a restaurant menu. Calling Neil LaBute: ''Fat Pig'' indeed. 
 But forget Brecht, forget Mr. LaBute, at least for now. Today the goodies on the groaning board look too tempting, and visions of imaginary arts meals dance in our eyes. Who cares, for now, about the economic crunch that makes serious work harder and harder to do on Broadway? Who cares about the paucity of public support for the arts, or underfinanced arts education, or skyrocketing ticket prices? Never mind about those brain-dead Hollywood summer blockbusters and reality television shows and the dearth of vital new composers, conductors and choreographers. Or those imitative pop acts whose highest goal is to sound like someone else.
 Delusions! Phantoms! Munching our lotuses, we can live for now in that blissful season of anticipation, when all seems possible and cruel reality needn't trouble our dreams. We can believe that all the arts are robust, and that our own pleasures as culture consumers will be ample and infinite. For this brief moment, all's well with America and American culture. We'll worry about tomorrow tomorrow.

HEADLINE: City Report Differs With Jets On Gains From Stadium

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Sports and trade-show activity at a proposed $1.4 billion stadium for the Jets will more than cover the cost of the $600 million the city and state want to invest but will produce far fewer jobs and less tax revenue than the team has said, according to a report issued yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office.
 Under the budget office's most optimistic account, the stadium would generate about $28.4 million a year in new city tax revenue, more than enough to cover the $21 million a year in debt service needed for the city's $300 million investment. The state would get $24.9 million from the stadium, $11.9 million less than the Jets have estimated but enough to cover the state's debt service.
 Still, the report said, the stadium tax revenue would be $6.1 million a year less than the Jets said in their report. More important, the stadium would produce barely half the 6,971 permanent jobs estimated by the Jets, according to the report. 
 If the stadium, to be called the New York Sports and Convention Center, attracts only half the number of conventions the Jets predicted, city tax revenue would fall to $22.9 million, about what it would cost the city to service the debt.
 The Jets have said they would invest $800 million in building the stadium, while the city and state would provide a total of $600 million.
 Opponents have criticized the project for weeks, and yesterday its supporters, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, seized on aspects of the report to bolster their contention that the stadium over the West Side rail yards will be a economic engine for the city. The mayor said the report supported ''what we've been saying all along, and that is that this project will be a great economic boon to this city and that the anticipated tax revenues to this city will be much greater than the debt service.'' 
 The Jets described the report as ''pessimistic and inexpert,'' but also praised the budget office for analyzing the project's value as an exhibition hall, not simply as a stadium. All in all, the Jets said, the building will generate about $72 million a year in new state and city tax revenue, or about $30 million more than they believe it will cost the city and state in annual debt payments.
 ''They're halfway right because they analyzed it as both a stadium and as a convention center,'' said Thad Sheely, the Jets' vice president for development. ''They give us 100 percent credit for sports uses but cut the convention business in half and do not provide an accurate assessment of the demand for mid-sized exhibition space in New York City.''
 The budget office's report also raised a number of questions about economic forecasts for the project and the wisdom of such a large public investment. Ronnie Lowenstein, director of the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan city agency, said stadium advocates were not reading the report very closely.
 ''The message we're trying to convey is not exactly the message the Jets and the mayor are spinning,'' she said. ''Our report found that there would be half the jobs the Jets are expecting and significantly less tax revenues for the city. We also found that two-thirds of the tax revenues are coming from convention and exposition activity, rather than football. But we know from past experience at convention centers around the country that those are very speculative assumptions.''
 New convention centers in both Washington and Boston are struggling, in part because of a significant oversupply of exhibition space and the sharp competition between cities for conventions and trade shows.
 Although the Jets predict that the stadium will attract 40 conventions and trade shows a year, Ms. Lowenstein said that expectation had to be treated with some skepticism.
 New York is a hugely attractive destination, she said, but it is not always the choice for cost-conscious conventions and trade shows, because it is also relatively expensive. 
 The average room rate at hotels in New York City is $170.38 per night, 80 percent more than in Orlando, Fla., ($94.58) or Chicago ($96.56), 44 percent more than in San Francisco ($118.19) and 122 percent more than Atlanta ($76.70), according to Smith Travel Research, a leading hotel industry data firm.
 ''New York is an expensive market,'' said Randy Smith, chief executive of Smith Travel. ''As a result, they don't get the convention business that Chicago, Orlando and Las Vegas get. Those are cheaper markets, and they've geared themselves to conventions.''
