HEADLINE: As Interest Rates Rise, So Do the Market Hazards

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
INVESTORS may not know how fast or how high market interest rates will ultimately rise once the Federal Reserve is done tightening the nation's monetary policy. But they do know that as rates climb, they will reassess what they are willing to pay for stocks.
 Common sense tells us that people are less likely to pay steep prices for shares of equities if alternatives -- like Treasury securities -- become more attractive. 
 That is certainly the way it has worked in the past. 
 Ned Davis Research, an investment advisory firm in Venice, Fla., recently compared 10-year Treasury yields and the so-called earnings yield of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index from March 31, 1965, to March 31, 2004. The earnings yield is the inverse of the price-to-earnings ratio; as such, it measures the amount of corporate profits investors are buying with their equity dollars. 
 Ned Davis researchers found a correlation between the two yields. In fact, a majority of moves in earnings yields can be explained by moves in long-term Treasury rates, they say. ''There are periods where, for a little bit of time, this doesn't hold true,'' said Sam Burns, senior equity research analyst for Ned Davis. But over time, he added, ''there is a relationship.''
 If earnings yields tend to rise with Treasury yields, then P/E ratios -- as their inverse -- are likely to fall. And that is exactly what tends to happen.
 So if history is any guide, P/E ratios, which have already fallen considerably from the lofty levels of the late 1990's -- because of falling prices in the bear market and rising earnings in the economic recovery -- may drop even more as the Fed raises rates to keep the economy from overheating.
 While Treasury yields have dropped this week,, they have risen sharply since the end of the first quarter, from 3.86 to 4.46 percent on Friday. Of course, that won't necessarily translate into lower stock prices, at least not right away. P/E ratios could fall simply if corporate earnings (the ''E'' in P/E) grow at a faster rate than stock prices (the ''P''). That has generally been the case so far this year, as earnings for the S.&P. 500 rose an estimated 27.5 percent in the first quarter and 20.8 percent in the second. Stock prices, without dividends, have risen only around 2.6 percent since the start of the year. 
 But if Treasury yields move higher, it would mean that investors, particularly those who benefited from owning more speculative, high-P/E stocks last year, will need to reassess the risk in their portfolios. That is especially true now that the Fed has begun to raise rates and the pace of corporate earnings growth is expected to be slower in the year's second half.
 ''Overvaluation in the stock market doesn't cause prices to go down, but it does cause your level of risk to rise,'' said James Stack, president of Stack Financial Management in Whitefish, Mont., and editor of InvesTech Market Analyst, a newsletter.
 What can investors do to lower this risk?
 First, they shouldn't overreact. Bill Nygren, manager of the value-oriented Oakmark Fund, notes that corporate earnings are expected to continue to grow this year, though perhaps not at the blistering rate they did in the second half of 2003. He argued that if inflationary worries turned out to be overblown and if rates didn't rise as much as expected -- a real possibility, he said -- stocks could end up performing better than many analysts predict.
 Because the gap between P/E ratios on high-quality and speculative shares has narrowed in recent years, Mr. Nygren said, worried investors should consider higher-quality stocks -- big household names like McDonald's and Anheuser-Busch. (Both are holdings in his fund.)
 Tobias Levkovich, chief United States equity strategist at Smith Barney, agreed. He said that ''the very largest of the large caps, the megacap names, look attractively valued'' relative to the rest of the market. He was referring to the largest 25 companies in the S.&P. 500 large-cap stock index. Historically, these giants have traded at a premium to the overall market, but that is not true today.
 Another option is to hunt for sectors of the economy that have tended to do best amid rising rates. 
 Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at S.&P., recently looked at the six periods in which the Fed has raised interest rates multiple times since 1970. Among the industries that outperformed the market were a couple of classic conservative sectors: health care and energy. Health care, in fact, was one of the few industries to have positive returns, on average, a year after the first rate increase during those periods, according to S.&P. 
 The energy sector continues to intrigue many money managers, and for a couple of reasons. For starters, many believe that while oil prices have declined from their recent highs, they are likely to stay above $30 a barrel for a while. That should help energy company earnings. Moreover, because energy profits are still rising amid high oil prices and strong global demand, the sector is trading at an average P/E of less than 12.3, based on estimated 2004 operating earnings. That is the lowest multiple among the S.&P.'s sectors. 
 The S.&P. study found that technology was the best-performing sector, on average, after initial rate increases in those six periods since 1970. But David Dreman, co-manager of the Scudder Dreman High Return Equity fund, said technology might not do so well this time around.
 Why not? Blue-chip tech stocks trade at an average of 25 times their 2004 estimated operating earnings, the highest P/E among sectors in the S.&P. ''The higher that interest rates go, the less you're willing to pay for the future,'' Mr. Dreman said. ''So my thought is, the Nasdaq, the tech sector, the dot-coms and other fast-growing segments of the market may have problems with P/E compression.''

HEADLINE: The Ripple Effect Of Losing a Landmark

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
ONE of the key reasons the Goodspeed Opera House decided to leave its longtime home lies tucked behind Main Street of East Haddam, a storybook village that invokes an image of Oz, minus the Munchkins. 
 Behind tri-colored houses draped with gingerbread, rainbows of flowers sneaking over their edges onto the paths of the narrow street and the grand, old Goodspeed -- a Victorian mansion set atop the Connecticut riverside -- there are acres and acres of wetlands. 
 For many who live and work in the little village that surrounds the Goodspeed, the wetlands are worth saving. For the Goodspeed, they were perfect for parking lots. 
 The Goodspeed Opera House has long been a cornerstone of tourism in Connecticut and its commitment to musical theater has brought it acclaim. But modernization has bypassed the Goodspeed for many years. 
 Six years ago, the Goodspeed's administrators gave East Haddam officials their plans for expansion. Almost immediately, several citizens of the downtown section of East Haddam formed the grassroots Village Planning Group. 
 ''We went in with the expectation that Goodspeed was going to expand here and we wanted to be sure it was done in the most balanced way possible,'' Kris DiErrico said as she sat in her office overlooking the wetlands in question.
 Ms. DiErrico is the design half of Lifespace, an architecture and interior design firm a few houses away from the Goodspeed. ''The question was, 'Could we handle the scope of this massive project in this little town?''' 
 After years of meetings with town officials, the Goodspeed got tired of waiting for the answer and took Middletown up on its offer to provide two sites for a new Goodspeed to open four years from now. One site is for the theater, the other for offices, a production shop, a library. The announcement surprised few in the village section of East Haddam who had been monitoring negotiations between the theater and East Haddam and the theater and Middletown. It appalled outsiders, though. 
 ''It's a sin,'' said Lisa Aurora as she fluffed her daughter's wedding dress outside the Goodspeed a few days after the announcement.
 Mrs. Aurora's wedding pictures had been taken at the Goodspeed, and now the daughter was standing where the mother had stood, on the steps of the theater. 
 ''We would not be shooting photographs here if the Goodspeed was not producing shows, oh no,'' Mrs. Aurora said. ''There's just something about the Goodspeed and the history and the presence.'' 
 Those are words local restaurateurs, who have made at least some of their living from Goodspeed patrons, did not want to hear. The bride was posing just steps away from the Gelston House, bought by the Carbone Restaurant Group eight years ago. The company transformed the aging inn, opening a grill, a tavern and a beer garden and refurbishing several rooms above for overnight stays. The restaurant is only steps from the theater and is so dependent on theater clientele that it structures the hours of its grill room to accommodate matinees and special showings.
 ''The sun will come up tomorrow,'' said Michael Androw, the general manager, invoking a line from the hit show, ''Annie,'' which made its debut at the Goodspeed. ''Our business is going to be here tomorrow. And it still remains to be seen. No shovels have hit the earth yet.''
 The drawbridge of the East Haddam Swing Bridge went up, and cars began to accumulate, waiting for the bridge to reopen. From the porch of the Gelston House, Carol and Herb Criswell of Signal Mountain, Tenn., watched the line grow. 
 ''We've always heard of the Goodspeed,'' said Mr. Criswell, who was in town to see his daughter, Kim Criswell, perform as lead actress in Goodspeed's current production, ''Call Me Madam.''
 ''I think moving the Goodspeed to another town is a disappointment. It's the keystone of this little town.''
 Across the street, Jacqueline Cacace, who co-owns LaVita Gustosa, a restaurant and bakery, stood behind the bakery counter talking about the move.
 ''Of course we were upset and disappointed,'' said Mrs. Cacace, who with her husband has been negotiating to buy the building where their businesses stand.
 Although the bakery gets little business from Goodspeed patrons, the restaurant depends on them for more than a quarter of its business, Mrs. Cacace said. ''We're worried about property values dropping once the Goodspeed leaves,'' she said. ''But we're going to do our best to adjust to their changing situation.''
 At Fish Sisters, a clothing boutique, the owner, Carole Scherrer, said she doesn't depend on the Goodspeed for her customer base. But she lives in town, she said, and is disappointed with the Goodspeed's decision.
 ''The Goodspeed is East Haddam and East Haddam is the Goodspeed,'' she said. ''People come here from all over just to visit the opera house.''
 The theater is nonprofit, so it does not rate in the town's Top 10 taxpayer list, according to the tax assessor's office. The theater employs about 200 people in the summertime, when it runs two shows. Year-round, Goodspeed employs about 60. The theater's move will be profound in the loss of millions of dollars of spin-off spending, town officials said.
 Middletown's offer is contingent upon about $30 million in state bond money. Gov. John G. Rowland has been generous with state bond money in the past, particularly for urban reclamation projects such as the one Middletown is trying to affect on its Main Street. With a new governor, however, and the issue not yet before the state bond commission, no one, including Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, a member of the commission, could say for certain if bond money would be allocated for the project. ''I think most commission members at this point are getting their information from the newspapers,'' Mr. Blumenthal said Monday.
 In East Haddam, Brad Parker, East Haddam's first selectman, was buying coffee and sweets at La Vita Gustosa's bakery counter. Just when he thought the Goodspeed was swinging East Haddam's way, theater officials took the Middletown offer, he said. 
 ''We've been working very hard with them in recent weeks,'' he said. Then he took umbrage with Middletown's use of state money to lure the theater there, and said he had already written a letter to the governor expressing his concerns.
 ''The state shouldn't get involved with this,'' he said. ''What kind of message will the state be giving to small towns if they start following this practice?'' 
 Middletown's mayor was unapologetic. ''They never got so far as even giving them permission,'' Mayor Domenique Thornton said. ''They never granted the theater approval, and as a matter of fact their zoning requirements were so restrictive that there was no way this type of structure would ever have been built in East Haddam.''
 East Haddam officials said they have worked long and hard to keep the Goodspeed in town, short of destroying wetlands. ''It's hard to turn a swamp into a parking lot,'' Mr. Parker has said in the past.
 The town was in the process of enacting a zone change to accommodate the size of the Goodspeed's expansion, but there was little it could do about the wetlands issue, he said.
 At least one village merchant was unmoved by the announcement.
 ''I'll miss the actors and the actresses who come in,'' said Mike Billings, the proprietor of Delo's package store. ''There's going to be changes. But what comes with change is possibility.'' 
 Mrs. Aurora wasn't happy, though.
 ''This is a landmark in Connecticut,'' she said, fixing a flyaway hair on her daughter's brow. ''This is what Connecticut is, right here.''

 and Brad Parker, the town's first selectman. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Indonesians Hope a Real Election on Monday Will Bring Real Change

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: PROBOLINGGO, Indonesia, July 2 

 BODY:
Over baskets of warm rice and vats of steaming soup, the election patter at the breakfast stall, a few rickety benches deep inside the food market here, got off to a brisk start. 
 There was no way, said the proprietress, a spry 64-year-old military widow called Ariyo, that she would vote for anyone from the ancien regime that ruled Indonesia with an iron hand for more than 30 years. 
 Nor was she going to listen to the recommendation of a prominent Muslim leader. The incumbent, President Megawati Sukarnoputri, was not an option either, she said. 
 ''I'm voting for S.B.Y.,'' Mrs. Ariyo said with a triumphant smile, carefully enunciating the initials of Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, a former general. ''He can stabilize the prices, and make things safe.'' 
 General Yudhoyono, a relative newcomer to Indonesia's rough and tumble politics, is the front-runner in the presidential election on Monday, according to voter surveys. He has consistently received more than 40 percent in the opinion surveys in the last several weeks, far ahead of four other rivals. 
 The voting will be the first round in a two-tiered election, the first time that Indonesians will directly choose their president. It will be a milestone in the democratic development of this, the world's most populous Muslim country.
 General Yudhoyono, until recently the minister for national security in Mrs. Megawati's cabinet and a graduate of two military training programs in the United States, will probably fall short of 50 percent of the vote, the polls show, meaning that he would face a runoff vote on Sept. 5.
 Most political analysts here are saying, though, that he will emerge as Indonesia's next president. 
 Much of General Yudhoyono's support appears to come from people like Mrs. Ariyo, who feel unencumbered in their choice by loyalty to political party, religious organization or even village headman. People say they are choosing whom they want, and the polls indicate they are choosing based on their feeling that he is trustworthy, rather than on any specific issues or stances.
 ''We're supposed to follow Gus Dur,'' said Mrs. Ariyo, using the nickname of Abdurrahman Wahid, a former leader of Nahdlatul Ulama, the country's biggest Muslim organization. ''But he's there for religion, and this is politics.'' A couple of early patrons murmured agreement. 
 Moreover, she said, she did not approve of Mr. Wahid's choice for president, General Wiranto. (Many Indonesians use only one name.) The general, a former chief of the armed forces under Suharto, has been indicted for crimes against humanity in East Timor by a tribunal supported by the United Nations.General Wiranto won the nomination of the Golkar Party, the established political machine from the Suharto era. But Golkar appears to be unable to deliver with its customary efficiency. 
 In recent months five presidential candidates have gone through the trappings of campaigning that are common in well-entrenched democracies: public rallies, a televised debate and expensive television advertisements. 
 Newspapers have been filled with campaign coverage, and in some cases publications have made points in indirect ways. To show General Wiranto's cozy connection to the Suharto government, for example, the weekly magazine Tempo found an old photograph that showed Suharto signing a piece of paper on the back of General Wiranto, who was leaning over to be used as a desk by the dictator.
 Almost slyly, the magazine found an old photo of a young President Megawati with her husband, Taufik Kiemas, both looking very slim compared with their portly figures now. 
 In a poll by the International Foundation for Election Systems, released Thursday, General Wiranto received the support of only 14.2 percent of respondents, compared with 43.5 percent for General Yudhoyono. 
 Despite the lack of openness in the financing of the campaigns, people who have worked over the last dozen years to bring democracy to Indonesia seemed pleased with the way they have unfolded.
 ''It's almost revolutionary that people think they can choose independently of their organization,'' said Smita Notosusanto, director of the Center for Electoral Reform, who led the effort to get a constitutional amendment that allowed for a direct presidential election. 
 But as Election Day nears, independent choice is not the case everywhere. 
 At Nurul Jadid, an Islamic boarding school in Paiton, 25 miles east of here, one of the principals, Malthuf Siroj, said he was instructing students of voting age to vote for General Wiranto. Of the more than 7,000 students at the school, about 60 percent could vote, he said. Huge banners for General Wiranto hung across the entrances to classrooms and dormitories. 
 The principal explained that he was supporting General Wiranto because his running mate, Salahuddin Wahid, is the brother of Abdurrahman Wahid, the former leader of Nahdlatul Ulama and the spiritual leader of the school. 
 Indeed, General Wiranto specifically chose Salahuddin Wahid as his vice presidential candidate in an effort to capture a big slice of the votes here in the Nahdlatul Ulama stronghold.
 But in another sign of the newly competitive nature of Indonesian politics, President Megawati countered by choosing the current leader of Nahdlatul Ulama, Hasyim Muzadi, as her running mate.
 None of the five candidates favor the introduction of an Islamic state in a country known for its largely tolerant practice of Islam. 
 Aside from the institutional trappings of electioneering that have emerged, the campaigning has produced a new kind of political creature in Indonesia: organizers who have not previously been involved in politics. 
 At the Nirwana restaurant here, an upscale version of Mrs. Ariyo's food stand, one of General Yudhoyono's precinct workers was marveling over how hard she had worked in the last two months. 
 The organizer, Yuniar Sulastri, a 46-year-old mother of two who owns the restaurant with her husband, said she had gone house to house in the district handing out pamphlets, battery-operated wall clocks and coffee mugs emblazoned with the candidate's face. 
 Ms. Sulastri joked that her task had been made fairly simple. 
 The recently elected local legislator representing General Yudhoyono's Democratic Party was a very popular Indonesian movie star, Adjie Massaid. He is usually seen in television soap operas in jeans and a T-shirt. 
 ''We put him in Muslim clothes,'' said Ms. Sulastri, handing around palm cards of the movie star dressed in a white Islamic hat and white robes. ''I campaigned with him for three months. That made it easy.'' 
 The campaigning has been fairly light on the discussion of issues, even though Indonesia's economic growth falls behind its neighbors and unemployment continues to grow. 
 Focus groups conducted by the Washington-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs showed that voters were interested in the personal probity of candidates. ''Corruption, collusion and nepotism'' were the most consistently cited problems with the country's politics, the institute said. 
 Indonesia was listed as the 10th most corrupt country in the world in the most recent ratings by Transparency International, a watchdog group. But voters told the focus groups that General Yudhoyono appeared to be a man of ''integrity, quiet competence and authoritative bearing.'' 
 That judgment seemed to be borne out at the breakfast stand. ''I'm voting for S.B.Y., he's clean,'' said Halimah, 35, the daughter of the owner.

HEADLINE: Honk if You Love Railroads

BYLINE: By Verlyn Klinkenborg. 
Verlyn Klinkenborg writes editorials for The Times. He is the author, most recently, of ''The Rural Life.''

 BODY:

THE OLD IRON ROAD
An Epic of Rails, Roads,
and the Urge to Go West.
By David Haward Bain.
Illustrated. 434 pp. Viking. $27.95.
 IMAGINE a picaresque race across the country, east to west. Some of the racers -- like the historian David Haward Bain and his family, for instance -- live in the present. Some live in the past, like Samuel Clemens, the Donner-Reed party, assorted forty-niners and Mormons and emigrants. A few, like the Bains and Alice Huyler Ramsey, who in 1909 became the first woman to drive across the country, pay little attention to the clock. Others, like Grenville Dodge, chief engineer for the Union Pacific, are really racing against bankruptcy, and to them time is everything. Many begin the journey in St. Joseph, Mo., the traditional jumping-off point for the westward journey, but most come from farther east, like the Bains, who started in Vermont. Some take the train, some lay the rails, some walk, some drive oxen, and some drive the Lincoln Highway or the country roads that thread away from the Interstate. Set them all on the road together, as simultaneously as the linear nature of words will allow, and you have Bain's book ''The Old Iron Road.''
 Bain is the author of ''Empire Express: Building the First Transcontinental Railroad'' (1999), a history of the enterprise that culminated in the joining of the Central Pacific and Union Pacific railroads in the Golden Spike Ceremony at Promontory, Utah, in May 1869. Researching and writing that book took 14 years, and Bain planned the cross-country journey he describes in ''The Old Iron Road'' as a way to reward his wife and children for their patience and support -- and, really, to show them some of the wonders he had come across in his work. In one sense, then, ''The Old Iron Road'' is a retelling of ''Empire Express'' from a personal angle. Instead of the chronologies of politics and economics and track laying, this book is anchored by the geographies of the many Americas Bain and his family found as they made their way west by car.
 But another impulse also drives this book. Writing a big book -- and, just short of 800 pages, ''Empire Express'' is very big -- requires a tunnel vision that gets narrower and narrower as time passes. You forget how much you know and remember only how much there is to know. You stop looking around and start staring at your next few steps. In ''The Old Iron Road,'' Bain affords himself the luxury of wandering -- literally -- over the tracks his previous book set down across the American West. But this time he gets to make all the detours, take all the dead-end roads, meet all the characters he did not have time for or did not know about the first time around. In ''The Old Iron Road,'' the dead seem to rise up to greet him as he goes, and the living save all their best stories for him.
 We meet a lot of familiar folks on the road with Bain -- John C. Fremont, Calamity Jane, Henry Fonda, Fred Astaire, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. But we also meet a lot of people who are less well known, like Edwin E. Perkins, late of Hastings, Neb. Perkins was an inventor whose imagination was wedded to the hyphen. He created Motor-Vigor, Glos-Comb and Jel-Aid before finally perfecting in 1927 the product that made him wealthy, Kool-Aid. We get to know railroad ghost towns before the people moved out and the ghosts moved in. We get a distant glimpse of the thousands of Chinese who worked on the rails nearly a century and a half ago, their ''acres of canvas tents staked out along the railroad grade'' and their ''cook fires redolent with peanut oil, garlic, cuttlefish and pork.''
 It is impossible to cross this country by land without being changed by the experience. ''The Old Iron Road'' captures this fact vividly, in as many different forms as Bain can find room for in its pages. And if, at times, we feel as though we've been dragged through far too many county museums and eaten in far too many historic hotels with unhistoric food, it is still engaging to cross the country in the company of someone who knows the road so well. Best of all, Bain leads the reader to people who know every inch of the crossing -- by rail or ox cart -- better than he can imagine. We are lucky to be in their company, even for a while.
 For many readers, ''The Old Iron Road'' may seem like a book to travel with, to lead them off the main roads and into a hidden country. When it becomes a paperback, I hope it will be reprinted in the form of an old-fashioned AAA TripTik, one of those customized plastic-bound route guides that the auto club prepared, and still prepares, to guide travelers on their way. In a TripTik, each new page is a new stretch of road, with side routes and attractions properly marked. ''The Old Iron Road'' is a book that cries out for that kind of graphical representation, a way of visually chronicling all the American journeys it contains.

HEADLINE: Russia Wants to Supply Energy to North Korea

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia, June 29 

 BODY:
Russia is moving to become a major supplier of electricity and gas to North Korea at a time when the supply of nonnuclear energy sources available to that impoverished country is emerging as an important bargaining chip in talks intended to defuse North Korea's nuclear weapons program.
 ''We are building energy transmission lines to the North Korean border,'' Sergei Darkin, governor of Russia's Pacific Maritime region, said in an interview on Monday. Governor Darkin said that if President Vladimir V. Putin ''gives us the task of transmitting energy to North Korea next year, we will be ready to do that.''
 North Korean negotiators said at the recent talks in Beijing that one price for freezing their nuclear-bomb program would be getting fuel supplies from other nations to provide two million kilowatts of power a year. That is roughly the output that was expected from the two nuclear reactors that were to be built under the 1994 international accord intended to end North Korea's nuclear weapons program. 
 Although South Korea spent about $800 million on the initial construction of the power plants, the program was frozen 18 months ago after North Korea ended international monitoring of nuclear materials that could be processed into bomb fuel.
 What is behind North Korea's demands for power is a shortage that has contributed to the nation's industrial collapse.
 Governor Darkin said Russia was completing plans to export excess electricity from Russian hydroelectric dams to the Korean peninsula, sending power also through North Korea to South Korea. Skeptics say such a project would enable North Korea to turn off lights in South Korea. But supporters say that North Korea would become dependent on the arrangement and moderate its behavior.
 At a conference in June to discuss energy-sharing between Russia and the Korean peninsula, North Korean officials agreed to provide by August basic data on its electric power system to the Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, a South Korean government research group.
 Separately, Russian and Korean energy planners are studying routes for a Korean peninsula extension to a gas line now under construction to Khabarovsk from huge gas deposits off the Pacific coast of Russia's Sakhalin Island.
 A 1,900-mile pipeline from these reserves to Seoul would take four years to build and would cost up to $3.5 billion, Selig S. Harrison, a Korea expert at the Center for International Policy in Washington, said in an interview in Seoul. North Korean officials strongly favor building this line, said Mr. Harrison, who had extensive meetings with North Korean officials in April in Pyongyang, the capital. South Korea would probably finance the construction. 
 The ExxonMobil Corporation, the lead developer of one gas field in Sakhalin, has started to build a gas line to Khabarovsk. Russian officials want the line extended 450 miles south, to Vladivostok. The line could be extended through North Korea to Seoul, regional energy experts say.
 North Korea ''built its economy primarily around the abundant, low-cost Chinese crude oil flowing directly to its refineries,'' Mr. Harrison wrote in a recent essay explaining the North Koreans' desperate energy shortage to a regional energy cooperation conference in Seoul. But with the collapse of the Soviet Union and the conversion of China from oil exporter to oil importer, North Korea's crude oil imports have dropped by 85 percent, he wrote. By allowing the construction of gas and electric lines from Russia through its territory, North Korea could earn transmission fees, paid in energy.
 If its economy revives, North Korea could also buy Russian oil, which is expected to come to a maritime terminus near this port city as part of a planned pipeline from the eastern Siberian reserves. Vladivostok increasingly hopes to become a Northeast Asian crossroads. Last Sunday, a dozen English-language teachers from both Koreas mingled amiably at an academic conference in Vladivostok, long considered neutral ground by Koreans. 
 This weekend, Russia's foreign minister, Sergei V. Lavrov, is visiting both South Korea and North Korea, reportedly to lay the groundwork for a fall summit meeting in Vladivostok with President Putin of Russia and the leaders of the two Koreas. 
 ''Kim Jong Il is a man who goes by protocol, a very methodical person, so first there should be meetings by foreign ministers,'' said Olga P. Maltseva, a Vladivostok journalist who on Tuesday celebrated the publication here of her new book about the North Korean leader, ''A Waltz With Kim Jong Il.''
 In recent days, Russian railroad stations between here and the North Korean border were on alert for a possible visit by Mr. Kim in his armored train. He rode the train to Moscow on an earlier visit.
 His father, Kim Il Sung, visited the Soviet Union 10 times, often meeting Soviet leaders secretly in Vladivostok, Larisa Zabroskaya, a Korea expert at the Russian Academy of Science, said in an interview here. Ms. Zabroskaya, who believes that President Putin is trying to broker an inter-Korean summit meeting here this fall, said, ''In Soviet times, there was a tradition that whenever a Soviet leader came to Vladivostok, the North Korean leader would come to Vladivostok.''
 Pak Jong Song, director general of the North Korean Railway Ministry, recently endorsed Mr. Putin's plan to create a rail network that he calls the ''Iron Silk Road'' to link North and South Korea's railroads with the Trans-Siberian Railway. In a return gesture, Russia sent 35,000 tons of wheat to North Korea, Russia's first food aid to North Korea, through the United Nations World Food Program.
 North Korea's courting of Russia is part of a wider diplomatic offensive started this spring to isolate the United States, American analysts say.
 In April, Kim Jong Il traveled to Beijing. In May, he received a visit from Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi. Also in May, North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations, Han Song Ryol, floated the possibility of North Korea signing a peace treaty with the United States and South Korea. [On Friday, Mr. Koizumi told the Japanese NTV television network that he wanted to normalize relations with North Korea within one year, adding, ''The earlier, the better.'']
 North Korea wants to improve ''bilateral relations with Tokyo and Seoul while remaining on good terms with Beijing and Moscow,'' C. Kenneth Quinones, a Washington-based Korea expert, wrote recently for a Japanese newspaper. ''Pyongyang's efforts have deflected much diplomatic pressure back on to Washington.''

HEADLINE: Marching Sideways Into the Second Half

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM

 BODY:
DOMESTIC stock mutual funds have extended their winning streak to five quarters -- but just barely, as the threat of rising interest rates, inflation and uncertainty in Iraq has set a sober tone on Wall Street.
 In many ways, the second quarter was transitional for the markets, investors and the mutual fund business, which faced new rules from federal regulators to bolster the independence of fund boards.
 The average general mutual fund that invests in domestic stocks eked out a gain of about 0.8 percent, on average, in the quarter. Among all domestic equity funds, the average gain was just 0.7 percent. That compares with a gain of 3.3 percent in the first quarter and 11.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 2003, a remarkable year for the equity markets. 
 For now, though, the buzz seems to have worn off, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up only 2.6 percent in the first half and 1.3 percent in the second quarter, and the Dow Jones industrial average showing a slight loss of 0.2 percent for the first half, and a tiny gain of less than 0.1 percent for the quarter. 
 At least stock funds made money. Bond funds, coping with the threat of rising inflation and interest rates, lost 1.8 percent, on average, in the recent quarter as bond prices fell. 
 Russel Kinnel, director of mutual fund research at Morningstar Inc., said the stock market ''has been drunk on cheap money from the federal government for a while,'' referring to low interest rates and the fiscal stimulus. 
 ''You have to figure the hangover is coming,'' he said.
 It may already be here. Investors got a sobering taste of it on the final day of the quarter, as the Federal Reserve Board began the painful process of weaning Wall Street from its addiction to historically low interest rates.
 Last week, the central bank raised its target on the federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 1.25 percent, in the first of what many people expect to be a series of rate increases in coming months.
 The wait for the rate move kept the major stock indexes in a tight trading range for weeks, making the job of equity fund managers that much more difficult. 
 ''A sideways market to me is a very logical development when you have a confluence of good economic data and good corporate profits supporting the market, but two major uncertainties pressuring it,'' said Nick Sargen, chief investment officer at Fort Washington Investment Advisors in Cincinnati. Mr. Sargen was referring to geopolitical concerns surrounding the violence and transition of authority in Iraq, which led to higher oil prices in the second quarter, and, of course, to the outlook for interest rates.
 The mere threat of inflation and rising rates has already had an impact on the bond market, where the yield on 10-year Treasury notes, for example, was up to 4.58 percent at the end of June, from 3.86 percent at the end of March.
 As a result, long-term government bond funds, particularly vulnerable to interest rate risks, posted average losses of 4.7 percent.
 INTEREST rate fears also seemed to slow the performance of stock sector funds that invest in industries whose earnings may be hurt by higher borrowing costs. Among them were financial-services sector funds, which fell 2.7 percent, on average, in the quarter, and real estate funds, which were down 5.5 percent. That was a major turnaround from the first quarter, when real estate funds outperformed other categories of domestic stock portfolios, posting gains of around 12 percent. Technology funds were also among the poorer performers in the second quarter, posting average returns of 0.1 percent. 
 Still, fund investors did not appear too discouraged by the results, as they continued to put money into equity funds in the quarter. Nor did they seem fazed by news of industry reform, stemming from the mutual fund trading scandals that began last year. 
 In the quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission made a big change in the way mutual fund boards operate. By a vote of 3 to 2, the S.E.C. approved a requirement that all fund boards eventually be led by an independent chairman. The agency also requiredthat 75 percent of all board members be independent themselves. 
 Moreover, investors saw yet more settlements between major fund companies -- including Janus Capital, Strong Capital Management and Pilgram Baxter & Associates -- and state or federal regulators in the last quarter.
 The big question for fund investors in recent months has been where to put their money. Unlike the first quarter, when there were clear-cut winners -- small-capitalization stock funds, real estate funds and emerging-market funds, to name a few -- the second quarter was ''all over the map,'' Mr. Kinnel said.
 The performances of large-cap and small-cap funds, for example, were fairly similar, as were those of growth and value portfolios.
 But some market watchers say they saw a shift of sorts in market leadership in the quarter. ''I think we really saw the turn in April and May, particularly related to the heightened geopolitical problems in Iraq,'' said Joseph Quinlan, chief market strategist at Banc of America Capital Management.
 While speculative segments of the stock market did well in the first quarter, continuing a trend from 2003, investors began to embrace higher-quality assets, including blue-chip stocks and stock funds, in the second.
 Large-cap stocks held their own in the last quarter, but higher-quality large caps appeared to perform even better. Standard & Poor's categorizes stocks in the S.&P. 500 index based on the quality of the underlying companies' earnings and dividends and applies letter grades to them, from D to A+. In the second quarter, the C's fell 1.2 percent, while those rated A-, A or A+ rose 1.1 percent; in the first quarter, both groups rose, but the C's were far ahead. 
 There was another sign that speculation might be over: diversified emerging-markets funds fell by 9.1 percent over the last three months. That helped drag down the performance of international stock funds in general; they lost 2.4 percent, on average.
 But some market watchers are not convinced that the solid performance of domestic blue-chip stocks reflected a fundamental shift in investors' thinking.
 Some of the best-performing stock funds in the second quarter, for instance, were not blue-chip funds, but rather small-cap portfolios like Excelsior Small Cap, a growth fund that was up 6.6 percent. 
 Douglas H. Pyle, lead manager for the fund, said its success stemmed from its strategy of stepping only into stocks that had already experienced major declines in share price. Moreover, the fund has historically ignored real estate investment trusts, an avoidance that certainly helped in the quarter. ''What you don't own can often add to your performance,'' he said.
 As for the broad markets, there is disagreement over whether they are headed for a summer rally or the doldrums.
 The markets may be treading water this summer, said Mr. Sargen, of Fort Washington Investment Advisors, because of continuing worries about Iraq as well as terrorism fears, partly related to major summer events like the Olympic Games and the major political conventions. 
 BUT others point to a potentially positive wild card: corporate earnings.
 Mike Thompson, director of research at Thomson Financial , said Wall Street analysts had been steadily increasing their estimates for third-quarter S.&P. 500 earnings growth, to 14.1 percent at the end of June from 11.8 percent on April 1. Estimates have also climbed for fourth-quarter earnings, to 15.5 percent from 13.1 percent in April. 
 While that estimate would pale in comparison to 28.3 percent growth in the fourth quarter of 2003, ''These are fantastic numbers,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''We're growing at a blast-furnace pace.'' If the estimates materialize, overall profit growth for 2004 could exceed 20 percent. And that could be just the surprise to re-energize the markets, market watchers say.

HEADLINE: As Businesses Wander, New Jersey Fights Back

BYLINE: By SUSAN WARNER

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to business, New Jersey is raising the ante.
 Buffeted by recession, corporate poaching by other states and defections in New Jersey's signature pharmaceutical industry, the McGreevey administration has begun -- although belatedly -- to beef up efforts to attract new companies and hang on to those already here.
 After scaling back incentives and raising corporate taxes in last year's budget, Governor McGreevey has restored and in some cases enhanced the state's main program aimed at attracting and expanding business. Indeed, in the latest budget that was approved by the Legislature a little more than a week ago, new incentives were added to keep New Jersey businesses from straying.
 Not that all is well on corporate campuses around the state. Corporate tax rates remain among the highest in the nation, and the newly enacted ''millionaire's tax'' -- which despite its name applies to all personal income over $500,000 a year -- could alienate corporate leaders. 
 Nonetheless, James Leonard, vice president for government relations at the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, says, ''We hope we've turned the corner from the days of bashing the business community.''
 Mr. Leonard said it remains to be seen what effect the millionaire's tax may have on corporate locations but , ''Over all, I would say there is a better balance.''
 The governor is even getting into the act personally.
 When produce merchants in Philadelphia were recently considering a move across the Delaware River, Mr. McGreevey put in a conference call to them -- addressing many by name -- in an ultimately unsuccessful bid to lure 1,100 workers to a $94.9 million state-financed center in Camden. And in April, he ordered his entire cabinet to a special meeting with executives from pharmaceutical companies to discuss how the state could keep them happy -- and right where they were.
 ''We're in a very competitive environment,'' said State Treasurer John E. McCormac. ''We owe it to our residents to try and bring in projects that create jobs.''
 Compared with neighboring New York City, New Jersey is a bargain, and price-conscious businesses have flocked to the northern part of the state in recent years.
 ''New York City is obviously a relatively high-cost jurisdiction and many of the companies spurring development in Jersey City are interested in that,'' said Gaulberto Medina, who was chief executive of the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission in the Whitman administration and is now director of the technology enterprise group at Cushman & Wakefield in East Rutherford.
 In the southern tier, the state is eager to jump-start development in Camden, where it has already made a $175 million investment and is about to embark on a $1.3 billion redevelopment project. With that squarely in mind, officials offered enticing packages to coax both the produce merchants and the Cigna Corporation, an insurance company based in Philadelphia with 1,500 employees, across the Delaware River. In both cases, the businesses decided to stay where they were.
 For now at least, Mr. McCormac says that New Jersey will respond to companies only when approached, even though companies in the state are regularly courted by other states trying to attract high-paying technology jobs, particularly in pharmaceuticals and biotechnology.
 ''We don't play the game,'' Mr. McCormac said. ''We don't aggressively seek companies. We react to inquiries. We don't do mailings. We don't do visits. We don't do cold calls.''
 As for what New Jersey has to offer, Mr. McCormac says the state's business assets, including a well-educated work force and high-tech research infrastructure, speak for themselves.
 ''Anybody looking to expand or move would not be fulfilling their fiduciary obligations if they didn't consider New Jersey, particularly if they are in pharmaceuticals or financial services,'' he said. 
 In May, the most recent month for which figures are available, employment in New Jersey reached a record 4.04 million, according to the State Department of Labor. 
 New Jersey has the nation's highest median family income -- $70,488 a year, according to 2000 Census figures -- and a stable of high-paying manufacturing and professional jobs. But historically, the state has been less hungry than other locales to slug it out for new business, said Richard Harris, a professor of political science at Rutgers-Camden and director of the Rand Institute for Public Affairs.

Now, More Aggression
 ''Now the recent economic downturn has begun to pinch those high-end jobs as well,'' Professor Harris said. ''As a result, the state is becoming much more aggressive.''
 States are battling for companies like CareGain, a three-year-old startup that develops software for health insurers.
 In 2003, the company had 15 employees working in the corner of a warehouse. Since then, CareGain has grown to 45 employees and expects to have as many as 120 workers by the end of next year. The company moved in the spring to new space in East Windsor after qualifying for the state's Business Employment Incentive Program, which could be worth up to $950,000 over the next 10 years. In addition, the company expects to receive state job-training funds valued at up to $750,000 over the next 18 months.
 At the end of 2003, CareGain began to explore opportunities in Pennsylvania, New York and Connecticut as well as New Jersey. ''You've got to consider all of the economics,'' said William Hackett, the chief financial officer at CareGain.
 In the end, the company was satisfied with the state's help in financing its expansion. ''Our bias was to remain here, but absent these grants we would at least have gone further down the road in terms of offers from Pennsylvania and Connecticut,'' Mr. Hackett said.
 Critics say that such incentives are taxpayer-financed gifts to business that drain the public treasury. 
 ''What's happening here is companies are playing states off one another to get money,'' said Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a nonprofit research group. ''I have a feeling that behind the closed doors of the boardroom they're having a nice chuckle -- and we're paying for it.''
 The state's primary economic incentive program is the Business Employment Incentive Program, or BEIP, which provides grants equal to up to 80 percent of the state income tax that would be generated for each new job created. Since the program began in 1996, the state has awarded 206 grants worth a total of $650 million. For that outlay, according to the State Economic Development Authority, the grants are expected to generate a total of 45,000 jobs.
 Last year, Governor McGreevey cut the program while wrestling with a bulging budget, but he restored it in September after the decision had drawn howls from the business community, particularly from companies that had already decided to relocate in the state based on a 10-year payout.
 ''The governor received a lump on his head when he threatened to eliminate the BEIP program,'' said Philip Schepel, president of Mintax Inc., a consulting firm in East Brunswick that helps Fortune 1000 companies evaluate and negotiate government incentives. ''He and his staff have realized that business retention is very important in this state.'' 
 Another factor driving the state's more aggressive business posture, Mr. Schepel said, was a decision earlier this year by Merck, the pharmaceutical giant, to build a vaccine plant that employs 200 people in North Carolina. Merck, which has its corporate headquarters in Whitehouse Station and in fact once employed Mr. McGreevey, did not even ask New Jersey to make a bid for the project. 
 ''It wasn't that many jobs,'' Mr. Schepel said, ''but it had a psychological impact because it was Merck.''
 Indeed, mergers and cost pressures on pharmaceutical companies -- the state's leading industry -- have raised some alarms.

Battle for Drug Companies
 Last year, employment in the pharmaceutical industry remained at 63,000 -- the first time it had not gone up in more than a decade, according to the Health Care Institute of New Jersey. 
 Novartis, the Swiss drug-maker with operations in New Jersey, chose to expand in Cambridge, Mass., though it has since received a $5.8 million state grant to bolster its operations in New Jersey. Aventis, with its United States headquarters in Bridgewater and 3,500 workers in the state, is being acquired by a French rival, Sanofi-Synthelabo, which could jeopardize New Jersey jobs.
 Pfizer, which employs 5,500 in New Jersey, is seeking a grant for a possible expansion that will be presented to the state Economic Development Authority this month. The company is expected to argue that without state assistance it may have to look elsewhere, possibly Michigan, where it has additional laboratory space. The company has said that it would like to develop a $400 million research and commercial operations campus in Morris Plains that could involve up to 5,000 workers.
 ''Drug companies are our No.1 industry,'' Mr. McCormac said. ''We've got to make the extra effort to, first and foremost, keep them here and, second, make sure they consider New Jersey when they are thinking about expansion.'' 
 To underscore that point, when the state restored the incentive grants, it sweetened the program. In the past, New Jersey required companies applying for grants to create 25 new jobs if they were situated in an economically distressed part of the state and 75 positions elsewhere. Now companies can qualify for a grant if they hire just 25 workers anywhere in the state. Moreover, the job requirement drops to just 10 new positions for companies in certain high-tech industries. 
 In addition, the state extended the credit for workers who live in Pennsylvania -- making New Jersey more attractive to companies in that state looking for new space. Yet the state also tightened some provisions: it limited each grant to $50,000 per employee; it required that companies provide health care for the new workers; and it restricted the incentives to companies that agreed to build in conjunction with the governor's development policies. 
 But the biggest change was a provision allowing the state to finance the grants by borrowing rather than with general tax revenue. Not everyone agrees with that move. 
 ''The idea that we're going to go into debt to give this money back to businesses sets a bad precedent,'' said Mr. Shure, whose organization recently analyzed the incentive program.
 For his part, Mr. McCormac said the ability to float bonds to finance the grants was crucial to gaining business confidence in the program, particularly after the McGreevey administration cut the 2004 budget appropriation.
 Mr. Shure said that certainty came with a price, however: bond debt that must be paid off by taxpayers. 
 ''What is ever certain about running a business?'' he asked. ''What about the uncertainty of a senior citizen who may or may not get pharmaceuticals if we let business go to the front of the line?''
 He said it was dangerous for governments to get involved in picking winners and losers in business. And he suggested that the state would provide a better environment for companies if it took its business incentive money and invested in standard government services like education or better transportation systems.
 And as the analysis by New Jersey Policy Perspective pointed out, since 2001 at least eight companies that received grants have laid off a total of 2,794 workers in the state.
 Caren Franzini, chief executive of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, which oversees state business incentive programs, said that companies must say they will have to leave New Jersey if not for the grants, but that inevitably plans change.
 ''We recognize that corporate reorganizations are a business reality,'' Ms. Franzini said. ''The BEIP grants that we award are always estimated amounts based on the facts as we know them at the time of the award.''

Incentives Are Examined
 As a result of the criticism, Mr. McCormac has asked Joseph Seneca, a professor at the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, to examine the program. Mr. Seneca said his report, which is expected to be completed shortly, will take a close look at state borrowing to finance business incentives as well as the level of accountability and public access to information about the grants.
 Over all, he said he thought that the program has been effective because it emphasizes employment, not real estate development or other attraction tools used in some states.
 ''In a world without state government and state boundaries it's probably true, we wouldn't need state business incentives,'' Mr. Seneca said. ''But in the real world, states compete for jobs and economic development, and they've done this since the beginning of the Republic.''
 The real world now extends to Eastern Europe, India, China and other parts of Asia where governments, eager to stimulate economic growth, routinely offer tax holidays, said Kathleen Norat, vice president for economic development at Mintax, the relocation consulting firm.
 ''That's the crux of incentive programs today,'' Ms. Norat said. ''It's no longer just competition among states within the U.S. for jobs.''
 In addition to the new provisions regarding the incentive grants, the state is expected to restore part of a program that allows money-losing companies to sell tax credits to profitable companies that need write-offs against New Jersey taxes, Mr. McCormac said. The program, which appeals to research-based companies in fields like biotechnology , was suspended in 2002. Mr. McCormac has told legislators that with revenue running $692 million ahead of forecasts, the state can afford to restore at least part of the program.
 In the latest budget, the state also made an important change that will help keep companies in New Jersey.
 ''BEIP doesn't help with a company that's looking to move,'' Mr. McCormac said, ''and we're trying to keep them here.''
 The new program grants a credit of up to $1,500 for each employee who remains in the state, up from $400 that was provided in a program that was started in 1997 and expired in 2002. Companies with more than 2,000 workers relocating to a specially designated urban development zone would be eligible for an additional $750 bonus. The new program applies only to companies with 250 or more workers, up from 25 in the old program, and has a cap of $20 million.
 ''The retention program will be critical even as New Jersey is working so hard to attract jobs the other states are working to entice companies in New Jersey to expand in their localities,'' Mr. Schepel said. He added that other states, particularly those from the South, frequently make three-day treks to New York and New Jersey to try to entice companies with incentives and lower costs.
 In addition to the Merck vaccine plant, North Carolina was able to snag an 850-employee Verizon call center with a $10 million grant up front, Mr. McCormac said.
 ''We could not compete with that,'' he said, dismissing that move as a minor setback. ''Individually, nothing is a big blow, but collectively we want to make sure that we're on the right track.'' 
 As states continue to emerge from recession, competition for companies will heat up, said Sujit Canagaretna, a senior fiscal analyst with the Council of State Governments in Atlanta.
 Mr. Canagaretna said that incentives can work for states and companies on the margin, but that in most cases relocation decisions are made on larger economic factors like overall costs or labor availability.
 ''You might have this little song and dance, but by and large it's going to come down to the economics,'' he said.

'Not About to Break the Bank'
 The produce merchants that state officials tried to lure to New Jersey ultimately decided to remain in Philadelphia, but only after the city offered them $150 million in incentives to stay.
 ''We'd like to have had them come, but there are competitive limits,'' Mr. McCormac said. ''We're not about to break the bank just to get a deal.''
 New Jersey now has that much more in its war chest -- and Pennsylvania that much less -- to deploy in the next skirmish over a corporate tenant, said Mr. McCormac, who is keen to land a top corporate tenant to validate Camden's redevelopment. ''If our competition keeps overpaying, then it will be beneficial to us.''
 Dennis Yablonsky, Pennsylvania's commerce secretary, said that in addition to the publicly announced deals, like the produce center and Cigna's flirtation with Camden, New Jersey has put Pennsylvania on the defense with a handful of other companies.
 Still, Mr. Yablonsky said, ''We haven't lost one yet.''

HEADLINE: Of Headers and Hooligans

BYLINE: By Joe Queenan. 
Joe Queenan is the author of ''True Believers: The Tragic Inner Life of Sports Fans.''

 BODY:

HOW SOCCER
EXPLAINS THE WORLD
An Unlikely Theory of Globalization.
By Franklin Foer.
261 pp. HarperCollins Publishers. $24.95.
 In his 1975 book ''The Painted Word,'' Tom Wolfe advanced the theory that Abstract Expressionism and Pop Art were cruel hoaxes foisted on the public by a cabal of Gotham con men. This was basically an indefensible position, but there was no one better equipped to fight such a gallant rear-guard action than the cunning Mr. Wolfe. Ultimately, the author found himself in the enviable position of having published one of the most entertaining books ever written about modern art, even though it was impossible to take the book's premise seriously. 
 Franklin Foer has achieved a similar feat with ''How Soccer Explains the World: An Unlikely Theory of Globalization.'' A dud athlete but an excellent reporter (mostly for The New Republic), Foer believes that soccer can be used to ''explain'' everything from nationalism to hooliganism to hatred of globalization to the nebulous prospect of Islamic democracy to the disintegration of Yugoslavia as a nation. This is a nice hook for a book and a savvy promotional gimmick, but Foer has overplayed his hand here; the fact that soccer can be ''linked'' to so many cultural phenomena does not mean that it ''explains'' them. But Foer's book is such an eccentric, fascinating expose of a world most of us know nothing about that his inability to prove his central thesis seems almost irrelevant. 
 The author certainly did his homework, and on a few occasions even seems to have put his life at risk while interviewing particularly vile soccer fans in Eastern Europe. During a six-month sabbatical from The New Republic, he spent quality time with cretins from Belgrade to Glasgow, traveled to Brazil to find out why no one wants to play there anymore, then spent even more quality time with cretins from London. He also devoted enormous amounts of energy to researching the history of a long-forgotten all-Jewish team from Vienna that briefly ruled the Austrian football cosmos during the 1920's. (The team fell apart after a visit to America; most of the squad took one look at New York City and decided to ditch Mitteleuropa for good.) He even trekked to Ukraine to visit an itinerant Nigerian player who never quite managed to adapt to the mysterious brand of mechanical, mathematically oriented soccer practiced in that unfortunate nation. Finally, Foer returned home to the United States, a land where soccer is generally ridiculed, ignored or played badly. 
 The book starts off like a house on fire, with a harrowing account of the connection between Serbian football hooligans and the massacres that occurred in Croatia and Bosnia in the early 1990's. It then moves on to a treatment of the venomous, idiotic warfare between Roman Catholic and Protestant fans that has been raging in Glasgow for more than a century. Here, Foer makes his most interesting point, that modernization, economic rebirth and a general rise in sophistication have not reduced tribal rivalries in all highly advanced societies, that pointless internecine warfare is almost a hobby for some people. As he writes, ''The city has kept alive its soccer tribalism, despite the logic of history, because it provides the city with a kind of pornographic pleasure.''Or, as he explains it elsewhere, ''Nobody, it seems, hates like a neighbor.''
 Foer also does a nice job explaining why so many American pundits, shock jocks, sportswriters and professional wise-alecks go out of their way to deride a sport whose strange, minimalist beauty escapes them. One reason: soccer aficionados bring it on themselves.
 ''I wish that my side, the yuppie soccer fans, were blameless victims in these culture wars,'' he writes. ''But I've been around enough of America's soccer cognoscenti to know that they invite abuse. They are inveterate snobs, so snobbish, in fact, that they think nothing of turning against their comrades. According to their sneering critique, their fellow fans are dilettantes without any real understanding of the game; they are yuppies who admire soccer like a fine slab of imported goat cheese; they come from neighborhoods with spectacularly high Starbucks-per-capita, so they lack any semblance of burning working-class passion.'' Touche. 
 ''How Soccer Explains the World'' bristles with anecdotes that are almost impossible to believe. Forty-six thousand fans once packed the Polo Grounds to see Hakoah of Vienna, the all-Jewish team, play an exhibition match. A popular Italian television program meticulously reviews controversial penalties, while referees are accused of rigging matches to appease powerful owners. Serbian teams used to throw games rather than risk being shot in the kneecaps by thugs in the employ of a gangster who later resurfaced as a mass murderer during the war in Croatia. And Protestant fans in Glasgow regularly chant vile insults directed at the pope, even though their team includes several Catholic players.
 All this makes for very engaging reading, but it won't get anyone in the United States any more excited about soccer. Since we already have ice hockey, a ferociously repetitive low-scoring game where nothing ever happens, and since hooliganism is not something we need to import to these shores, I suspect most readers will come away from this book relieved that professional soccer, like French pop music, German stand-up comedy and Indian movies, is something profoundly annoying that mercifully stays overseas where it can't do any damage to our fragile republic. Perhaps inadvertently, Foer has written a paean to a sport he loves that will provide even more ammunition to those who loathe it.

HEADLINE: One Cornerstone, but Many Loose Ends

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The language this morning during the cornerstone laying for the Freedom Tower at ground zero will probably be as lofty as the skyscraper itself. 
 But no one gathered around the great granite block -- not the governors, the mayor, the civil servants, the developer, the planners, and certainly not the reporters -- can say for certain how much of the current vision for the new World Trade Center will be realized.
 Guessing the future of long-term megaprojects is a fool's game. Their momentum depends on an alignment of political will, popular support, market demand and economic conditions that shift constantly, beyond the ability of anyone to control or predict. 
 These forces are not now in exact alignment at ground zero, although it is possible -- given the tortuous history of other major development projects in the city, like 42nd Street and Battery Park City -- to marvel at the fact that an official plan has been promulgated so quickly.
 Even more astonishing is the amount of damage caused by the warlike attack of Sept. 11, apart from the loss of 2,749 lives and the twin towers, and the amount of reconstruction that has unfolded in 34 months. This first phase of rebuilding may turn out to have been the easier part.
 Gov. George E. Pataki has gone to great lengths to identify himself personally with the rebuilding of the trade center, while the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has kept itself at some distance. The mayor's office is far more closely identified with an ambitious and controversial plan to redevelop the far West Side as a higher-density commercial, residential and entertainment quarter, an effort that is certain to affect the prospects of Lower Manhattan, despite official demurrers.
 Larry A. Silverstein of Silverstein Properties controls the development rights to all the office buildings on the trade center site. But after losing several rounds in a legal battle with his insurers, he lacks the insurance proceeds to pay for much more than the construction of the Freedom Tower. State officials continue to support him publicly, but are preparing themselves, as one said last May, ''for any eventuality.''
 Question marks hang over nearby properties, too, most notably the damaged and unoccupied Fiterman Hall of the Borough of Manhattan Community College, whose fate is the subject of a stalemate among city and state officials that may be settled soon.
 A resolution could not come soon enough for Antonio Perez, the college president. ''It's so disheartening,'' he said last week. ''I look out my window every day and I see the same building I saw at 6 o'clock on Sept. 11, 2001. All that's missing is the smoke.''

HEADLINE: A Good Deed, and an Eviction Notice

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
DOLORES KAPEN'S suggestion that her roommate inquire about renting the apartment next door seems like proof that no good deed goes unpunished.
 Mrs. Kapen, 84, has lived in her rent-stabilized two-bedroom apartment in a co-op building at 18 West 70th Street since 1969. And since the early 80's, after her children moved out, she has rented that extra room to a series of roommates. 
 Then, in December 2000, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal revised the Rent Stabilization Code, limiting the amount a rent-stabilized tenant can charge a roommate to a proportionate share of the rent. 
 Mrs. Kapen's monthly rent is $806. Under what is called a Senior Citizens Rent Increase Exemption, however, she pays only $585, with her landlord receiving a tax abatement. Mrs. Kapen's monthly income, mostly from Social Security, is $659. The young man renting that bedroom paid her $550 a month.
 But he needed more space. And figuring she would have little difficulty finding a new roommate, Mrs. Kapen told him about the sublet available next door. ''I said, 'Why don't you look into that one?' and I gave him the landlord's number,'' she said. ''The landlord asked, 'How much do you pay Mrs. Kapen?' And he told him.'' 
 In November 2001, the co-op's sponsor, Lepow Associates, began eviction proceedings. ''Our client's contention,'' said Mitchell H. Kossoff, a senior partner at Kossoff Alper & Unger, which represents Lepow Associates, ''is that Mrs. Kapen took advantage of the artificially low rent afforded by rent stabilization by subletting 50 percent or less of her apartment to a series of individuals over a prolonged period at rents which sometimes equaled those sums she was obligated to pay to the landlord.''
 Mrs. Kapen's lawyer, Jacqueline Burger of Legal Services for New York, which represents poor people in civil cases, contended that her client ''was not overcharging because she provided other services.''
 Mrs. Kapen said: ''I paid the whole renter's insurance. I paid to clean the place; the soaps, anything that broke, a bulb. So I wasn't making money.'' 
 Mr. Kossoff countered that such claims are ''fairly commonplace when tenants are tasked with the burden of proving that they are not engaging in impermissible profiteering.''
 The position of the state housing division is that only a roommate can claim an overcharge. But in two court rulings -- Ram 1 v. Mazzola and the BLF Realty Holding Corporation v. Kasher -- landlords have been allowed to seek eviction of tenants for overcharging roommates. In the first case, the roommate paid $2,200 when the rent was $1,847. In the other, a loft tenant was charging three times the $551 rent.
 Courts have since carved out exceptions. In 719 West 180th Street v. Gonzalez, the court ruled that the tenant could charge more than the proportionate share to cover additional services. And in L.E.S.P.M.H.A. Inc. v. Nunez, and 365 West End v. Kristaponis, the courts found that overcharging a roommate is a curable violation, meaning that if the tenant refunds the overcharge the tenant cannot be evicted.
 Even if one assumed that her client was overcharging, Ms. Burger contended: ''The landlord should not be able to evict, because there was no harm to the landlord. The purpose of rent stabilization is to preserve affordable housing. If she's evicted, he will be able to sell this apartment.''
 However, Mr. Kossoff said: ''It's true that if she is ousted the landlord stands to make more money. But I'm not going to apologize for that because renting and selling real estate in New York is a business.'' 
 ''My client is not unmindful that Mrs. Kapen is on in years,'' Mr. Kossoff continued, ''and I don't think this woman has enough to pay the rent herself without engaging in this type of activity. As a result, we offered to relocate her to premises she can afford -- on 88th between Fifth and Madison, not a bad address.''
 Mrs. Kapen turned down the offer. And, after preliminary court proceedings, the parties have resumed negotiations. The young man has since moved out -- not to the apartment next door -- and a new roommate has moved in.
 ''I haven't done anything wrong,'' Mrs. Kapen said. ''My friends are here. This is my home; I want it to be that forever.''
 ''I haven't had a good night's sleep since this started,'' she added. ''My blood pressure went up, so I'm on two pills now instead of just one. I keep thinking and hoping and wondering and wanting it to go away.''

HEADLINE: Sharon Schlesinger, Michael Ravid

 BODY:
Sharon Hope Schlesinger, a daughter of Peppie and Mark Schlesinger of Glen Rock, N.J., is to be married today to Michael Carl Alfred Ravid, the son of Jane and Benjamin Ravid of Newton Centre, Mass. Rabbi David M. Feldman will officiate at the Jewish Center of Teaneck, N.J. Cantor Ira Greenberg will assist. 
 The couple met at Brandeis, from which they graduated, the bridegroom cum laude. The bridegroom also received a master's degree there, in international economics and finance.
 The bride, 23, is a technical assistant in the laboratory of Dr. Susan Lindquist, the director of the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research in Cambridge, Mass. Her father is counsel in the New York office of Jenkens & Gilchrist Parker Chapin, the Dallas-based law firm. Her mother is a social worker in Rochelle Park, N.J., for the Bergen County Board of Social Services. 
 The bridegroom, 25, works as an analyst of bank holding companies in the supervision, regulation and credit department of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. His mother works for Jewish Vocational Service as the administrator of an English as a second language program for employees at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. His father is the Jennie and Mayer Weisman professor of Jewish history at Brandeis.

HEADLINE: Death Toll Rises to Six After Workplace Shooting

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 3 

 BODY:
A sixth man died early Saturday of wounds suffered during a rampage here on Friday at a meatpacking plant, where an employee opened fire with two handguns he had smuggled into work. Police officials identified the victim as Ardell Edwards, 55, a production line worker from Grandview, Mo. 
 The police said they still were not sure about the motive of the gunman, Elijah Brown, 21, who killed himself, except to say that he had acted with apparent deliberation in choosing his victims, some of whom he had just been sitting down with for an employee meeting.
 ''He knew exactly what he was doing,'' Kansas City's police chief, Ronald Miller, said at a news conference outside the ConAgra Foods plant where Mr. Brown and the victims all worked second shift on the manufacturing line, making products like bologna and braunschweiger. 
 Chief Miller said that two other men wounded in the attack were expected to survive, and that the investigation was continuing. 
 ''It's a complex situation,'' he told reporters. Then, in the next breath, Chief Miller seemingly reversed himself. ''It's really a pretty straightforward situation,'' he said.
 Interviews with employees, family members of the victims and people familiar with the stresses, strains and singular workplace quirks of the industrial meat-processing economy here in eastern Kansas said much the same thing: What happened at ConAgra is a shocking mystery -- ultimately unsolvable, perhaps, because Mr. Brown is not alive to answer for his crimes -- but on another level, it hardly seems a mystery at all, after other such recent incidents in the American workplace. 
 One witness said he believed Mr. Brown had had a confrontation of some sort with co-workers earlier this week. Another said he believed Mr. Brown had been teased or taunted. Police investigators and company officials declined to say what the employee meeting had been about that occurred just before Mr. Brown's attack.
 A spokeswoman for ConAgra, Julie DeYoung, said at Saturday's news conference that the company would not comment on its security procedures or how the guns got into the plant, nor would she say whether there were any disciplinary or grievance issues involving Mr. Brown. She said he had been hired last September as a manufacturing line worker, laid off earlier this year because of a production slowdown and rehired six weeks ago.
 The police also were not sure whether it was coincidence or not that three of the dead men were related. Lonnie Ellenberg, 46, and Travis Nelson, 23, both of Kansas City, and Mr. Edwards, the man who died early Saturday, were all part of an extended family, said Col. Sam Breshears, a deputy police chief.
 Colonel Breshears said one of the dead men was a Mexican citizen whose name would not be released until his family could be located. He identified the other victim as Leonardo Rodriquez, 49, also of Kansas City. Two other wounded men are expected to survive, Colonel Breshears said.
 People who work in the meatpacking industry here and in the auxiliary niche businesses that serve the industry, from warehousing to refrigerated shipping, said the environment of a meat factory is probably an important element in explaining what happened at the plant. The work is high-speed and high-pressure, they said, which often means a person cannot spare too much attention noticing whether a co-worker who is acting suspiciously or not. Lose focus, the workers said, and you risk getting behind on the line.
 ''It's a very stressful environment,'' said Eleazar DeLeon, 39, who left meat manufacturing after a few years and now works for a meat shipping and distribution company. Mr. DeLeon works nights at his job and had stopped for breakfast after work at a diner around the corner from the ConAgra plant. ''Any processing plant is repetitive line work,'' he added. ''It's very hard.''
 Employees at ConAgra said the bulky coats that everyone wears, both for warmth in the 40-degree refrigerator chill of the factory and for identification -- production side workers at ConAgra wear blue coats, packaging side workers wear white -- would also make it easy to conceal a weapon once it was on the factory floor. Many people also carry lunch boxes and coolers into the plant that have not routinely been searched in the past, one employee said.
 Edna Perkins is a career meat-processing worker, with 28 years on the line. She was one of the 160 or so people at the plant on Friday, and was also related to Mr. Ellenberg, Mr. Nelson and Mr. Edwards, though she described the men as being from ''another side of the family.''
 Just after 5 p.m., Mrs. Perkins said, she was at her job as usual -- she's a white-coated ''boxer'' on the packaging side, assigned the task of packing prepared meat for shipping -- when she saw people running above her on the catwalk that extends out over the production floor. A few seconds later a man walked by above her, bleeding. 
 ''My first thought was that they'd had a mechanical accident,'' she said. Then everyone started running and next thing she knew she was outside the plant in the parking lot. Interviewed by telephone Saturday morning from her home, Mrs. Perkins said she had been unable to sleep all night.
 On Saturday, the plant was closed, sealed by police barricades on the driveway, and the ConAgra spokeswoman, Ms. DeYoung, said she did not know yet when it would reopen. Counseling sessions were being offered on Saturday for employees.
 The shooting followed by a year and a day an attack in which a manufacturing plant employee in Jefferson City, Mo., killed three people and then himself. 
 Meat industry work has deep roots in Kansas City, where a nexus of railroads and ranching combined to build a culture of stockyards and packing plants beginning in the late 1800's.
 The industry has declined significantly over the last 50 years, but remains alive in the neighborhoods like Amourdale, named for the meat company, and in factories like ConAgra. In recent years, workers here say, the plants have also increasingly become the province of immigrants from Mexico and other Latin American countries. 
 Even on Saturday as the ConAgra plant sat silent and employees mourned, the city's culture of heavy trucking, rail and agriculture continued. As Chief Miller and other officials spoke at the news conference, reporters repeatedly had to lean in to hear, the speakers forced to shout, as another tractor-trailer rumbled by the factory door.
