HEADLINE: First, Get a Green Card. Next, Hire a Publicist.

BYLINE: By Gary Shteyngart. 
Gary Shteyngart is the author of ''The Russian Debutante's Handbook,'' a novel.

 BODY:
Lately I haven't been a good immigrant. I can't get myself to work an 80-hour week. I won't walk 20 blocks to save a subway fare. And I don't have that crazed, adrenaline-driven certainty that life will soon get better for me or mine. Maybe it's the gloomy times we live in. Maybe it's the economy. Maybe it's the war. But most likely it's that I'm sated -- the young immigrant's hunger and worries are gone. I'm not fat and doughy just yet, but my midriff looks, to quote an old friend, ''prosperous.''
 Want and fear drive America: the want of security, dignity and wild affluence, the fear of coming up short on all counts, the fear of extinction in an unforgiving market economy that rewards only the tireless and the unblinking. ''Remember the lesson of the . . . dodo bird,'' Monette Adeva Maglaya cautions the newcomer in her remarkable new book, THE COMPLETE SUCCESS GUIDE FOR THE IMMIGRANT LIFE: How to Survive, How to Thrive, How to Be Fully Alive (PDI Books, paper, $19.95). ''One must learn to adapt or else, perish.'' 
 I say Maglaya's book is ''remarkable'' not because it is a compendium of bizarre clip art, well-worn inspirational cliches, practical advice and religious hoo-ha, all of which it is, but because few books have come closer to telling me what it means to be an immigrant in America today. And if Maglaya is to be believed, it means living in a land of turbo-Darwinism that would shock the likes of Huck Finn and Augie March, a landscape of hucksters and dreamers, of work-at-home schemes, fake children's modeling contests and rampant identity fraud. It means, for the most part, living in Southern California amid tribes of Cambodian doughnut tycoons and Chinese laundry empires. It means believing in God (and preferably Jesus Christ), and making him (them) a part of everything you do. Religious, resourceful, highly flexible and yet essentially conservative, the immigrant is the most reliably American of all Americans, the indispensable citizen, the bedrock of the American dream with all its tainted pleasures and millennial lunacies.
 That said, the face of immigration, or at least the face of immigration guidebooks, is unrecognizable to me today. When my family came to the United States from the Soviet Union around 1980, we were given a slim instructional volume from a resettlement agency. Aimed squarely at the Soviet immigrant, the book stressed the prodigious use of deodorant and the need to grin painfully whenever an American was present (''smell-'n'-smile'' is how I committed this advice to memory). 
 As far as Maglaya is concerned, the modern superimmigrant has no need for such obvious instruction. Instead, he should gain quick proficiency with MapQuest and Google. Once these are mastered there are ''very strong arguments'' in favor of learning English, ''apart from the usual benefit of being able to read road signs.'' With English and the yield sign under his belt, the immigrant faces the quandary of finding a good house servant. Watch out, Maglaya warns, for they don't come cheap in this country. Immigrants who have had ''domestic help to do things for them'' will be ''in for a shock.'' Now that the tempest-tossed refugee has secured the services of a reputable manservant, it is time to find a suitable activity to occupy his time. ''Should he go into business? Should he pursue the arts?'' These are all difficult decisions to make for someone who has just sneaked across the Rio Grande, but if one finally settles on entrepreneurship it is often helpful to ''get a professional spokesperson or a mascot.'' You know, to help out with publicity.
 The author, who came to the United States in the 1980's from the Philippines with a master's degree in communications, leaves us with a list of recommended books, including Pat Buchanan's ''Death of the West: How Dying Populations and Immigrant Invasions Imperil Our Country and Civilization'' and other examples of ''the boat is full'' philosophy. Maglaya's assessment of the way immigrant groups perceive and treat other immigrant groups is yet another remarkable aspect of this book. We learn, for example, that ''Jews and Armenians have long histories of being involved in business in every area around the world where they settle,'' while Koreans have ''a somewhat hardy resistance to acculturation.'' Mexicans, despite being abundant in the author's adopted Southern California, are suspiciously absent from the list of enterprising immigrant groups. Possibly they have little of value to impart to Maglaya's ''bright, bushy-tailed eager beaver of a newcomer.'' The world rightfully looks to America as the nation most welcoming to immigrants -- and yet what many highly educated immigrants do not know, or do not care to know, about one another's struggles could fill a book. This one, for instance.
 But I couldn't help learning from Maglaya. She has compiled so many facts about living in America that by the end of this book I felt genuinely indebted to her. Were you aware, just for example, that disreputable modeling schools are a big draw because ''one of the hot buttons among immigrant parents is their dreams of success for their children''? Or that the policy of the United States is not to admit ''terrorists, Nazis and people likely to become dependent on welfare,'' possibly in that order? Or that you can stop credit bureaus from selling your name by calling 1-888-5OPT-OUT? Or that ''when pumping gas,'' you should ''prefer to do it yourself . . . rather than give your card to the attendant,'' who can ''steal your number at random''? 
 After learning the difference between Chapter 7 and Chapter 13 bankruptcy and the importance of stuffing every piece of financial mail into a good paper shredder, I felt more ready than ever to participate in our nation's rich economic life. Also, I felt scared -- scared like an immigrant; scared that in this capricious land everything I have worked for could be taken away with the click of a computer mouse or by my enrollment in the wrong modeling school. 
 Between meditations on immigrant fear and immigrant striving, the author keeps our spirits up with inspirational quotations from the likes of Shakespeare (''Rest, rest, perturbed spirit'') and Jenny Craig (''Self-love is the only weight-loss aid that really works in the long run''). There are also some exquisitely strange, naive, almost moving, illustrations -- including a homemade collage of Jesus floating above the earth. For Maglaya, being an immigrant means finding solace in religion. There are few paragraphs devoted to an immigrant's natural propensity toward ''homesickness, loneliness and despair,'' the debilitating feelings that crushed many members of my parents' immigrant generation, but lots of talk about craning one's neck toward Eternity. ''Look heavenward,'' the author instructs us. ''Put God first in your life and everything falls into place.'' ''Coming to America may have been part of God's Grand Design in order for you'' to fulfill your purpose. And for the harried, multitasking immigrant, this advice: ''Jesus Christ was stressed too.'' 
 Along with the Father and the Son, there is a worship of Country. At a time when most of the world is learning to despise us, the immigrant's faith in America's promise remains staggering and, to many, inspiring. Why else would millions of people regularly give up their mother tongue, their childhood friends, their elderly parents, their native hills and mesas and, of course, their cooks, chauffeurs and houseboys to come here? Maglaya puts it all into perspective: ''Barring unforeseen catastrophic circumstances induced by humans and extremely rare cosmic collisions like a comet or asteroid scoring a direct fatal hit on earth . . . America will continue to hold a prime position in world geopolitics for some time.'' 
 I don't know if she's right on that one. But I am going to get that paper shredder.

HEADLINE: In a Galaxy of Hotel Ratings, Are 5 Stars Enough?

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
AT the Burj Al Arab hotel, housed in a glass skyscraper molded like a billowing sail that soars over the Persian Gulf in Dubai, the cheapest room goes for $666 a night, and a standard two-bedroom suite costs $2,231. It is beyond dispute that this ranks among the world's great hotels.
 But is the Burj Al Arab merely in the upper tier of ''five star'' hotels -- a designation that has long been the standard for the world's best? No: according to the hotel and many travel writers, it is the world's first seven-star hotel.
 It is not alone in leaping into new galaxies of self-definition. As other lodging companies rush to establish their highest-level brands in cities and resort areas the world over, scores of luxury hotels now claim six-star status. 
 What is going on here? Has grade inflation come to hotel rating scales? 
 Well, yes -- but for good reason, argues David Beer, a founder of Brennan Beer Gorman Architects, a company that has designed top luxury hotels, including the Peninsula in Bangkok. There has been so much expansion and improvement in the five-star category in the last decade, he said, that there is a need to add an extra star to describe the creme de la creme. (Mr. Beer has a list of 11 hotels worldwide that he says meet this standard, and the Burj Al Arab is not on it.)
 ''At hotels in this country and around the world, a five-star rating may encompass anything from a very nice Sofitel or a very good Westin to the Mandarin Oriental in Hong Kong or the Gritti Palace in Venice, and they really aren't the same,'' he said, citing two hotels he believes deserve six-star status.
 Which brings up the question: Who, exactly, doles out these stars? Whether used to describe a basic motel beside a highway or a luxurious resort, the rankings confuse many travelers. That is mostly because there are no clear standards, and there is no definitive source.
 The Mobil and AAA travel guides, and the Michelin Red Guides in Europe, are well respected, though they do have detractors. But beyond those lies a vast gray area, where -- especially in Europe -- the use of stars can be so indiscriminate as to be nearly meaningless. 
 The best advice for travelers is to treat all ratings with skepticism and to check for the specific amenities a hotel offers. And remember that high price does not automatically mean high quality. 
 So what might six stars mean, if the universe can stretch that far? In Mr. Beer's estimation, the designation should go to hotels that maintain ''champion status,'' with exquisite personal service, unparalleled location and genteel exclusivity. Knocking elbows with fashionable locals in a flashy lobby bar is not something one does at a six-star hotel, he said. Though price is not the defining factor, he added, ''these are hotels that are basically for the guests who are paying $700 or $800 a night, which is a lot different from luxury five-star hotels with lots of shops in the lobby and outsiders coming in and weddings being held on the staircase.''
 SOME traditional luxury hoteliers resist ratings supersizing. 
 ''I wouldn't use the term 'six-star hotel' myself,'' said Ricci Obertelli, the global development director of the Dorchester Hotel Group, whose luxury properties include the Dorchester in London, the Beverly Hills Hotel in California and the Hotel Meurice in Paris.
 But Mr. Obertelli knows a six-star hotel when he sees one. ''For example, if you were a wealthy entertainer and you came to the Dorchester in London,'' he said, ''and let's say you just finished your show and you wanted to have a five-course meal at two in the morning, you'd expect a chef to be there to prepare it. And that expectation would be met.'' 
 The global hotel industry is dominated by about 10 international chains, most of which have developed brands that fit into four or five categories, roughly corresponding to star ratings. A typical one-star chain is Motel 6, owned by Accor Hotels, which also has the five-star Sofitel brand. A big player in the crowded three-star niche is Courtyard by Marriott, from Marriott International, which also owns the five-star Ritz-Carlton chain.
 Because corporate travel reimbursement policies often spell out the price level and even the hotel brands an employee may use, many frequent business travelers can readily rank domestic hotels on the five-tiered scale. But some ranking systems claim to be far more discriminating. 
 The two major ones in the United States are the Mobil Travel Guides, which award stars, and the AAA travel guides, which award diamonds. Ratings in these guides, which promote themselves largely to leisure travelers, are based on evaluations by teams of inspectors who are armed with detailed checklists when they visit hotels. 
 To earn three stars from a Mobil inspector, for example, a hotel needs to pass muster on a long list of requirements -- from ''complete room service'' and two phones to ''framed artwork or interesting architectural features in room.''
 In its ratings for 2004, Mobil gives five stars to only 30 of the estimated 50,000 hotels in the United States. AAA awards five diamonds to only 68 hotels domestically. 
 Both Mobil and AAA say their strict grading is in stark contrast to what Mobil calls the ''wildly fluctuating'' and ''suspect'' galaxies of stars awarded elsewhere, especially on Internet travel sites that rank hotels while at the same time selling their rooms.
 Peter Greenberg, the author of ''Hotel Secrets From the Travel Detective'' (Villard), recommends taking all guides with a grain of salt. ''They're guidebooks, not bibles,'' said Mr. Greenberg, who is the travel editor for ''Today'' on NBC. For hoteliers, he said, they are important ''partly because getting a good rating allows them to justify a higher rate.'' 
 ''It's sort of like the Academy Awards,'' he added. ''When you get the Oscar, your rate just went up.'' 
 Travelers abroad, especially in Europe, are also often confused by hotel ratings. In some countries, hotels are given star ratings by government-affiliated tourist agencies, which rely mostly on simple evaluation of physical property -- is the bathroom in the room or down the hall? -- and room rates. ''The assessment is based exclusively on objective criteria. Individual evaluations are emotional and subjective,'' the German Hotel and Restaurant Association acknowledges on its Web site. 
 MR. GREENBERG said that ''overseas, a star rating can represent a government designation that signifies, for tax reasons, what a hotel is charging.''
 ''A five-star hotel can simply mean you're staying in the most expensive hotel in town,'' he added. ''It doesn't necessarily mean you're staying at a great hotel.''
 Of course, a well-informed travel agent with many industry sources and lots of personal experience can provide good hotel evaluations. 
 Yet even top travel agents say they are sometimes bewildered by the stars. ''Really, you have to know the hotel, because the ratings systems are really all over the lot,'' said Blake Fleetwood, president of Planetarium Travels in New York. 
 He did offer a general rule of thumb about the relationship between price and rating at the highest levels: ''It's about $100 a star,'' he said.

Starstruck
Assigning hotel star ratings can be highly subjective. But some travel professionals agree on certain criteria, and on some types of chain hotels that generally fall into each tier.

*****
[Rating: 5 Stars]
Elegant decor and amenities, with an emphasis on personal service. Rooms usually have luxurious bathrooms. Other offerings include spacious fitness centers, spas, business centers and, generally, a highly regarded restaurant on site. Top urban or resort locations. Concierge and 24-hour room service.
Examples: Ritz-Carlton, Four Seasons, Peninsula, Westin, Sofitel.

****
[Rating: 4 Stars]
Dependably high-quality hotels that can often handle conventions, meetings and special events. Prime locations. Good restaurants and shops. Concierge and room service, often 24 hours. Fitness and business centers.
Hilton, Radisson, Hyatt, Wyndham, Sheraton, Marriott Hotels.

***
[Rating: 3 Stars]
May or may not include restaurants and room service. Comfortable, convenient rooms, usually with ample space for work. Usually near highways.
Courtyard by Marriott, Hampton, Holiday Inn, Hilton Garden.

**
[Rating: 2 Stars]
Basic but consistent comfort and value, usually without food service and almost always near highways and chain restaurants.
Days Inn, Travelodge.

*
[Rating: 1 Star]
Simple, clean, convenient to highways.
Motel 6, Econolodge.

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; ART; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 1791 words

HEADLINE: A Picture Is Worth 216 Newspaper Articles

 BODY:
IN 1988, Gerhard Richter created one of the most riveting works of modern political art with a series of paintings about the German terrorist group known as the Baader-Meinhof gang. The paintings were blurry deadpan adaptations of black-and-white snapshots, whose ambiguities fueled the ongoing debates about the nation's history and ambitions. Now Mr. Richter, 72 and perhaps the most influential painter in the world, has returned to a political theme with ''War Cut.'' Typically indirect and multilayered, it takes the form of an illustrated book. 
 The topic is the war in Iraq. Again, ambiguity is a theme, but unlike his earlier political work, the result is colorful and abstract. The book consists of collages: 216 photographic details of Mr. Richter's 1987 painting ''No. 648-2,'' accompanied by an equal number of newspaper articles from The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung on March 20 and 21, 2003, the beginning days of the war. The result links two normally unrelated mediums, creating a hybrid commentary that can be seen as a kind of absurd historical novel. 
 ''War Cut'' was published by Verlag der Buchhandlung Walther Konig. The following interview was done in German in April at Mr. Richter's Cologne studio by Jan Thorn-Prikker, a freelance critic and the editor of Kulturjournal, a cultural magazine of the Goethe Institute in Munich. The translation is by Tim Nevill.

JAN THORN-PRIKKER -- Can you say something about the abstract painting that served as a starting point for ''War Cut''?

GERHARD RICHTER -- That picture was done long ago, in the 1980's, so the Iraq War wasn't involved. I was slightly surprised when the Musee d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris bought the picture; there are more attractive works, not so rough and harsh. But about two years ago I took close-ups of the work in the museum without knowing what I might use them for. When the war started, I heard all these conflicting opinions. I thought newspaper reports were salutary -- impotent and ineffectual as everything else in the face of catastrophe -- but their plain presentation of the facts consoled me.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Do you include all the articles published about the Iraq War in the paper on those first two days, or did you leave out some?

RICHTER -- I left out some. My layout determined what I included or didn't include. It was not something I had specifically in mind before I started. I wanted to vary the layout, to move from empty to full and back again. I had a general plan, a sense of balance. But the specific arrangement evolved as I worked on it, until at some stage there were 324 pages. I read most of the texts only after I placed them with the pictures. I read them as literature, which was very pleasing. I was not looking for straightforward narrative, which is maybe also why I chose that particular abstract painting. Some of my other abstract pictures are less ambiguous. Their atmosphere is either very agitated or tranquil or almost storylike in their narrative flow, so that they seem nearly representational or surreal. This picture had none of that. It was close to being uncommunicative, which I don't mean negatively.

THORN-PRIKKER -- The Iraq war was a television war. Why did you reject using those images?

RICHTER -- ''War Cut'' only very indirectly involves reality. Even the facts in the newspaper articles somehow become unrealistic in this context. I removed the headlines and bylines from the articles. I respect the writers. But I like to think that maybe by removing the headlines I contributed toward having these texts read as literature. It would be like taking a newspaper photo and putting it in a museum as an oil painting, which is I suppose what I did with Baader-Meinhof.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Then would you say that ''War Cut'' was also a kind of plea: ''Look closely at these texts; they talk about your world''?

RICHTER -- Yes, but also I mean that the texts now survive longer than the single day when they were in the newspaper.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Why did you use The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung?

RICHTER -- Because I have been reading it for 40 years.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Why March 20 and 21, 2003?

RICHTER -- The outbreak of war is the date that people remember. Just like the start of Hitler's war on Sept. 1, 1939. On the other hand, it seems to me that March 20-21 didn't have an impact comparable to, say, Sept. 11, 2001.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Did you order the texts chronologically?

RICHTER -- No, only approximately. After all, I had this strict framework where every page had fixed arrangements and magnitudes. But that still left sufficient latitude for preferences and specific confrontations with images, and for a certain breadth of themes. The real gift for me was the fact that chance could bring about wonderful combinations.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Could you say something about the unusual form of ''War Cut?''

RICHTER -- My approach to form is very simple. Whatever is real is so unlimited and unshaped that we have to summarize it. The more dramatic events are, the more important the form. That is why people marry in a church and why we need a priest for a funeral.

THORN-PRIKKER -- With ''War Cut,'' did you give these dramatic events form by putting them between book covers?

RICHTER -- The book covers and the way the material between them is treated. And the way texts and images influence one another, change their meanings, with the images changing incomparably more because they are much more open and ambiguous.

THORN-PRIKKER -- But the images and texts are placed alongside one another almost blindly.You have great trust in the chance occurrences involved in such form.

RICHTER -- Form is all we have to help us cope with fundamentally chaotic facts and assaults. Formulating something is a great start. I trust form, trust my feeling or capacity to find the right form for something. Even if that is only by being well organized. That too is form.
 As for chance, consider John Cage. His musical compositions were never a total appropriation of a chance acoustic event. He devised an ingenious system to build structures from dumb abundance. And he devoted even more skill to giving form to this succession of sounds. That is the absolute opposite of chance, nature and rubbish. 

THORN-PRIKKER -- When people hear you say that form is the most important aspect, that could easily be understood as meaning that you are unconcerned about the politics or the human cost of the war.

RICHTER -- No, no. In this case the facts are so overpowering, the contents so crucial, the form is also all the more significant. We need it simply to be able to deal with the subject matter.

THORN-PRIKKER -- How did you decide how to arrange the texts with the photographs?

RICHTER -- My method was to attach a number of texts to a number of images without having to think about whether something would be better positioned to the left or the right, above or below. Or whether a specific image fit together with a particular text or not. Most did fit together, and only a few inappropriate or banal conjunctions had to be changed. The images are always arranged in accordance with -- what shall I call it: aesthetic criteria? I placed these images so that a connection develops in terms of colors, structures and other characteristics. It all starts somewhat casually. It was like putting together a story or a film, which begins somehow or other, has tranquil and wild, nasty and fantastic passages, and then once again fades away, ending in white. A dream.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Once you put a text alongside an image, both lose their independence. It immediately establishes a relationship.

RICHTER -- Some images match the cruelty and the madness described in the texts shockingly well. And others can even serve as illustrations when the texts speaks of deserts and other landscapes.

THORN-PRIKKER -- ''War Cut'' seems to show aerial photographs. Oil fields on fire. Pools of oil, blood -- things that in reality aren't depicted. Sometimes ghosts, death heads, hideous faces emerge from the images.

RICHTER -- I have nothing against that.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Your book is contradictory. As an artist's work it says, ''That's how things are. That's how the world looks.'' However the same book simultaneously says, ''That's unacceptable. Things can't continue like this.'' The book both raises a protest against the world as it is and confirms that state of affairs.

RICHTER -- Yes, that is also why I wanted to try and see this war from a completely different angle. Admonitions, protests and such are not my thing.

THORN-PRIKKER -- To what extent is ''War Cut'' an attempt at coming to grips with a war? I've met a few people who reacted to ''War Cut'' with something close to annoyance. They say that you take everything and simply throw it together -- that this is merely a simulation of sympathetic interest. They say that you could just as easily have made a collage with anything.

RICHTER -- Of course that isn't the case. Anyway, it's not possible. How could one be in this world without feeling dismayed by it? Even if one paints flowers and gingerbread.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Do you think your book involves a sense of mourning?

RICHTER -- Yes, and rage, too. Mainly rage because war is upsetting, because it demonstrates our impotence, because obviously we can't prevent it, because we cannot assess it anywhere near adequately. That becomes apparent in the many different judgments, prejudices and simplifications we hear and read. That is also why I absolutely avoided expressing an opinion, which is completely useless here and obstructs the attempt to come somewhat closer to the truth. In addition, my opinion is certainly just as wrong as that of my friends who almost all greatly simplify matters, condemning the war and grumbling about Bush in a way that is close to kitsch. That is not my way.
 I certainly don't think the war is unnecessary. Otherwise it wouldn't happen. And we are certainly far from being able to do without wars. But I did not have so much cause to mourn. Sept. 11 horrified me to a greater extent.

THORN-PRIKKER -- Does the fact that you belong to the generation that experienced World War II influence your feelings about war?

RICHTER -- Yes. Those experiences are present, like an underlying theme.

THORN-PRIKKER -- But you keep the wound fresh. Whether you mean it that way or not, that is a way of expressing sympathy.

RICHTER -- Yes, it is. But the greatest pleasure was to complete this book. Then it was fun to have produced something beautiful. I found my way back to painting. That was a new beginning after a long intermission. After all, I hadn't painted for two years. It was good to produce something like this. Something storylike, something fantastic. The absolute opposite of war.

HEADLINE: Three Big Winners in a So-So Quarter

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
MOST mutual funds eked out very small gains in the second quarter, but it wasn't easy. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose only 1.3 percent for the quarter, and domestic stock funds, for the most part, couldn't even manage that performance. Still, there were some standouts. 
 Managers of three strong performers among no-load funds, those that do not have sales charges, talked about their portfolios and their thoughts about the market for the rest of the year.
 The $101 million UMB Scout Small Cap fund returned 10.3 percent for the quarter. David R. Bagby, 54, the manager, said he aimed to buy ''very well-financed small companies that produced significant amounts of excess cash flow.''
 ''Ideally,'' he added, ''they are eventually acquired by bigger companies in their industry.''
 Indeed, all three of the fund's top-performing stocks were from companies involved in acquisitions during the second quarter. Tom Brown Inc., a natural-gas exploration and production company in Denver, was acquired in May by the EnCana Corporation, an energy company based in Calgary, Alberta, that holds natural-gas reserves in the Rocky Mountains. ''With market prices markedly higher, they saw this as a good opportunity,'' Mr. Bagby said. Shares of Tom Brown rose 27.6 percent from March 31 through May 21, when trading stopped. 
 Another holding, Isco Inc., a maker of water-testing instruments that is based in Lincoln, Neb., was acquired in June by Teledyne Technologies, the electronics and aerospace company based in Los Angeles, for $16 a share in cash. Isco shares rose 32.5 percent in the quarter until they stopped trading on June 16. ''Eight or nine companies were interested in acquiring Isco,'' Mr. Bagby said. ''Teledyne was a surprise because it's a little out of its industry.'' 
 In June, GE Energy, a supplier of power generation and energy delivery technology, based in Atlanta, signed a definitive agreement to acquire BHA Group Holdings, a company in Kansas City, Mo., that provides air-quality control products and services, for $38 a share. The transaction is expected to close in the late summer. ''GE makes turbines that produce electrical power, and this company makes the filters that are used in the turbines,'' Mr. Bagby said. ''I thought it was a perfect fit.'' Shares of BHA rose 26.2 percent in the quarter.
 Looking ahead, Mr. Bagby is optimistic about the market. ''Stocks tend to perform strongly during election years,'' he said. 

Less Tech, More Health Care
 Philip C. Fine, 54, the lead manager of the $57 million Loomis Sayles Aggressive Growth fund, calls himself a ''bottom-up stock picker'' who aims to buy rapidly growing companies. The fund returned 7.21 percent in the quarter. 
 In the last six months, Mr. Fine said, he has reduced the fund's stake in technology companies to 23 percent of assets from more than 35 percent. He used the money to raise the stake in health care companies to nearly 30 percent of the portfolio, up from the midteens. In particular, he saw opportunities in the biotechnology industry.
 One winner was OSI Pharmaceuticals in Melville, N.Y. The company announced good results in its long-term clinical trials of its cancer drug, Tarceva, which is being developed in a global alliance of OSI, Genentech and Roche. The stock rose 83.4 percent in the quarter.
 Another pharmaceutical company, ImClone Systems, rose 69 percent. It began marketing its new drug, Erbitux, which was approved by the Food and Drug Administration earlier this year. Sales of Erbitux, which is used to treat colorectal cancer, were ''stronger than expected,'' Mr. Fine said.
 Over all, the fund's technology stocks made money in the quarter. One big winner, up 46.7 percent, was Research in Motion, based in Waterloo, Ontario. The company develops and markets products for the mobile communications market, including the BlackBerry hand-held device. ''It's selling like hot cakes,'' Mr. Fine said of the BlackBerry, ''and demand is exceeding supply.'' 
 He also expects a strong market during the rest of 2004 because of the election, but he is less optimistic about 2005. ''I think we'll have decelerating earnings and rising interest rates,'' he said, ''and that's a tough combination.''

A Value Formula
 The $83 million ICON Materials fund was up 6.35 percent for the quarter. Its manager, Derek N. Rollingson, 32, uses what he calls a ''modified Benjamin Graham model to calculate the intrinsic value of each company'' in the 15 industries in the materials sector. Mr. Graham and David Dodd wrote ''Security Analysis,'' the 1934 classic text for value investors.
 Unlike traditional value investors, Mr. Rollingson does not focus on companies with low price-to-earnings or price-to-book multiples. 
 To pick industries in which to concentrate, he uses a valuation system, based on Mr. Graham's equation, taking into account historical earnings, projected five-year earnings, stock price volatility and bond yields. The model, run daily, creates a per-share intrinsic value for every company in each industry. 
 Right now, Mr. Rollingson sees significant value in the industries for commodity chemicals, steel, and metal and glass containers. One of the fund's winners was the Methanex Corporation, in Vancouver, British Columbia, which makes and markets methanol, a liquid commodity chemical. Its shares rose 18.4 percent in the quarter.
 The fund also made money in Owens-Illinois, in Toledo, Ohio, the maker of packaging products and glass containers. The company's shares rose 19.5 percent in the quarter.
 Another winner was Steel Dynamics Inc., based in Fort Wayne, Ind. Its shares rose 15.5 percent. ''Global demand for steel is rising,'' Mr. Rollingson said, ''and demand is particularly strong in China.''
 He says he is optimistic about the stock market, saying it is still 10 percent undervalued.
 ''We're in a good environment,'' he said, ''where we can have good G.D.P. growth with the threat of inflation stemmed by offsetting increases in productivity.''


Big Fish Eating Small Fish

HEADLINE: The Broadway Producer Baby

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
ARIELLE TEPPER, a buoyant young theater producer, has an office in the Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway in Times Square. She's not alone: the building has long been known as theater central, a hive of suites where ideas are hatched, partnerships forged, contracts signed, legends born. In 1991, just after her freshman year at Syracuse University, she was working as a summer intern for the Off Broadway producer Eric Krebs, who sent her, on her first day, to deliver a package to 1501. 
 ''It was when Times Square was still pretty scary,'' she said a month ago in her cluttered office, where she works with a staff of four. ''But when I got to 1501, I saw this beautiful gold entrance in the middle of this crummy, crummy area, and I walk inside and see all the marble and these old elevators. I mean, it's just the coolest building ever. And I look at the names on the directory and I think, 'Oh, my God, everybody is here, this is really, really cool!' And I go home that night and my father says, 'How was your first day?' I said, 'Dad, it was like the coolest thing, I was a messenger.' And he's thinking, like, 'Great, you were a messenger.' And I said: 'No, but I went to this building, 1501 Broadway, and it was so cool. Everyone's there.' And he starts laughing. And I said, 'I don't know why you're making fun of me.' And he said: 'No, no, no, Ari. You own 1501 Broadway.' ''
 Thirteen years later, Ms. Tepper is still armed with the romantic notions of a stage-door Annie, the energy of youth and, not incidentally, a considerable fortune derived from the real estate empire of her maternal grandfather, Philip Levin, who died in 1971, the year before Ms. Tepper was born. In 2001, Ms. Tepper inherited a third of the family real estate portfolio, which Crain's New York recently estimated at $1 billion. Ms. Tepper has used part of her share to make herself into an eager new player in the treacherous world of theatrical producing.
 For instance, a month ago, Ms. Tepper was just back from a weekend in Reykjavik. She had gone to see an acrobatic rendition of ''Romeo and Juliet'' by a young Icelandic company, Vesturport, and she had returned more effervescent, if that's possible, than usual. The weekend, she said, using one of her favorite superlatives yet again, was ''the coolest thing ever.''
 In fact, Ms. Tepper, who is 31 and whose Valley girl lingo and cheerleader spirit make her seem even younger, liked what she saw so much that she has decided to transfer the Reykjavik ''R&J'' to Off Broadway. With its gymnastic staging and rock 'n' roll aesthetic, it could, she hopes, inherit the audiences at the Daryl Roth theater off Union Square, where the chaotic novelty show she had a hand in producing, ''De La Guarda,'' will close in September after more than six years.
 She also had meetings later that week to discuss advertising and marketing of the Broadway revivals of ''Jumpers'' and ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' two plays whose current incarnations she (along with many other contributors) helped finance. (Both productions are closing next Sunday, ''Jumpers'' prematurely, at a loss, and ''Raisin'' having recouped its costs.)
 None of this, however, was at the center of Ms. Tepper's attention. Rather, she was consumed by frantic preparations for the Summer Play Festival, a showcase for 18 previously unstaged shows -- 16 plays and two musicals -- that opens tomorrow and runs through Aug. 1 at the five-theater complex at Theater Row Theaters on West 42nd Street. Ms. Tepper is producing and financing it herself at a cost of $1 million.
 Though a commercial venture, it's an unusual enterprise, an almost philanthropic gesture that only a do-gooder rich kid could even attempt. It also represents Ms. Tepper's biggest investment in the theater thus far, not only financially but also in terms of control; her previous projects have largely been in partnership with other, more experienced hands.
 But perhaps most significant for her, the festival is an emotional investment as well; Ms. Tepper had something of the sort in mind for years as a tribute to her mother, Susan, who died of cancer in 1991. Her mother, she said, was a painter who believed that young artists need and deserve the nourishment that the affluent can provide. Ms. Tepper said she hoped she had a long life of philanthropy ahead of her, but now she was spending her energy and money on the theater -- ''instead of, like, curing cancer'' -- because of the four years she watched her mother living with a death sentence. ''She knew she was going to die, and it was four years of trying to live happily when you knew it was coming to an end. She lived her life doing everything she wanted to do, and her big thing was helping younger artists. Theater is what I love. It's made me very happy in my life.''
 Unlike other festivals in New York this summer -- for example, the Midtown International Theater Festival this month and the New York International Fringe Festival in August -- which choose the productions, Ms. Tepper's festival is creating them. Each play has been allotted a budget of $10,000 and each musical $15,000, money for actors and scenery. The writers, for the most part, chose their own directors, but on that Monday afternoon a month ago, Ms. Tepper and her associate producer, Rachel Neuberger, were interviewing volunteer producers -- mostly young people who work in the offices of Broadway producers and want the experience -- to oversee the individual plays.
 The plays were selected from about 1,000 submissions, Ms. Tepper said, the 50 finalists narrowed down by a panel that included the librettist John Weidman and the directors Harold Prince and Mr. Prince's daughter, Daisy, all of whom Ms. Tepper has worked with as a producer and investor.
 The writers range in age from early 20's to mid-40's and they aren't exactly novices. Some, like Anne Garcia-Romero, whose play ''Earthquake Chica'' will be presented at the festival; Kelly Stuart, whose new play is called ''Mayhem''; and Octavio Solis (''El Paso Blue'') have had productions and commissions at regional theaters throughout the country. Elise Thoron, who wrote the book for one of the two musicals, ''Prozak & the Platypus'' (the music is by Jill Sobule, the singer and composer of the pop hits ''I Kissed a Girl'' and ''Supermodel''), is also the author of the 2001 musical play ''Charlotte: Life? Or Theater?,'' about the artist Charlotte Salomon, who died in Auschwitz. John Bucchino, whose revue, ''It's Only Life,'' is the other festival musical, was a contributor to ''3hree,'' the trio of mini-musicals directed by Mr. Prince at the Prince Music Theater in Philadelphia in 2000. Ten of the festival writers are members of the collective New Dramatists that offers grants and workspace to playwrights, and several teach at universities. (A list and synopsis of the plays is on the festival Web site, www.spfnyc.com.)
 Though Ms. Tepper acknowledges that, until last week when she began advertising, advance sales were slow, she is counting on word of mouth and television advertising -- WNBC television, as one of the sponsors, is providing air time -- to draw walk-up buyers for the single-price $10 tickets. Other corporate sponsors are Smart Car and Millennium Hotels. Ms. Tepper is gambling that the festival will garner enough attention this summer that corporations will be interested in covering its costs in the future. She is not taking a right of first refusal -- or any other rights -- to the plays; if she did, she said, why would other producers come to see them?
 ''Here's the deal,'' Ms. Tepper said a month ago. ''I'll pay for it this year. I never want to pay for it again. This year I don't want money. My goal is that these writers have a future.'' Last week, she amended that; she'll pay for it again if she has to.
 Ms. Tepper has been working in the theater since the summer she discovered 1501 Broadway, and even those who consider her a spoiled rich girl concede she has been paying her dues. In fact, she is the youngest and probably the perkiest example of an increasingly dominant species of theatrical life: the producer-slash-angel investor, a category that includes Chase Mishkin (''Dirty Blonde,'' ''Match,'' ''Urban Cowboy,'' ''Prymate'') and Daryl Roth (''The Goat,'' ''Anna in the Tropics,'' ''Bea Arthur on Broadway''), among many others. The theater has always relied, to some extent, on wealthy individuals willing to risk small fortunes on precarious theatrical projects. But in the past these investors tended to be content as near-silent partners, with limited influence on the creative development of the show.
 Producers were a separate category: they took responsibility for the creative and business aspects of a production, but they were not necessarily wealthy themselves. (Hence Max Bialystock's famous two producing tenets: never put your own money in a show and never put your own money in a show.)
 But today the two categories are merging. ''It used to be there were producers and there were angels,'' said Jack Tantleff, who heads (with Peter Franklin) the theater department at the William Morris Agency, referring to investors who gave their money to producers and got out of the way. ''Now the angels are the producers.''
 The reason is largely economic. These days the cost of any show, especially on Broadway, has made fund-raising an enormous burden. So a producing community has evolved that -- aside from Disney, with its huge corporate resources -- now often forges alliances to share the economic burden, which is one reason that more names -- 20 in the case of ''Caroline, or Change'' -- now appear above a show's title. Producers have also become less willing to help create by working with writers, composers and directors to develop material. Instead, they prefer to find shows that have been well-received elsewhere and transfer them, or to package well-known titles and stars, which is why Broadway is dominated by revivals.
 ''It's too facile to say that all the great producers are gone,'' said John Breglio, a leading theatrical lawyer with dozens of clients on and off Broadway. ''Having decades of experience still counts for something. But now the entry to producing seems to be a checkbook.''
 For many theater professionals, this is change for the worse. ''They want to come to ad meetings, they want to come to the auditions, they want to be able to give notes out of town,'' said John Barlow of Barlow-Hartman, who has been a Broadway publicist for the last 15 years. ''Most shows have one or two big investors like that. So any good idea is pureed down to a fare thee well, and a singular vision cannot persevere because of what needs to be done in the interest of compromise. In the end, there's an overall lack of inspiration, and it trickles down. Critics feel it. Audiences feel it.''
 This transformation has been taking place over the last two decades, at the same time that Arielle Tepper was finding in theater an escape from the unhappiness caused by her parents' divorce and her mother's battle with cancer.
 Ms. Tepper grew up in Manhattan and attended the Dalton School. Summers during college -- her degree is in lighting design -- she worked in theater offices in New York and in London, and after graduation she got a job at Alan Wasser Associates, the theatrical general managers who handled ''Miss Saigon,'' ''Cats,'' ''The Phantom of the Opera'' and ''Les Miserables.'' Her first producing venture was a cabaret-style musical called ''Vices'' that she presented in Chicago.
 ''It cost $50,000, and I paid for it,'' she said. ''We got decent reviews and ran for five weeks and lost 100 percent of the money. But my father came to opening night and he said, 'You did that.' And I realized that I had. My confidence level was through the roof. I said, 'This is the coolest thing ever.' ''
 Since then, Ms. Tepper has shown a scattershot impulse in the shows she has invested in, works on Broadway as different as the widely reviled exercise in rock 'n' roll camp, ''Dance of the Vampires,'' and the widely praised literary musical ''James Joyce's 'The Dead' ''; and works Off Broadway as quiet and shrewd as Tristine Skyler's debut play ''The Moonlight Room,'' as ambitiously original as Jason Robert Brown's two-handed musical, ''The Last Five Years,'' and as raucous and in-your-face as the wordless youth-pleasing bungee-cord extravaganza, ''De La Guarda.''
 From a commercial standpoint, her choices have been dubious, but she acknowledges that she has the luxury of indulging her whims. Her first Broadway show, ''Freak,'' John Leguizamo's solo work, which she produced in 1998 with Gregory Mosher and Bill Haber, was a hit. But her investments in the musical ''A Class Act'' and in two productions directed by Mr. Prince, who recruited Ms. Tepper as a producer-investor -- Carol Burnett's play, ''Hollywood Arms,'' and Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman's musical ''Bounce'' -- were lost.
 Asked how she chooses her shows, she gave an answer that testifies to an unformed aesthetic and the luxury of wealth. ''I think now I sort of do projects based on things I really love as well as people I want to work with,'' she said. 
 ''There have definitely been shows that have been huge mistakes,'' she added, ''that I did because I was young and inexperienced. But then there are shows like 'The Dead' and 'The Last Five Years,' which lost money but were great shows and I can't imagine not having produced them.''
 Ms. Tepper recognizes that she is still something of a novice producer. Her money has bought her a seat at the adult table, and though she has no shortage of confidence that she belongs there, she also knows she is on a learning curve.
 ''I have spent most of my time on my shows on the marketing and advertising side,'' she said. ''The creative people I've worked with -- Hal Prince, Stephen Sondheim, Carol Burnett -- these are not people where I believe I'm smarter about the directions the show should go than they are. In my conversations with them about difficulties with the show, I always, always, always present my thoughts as, 'As an audience member I feel,' as opposed to, 'As a producer I feel.' ''
 Which may make the Summer Play Festival a pivotal moment in her career, the first time that she is making a leap into creating something on her own.
 It is personal, too. What Ms. Tepper's fortune may have bought her most of all is relief from sadness. ''My mother made me promise I'd never give money to research organizations,'' she said, sitting in the temporary office of the Summer Play Festival at Theater Row Theaters. ''She didn't want to hear about a medicine that was going to be helpful in 10 years. She wanted to help people now.''

HEADLINE: A Friend Of the Parks Reappears

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

 BODY:
EVERY homeowner knows that when the budget is tight, it can be difficult to maintain a property, let alone to put in improvements that will make the place look really special.
 Taking care of Westchester County's more than 17,000 acres of public parkland poses a similar problem. The parks department does, of course, have money for basic maintenance like cutting the grass and picking up the trash. But little is available for extras like planting decorative trees, buying park benches or maintaining the gardens around memorials. 
 Hoping for more enhancements exactly like those, the Friends of Westchester County Parks, a nonprofit group, is trying to raise money from the people who use and enjoy the parks.
 ''We would love to have beautiful flowerbeds in our parks and see that they're maintained and manicured and watered,'' said Judy Matson, the chairwoman of the group. ''There are trees that need to be pruned and trails that need to be cleared and a host of various projects begging for support and attention. The group was formed to find a way to support the parks and provide the kind of enhancements that are not within the county parks' general upkeep programming.''
 The concept behind the Friends of Westchester County Parks, Ms. Matson said, is similar to that of the Central Park Conservancy, formed by New York City residents to support what in 1980 was a deteriorating park system. No one contends that the county's system is in the dire straits that inspired the beginning of the city conservancy, but the model of public support is similar, and the city and the county groups were formed around the same time. Westchester Friends, dormant for many years, became active again only recently.
 ''Our parks are over 70 years old,'' said Andrew J. Spano, the county executive. ''It forms what is considered by most to be a great park system, and just like Central Park it needs some advocacy on an ongoing basis.''
 Since the birth of Westchester's Parks Commission in 1922, the system has grown to include more than 50 parks, 6 golf courses, 5 swimming pools, 4 beaches, the Bronx River Parkway, the County Center and 3 boat-launching sites.
 It is a diverse system, ranging from Playland, the amusement park in Rye, to Muscoot, a working farm in Somers, to miles of hiking trails and acres of nature preserves. Park officials estimate that the system gets more than three million visitors a year. 
 ''Our county system is like most state park systems, in the breadth of what we have and manage,'' said Joseph A. Stout, the county parks commissioner. ''The facilities and the programs that we offer is not what you typically see on a countywide basis.''
 Mr. Stout says the park system is also atypical financially, receiving roughly 75 percent of its $42 million budget from revenue like golfing fees, concession rents and other business activities. The remaining 25 percent comes from tax dollars, which is the primary source for most municipal parks elsewhere. 
 Describing the park system as an economic force in Westchester, Mr. Stout pointed out that it is the county's largest employer of teenagers, and that it is used by tourists from outside the county who come to Playland, for example, or to the Bronx River Parkway to bicycle on Sunday. Those visitors spend money on food, gas and other local purchases. 
 Yet none of that means that the department and its staff of roughly 370 full-time employees have the resources to maintain the parks fully -- let alone improve them.
 As an example of how the Friends group could help, Mr. Stout suggested a donation earmarked for the perpetual care of a specific group of trees. Though his staff is supposed to care for millions of trees, he said, the tree crew has only three full-time members -- and they have time only for the ''bad emergency ones.'' With a Friends donation aimed at a specific site, he said, money could be used to hire a contractor to do the tree work.
 The new fund-raising effort includes radio public service announcements, as well as the distribution of brochures at park events.
 There is also the new Friends Web site, www.friendsofwestchesterparks.com,which offers membership and donation details. Donors can contribute to specific funds, like the Parks Tree Trust and Future Forests Funds, which raises money for the care and maintenance of the park system's trees.
 A donor can plant a seedling tree, or ''adopt'' a tree in memory of someone, with the use of a commemorative plaque. Memorial benches are also available. The actual tree work is done by park employees or contractors; the tree species, bench style and locations are determined with the help of the county forester.
 Donations can also be given to the Kensico Dam Plaza Enhancement Fund, to replace, as needed, the 80-year-old trees that now line the walkways.
 To involve schoolchildren in supporting the parks, the Friends group has begun a ''Pennies for Parks'' campaign, in which donation boxes and coin canisters are being placed at sites in parks and at other county locations. Third graders from the Columbus Elementary School in Thornwood were the first to take part in the program; the Friends group plans to rope in other schools in the fall.
 Saying she sought to raise $1 million over the next year, Ms. Matson said she hoped that Friends of the Park would ''help us be aware of the parks we take for granted on a daily basis.''
 ''They do need care and nurturing,'' she added, ''and we do need to keep them clean and green and growing, not just for today but for future generations.''

 right, Judy Matson and Liz Bracken-Thompson (with glasses) of the Friends of Westchester County Parks. (Photographs by Susan Stava for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Brooklyn Nets

 BODY:
The idea of bringing a professional sports team to the city almost always sounds great -- and then the calculation of cost versus benefits begins. It seems a new team requires a new sports facility, and for some reason, owners of these lucrative franchises are seldom willing to build anything without enormous infusions of public money. That is one of the major concerns about the proposal to place the Jets football stadium on Manhattan's far West Side at a cost to taxpayers of $600 million. It is also an issue when it comes to the Nets and Brooklyn. While the plans to bring professional basketball to Atlantic Avenue are in many ways more attractive than the football proposal, the scale of public investment needs closer examination.
 The amount the city and state will be asked to contribute to help the developer Bruce Ratner build the arena as part of a $2.5 billion, mixed-use 21-acre complex over Brooklyn's Atlantic Yards and on adjacent land is still being negotiated. But the public may be asked to guarantee hundreds of millions of dollars in bonded debt if the government helps pay for the arena and for significant infrastructure improvements to allow construction -- including moving Long Island Rail Road tracks two blocks. The tab also could include some 3,000 new parking spaces, which will help, if only a little, to manage the influx of cars in an already-clogged corridor. 
 Both proposed sports facilities in Brooklyn and Manhattan would be built over rail yards owned by the cash-short and debt-ridden Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which should not be pressured to give away its assets. The state-run authority -- which lacks other new sources of revenue -- should demand and get a fair market price for any land and air rights the developers at either site need. 
 A study commissioned by Mr. Ratner (who is a partner of The Times in constructing its new headquarters building) shows that the government would more than get back its investment in the Brooklyn project, based on 30 years of projected new tax revenues from team salaries and new office and residential occupants, among other factors. Another study, endorsed by opponents of the development, maintains that taxpayers could lose half a billion dollars in the deal. We would like to see a third, truly independent examination.
 Local objections to the Atlantic Yards development need to be addressed, particularly concerning the thousands of additional cars and cabs that can be expected on game nights. While some residents will be dislocated and inevitably wind up feeling pushed around, the mere threat of change is not a reason to oppose the project. Neither is the use of the state powers of eminent domain, as long as the people involved are compensated fairly. Mr. Ratner seems to have been generous in buying out homeowners and moving renters. Community residents have also been promised that the development around the arena will include 4,500 housing units, half slated to go to low and moderate income earners and the elderly. To address another longstanding complaint about sports projects, Mr. Ratner says 3,000 of the 19,000 seats for Nets games at the new Frank Gehry-designed arena will be sold at levels many neighborhood residents could afford -- around $15. 
 A basketball arena near downtown Brooklyn is basically a more attractive proposition than a football stadium in Manhattan. The building is less overwhelming and more likely to see regular use. Both the proposed sites need economic development, but the most important need of the far West Side of Manhattan is a subway line, not a monstrous sports center. The proposed Brooklyn site, at Flatbush and Atlantic, is already perhaps the best transportation hub in the city, but the area clearly needs an additional jump-start if it is going to thrive, and Mr. Ratner's project might provide that.
 There is also, of course, the dream of giving back to Brooklyn some of the luster it lost when Robert Moses killed Walter O'Malley's vision of building a domed stadium for the Dodgers at the same site nearly 50 years ago. That dream, the housing, the cheap tickets and all the other good things are not worth risking hundreds of millions of dollars in public money and dooming Brooklyn to impassible streets on every game night. But if those issues can be properly addressed, the idea of the Brooklyn Nets is tantalizing.

HEADLINE: Sudan Makes Pledge to Annan to Disarm Militias

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, Sudan, July 3 

 BODY:
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, has won a promise from Sudan's government to send troops to stop militia violence that has forced one million people to flee in the Darfur region.
 In a joint statement issued before Mr. Annan's departure on Saturday, the Sudanese president, Omar Hassan Ahmed el-Bashir, committed to disarming the militias and investigating human rights violations. 
 Mr. Annan had visited several camps in a tour aimed at pressing the government to end the 16-month Darfur conflict and to honor its promises to disarm the Janjaweed. That is the Arab militia blamed for attacks on black Africans.
 ''My message is simple: violence must stop,'' Mr. Annan told reporters after meeting with Mr. Bashir on Friday in Khartoum's heavily guarded military headquarters. ''The Janjaweed must be stopped, and a cease-fire must be respected by all.''
 Sudan promised to ''immediately start to disarm the Janjaweed and other armed outlaw groups'' and also said it would deploy a ''strong, credible'' police force to protect camps of displaced persons and other areas susceptible to attacks, the communique said.
 Sudan's foreign minister, Mostafa Osman Ismail, told reporters on Friday that 6,000 soldiers and policemen would be deployed in Darfur, but he did not say when.
 Thousands of people have been killed; the million or so forced from their homes have mostly taken shelter in camps with little access to clean water or proper sanitation.
 United Nations officials have called the situation the worst human disaster in the world, and Mr. Annan has said it is ''bordering on ethnic cleansing.''
 Sudan's pledge came as the United States raised the possibility of more sanctions if the government failed to act quickly to end attacks by the militias and allow aid to reach displaced people.
 The joint statement said the United Nations recognized Sudan's improvements in allowing some access to Darfur, but it highlighted the urgency of the situation by pushing for the resumption of talks between the government and the rebel group.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, a Bond Manager's Life Is Tougher

BYLINE: By CARLA FRIED

 BODY:
THE primary obsession for some Americans this spring was whether Carrie would end up with Mr. Big on ''Sex and the City,'' but bond investors found higher drama in Fed watching. When, they asked, would Alan Greenspan & Company raise interest rates? 
 They finally got their answer last week, as the Federal Reserve raised the federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 1.25 percent. 
 But unlike a television series finale, the Fed's move signals the beginning of a new season. 
 The small rate increase is expected to be the first of many Fed moves to keep the economy from overheating. And that is making bond fund managers and financial advisers scurry to protect their portfolios because, in the seesaw world of bonds, the prices of bonds fall when yields rise. 
 The second quarter was already tough. The yield on the bellwether 10-year Treasury note rose to 4.58 percent by June 30 from 3.86 percent three months earlier. That sent the total return -- yield plus the change in the securities' price -- to a 1.8 percent loss for the average taxable bond fund, according to Morningstar Inc. Municipal bond funds lost 2.1 percent, on average.
 ''Investing in stocks is tough, but bonds are tougher right now,'' said Lewis Altfest, a financial adviser based in New York who oversees more than $250 million. How tough? Earlier this year, William H. Gross, the Warren E. Buffett of bonds, became so bearish that he pulled some of his personal money from the $75 billion Pimco Total Return bond fund that he runs. He says he is now putting some of that money back in the fund, because prices in the Treasury market have become more reasonable, given sharply rising yields. But he remains cautious. ''I am neutral on bonds,'' Mr. Gross said. 
 Nor can you construe it as bullish when Robert L. Rodriguez has 38 percent of his $1.6 billion FPA New Income fund safely put away in cash and the fund's average duration -- a measure of its sensitivity to interest rate changes -- is a bearish 1.1 years. Mr. Rodriguez has guided the fund to 20 consecutive calendar years of positive returns; its annualized gain of about 7 percent over the past five years is about the same as that of Pimco Total Return.
 Mr. Rodriguez is still on a buyer's strike that began in June 2003, when the 10-year Treasury note yielded 3.14 percent. ''No one seems to realize how overvalued bonds got,'' he said. At current rates, he said, ''there's still significant downside risk.'' 
 Mr. Rodriguez said he would stay in cash until the 10-year Treasury note was yielding at least two to three percentage points more than the inflation rate. He expects inflation to run 2.5 to 3 percent over the next 12 months, which means that he is looking for a 10-year Treasury yield as high as 6 percent. ''Yes, rates are up, but not as far up as they should be or will be,'' Mr. Rodriguez said.
 The return to higher rates comes at an all-time peak for bond fund assets. In the market meltdown that started in 2000, chastened investors realized that bonds could help balance a stock-heavy diet. (In 2002, when the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 22 percent, the Lehman Brothers Aggregate Bond index gained 10.3 percent.) A record $140 billion poured into bond funds in 2002, and $31.4 billion more followed in 2003. More than $1.2 trillion was invested in bond funds at the end of May, according to the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund trade association. But that is not to say that investors have suddenly lost the urge to time the markets. Net withdrawals from bond funds exceeded $7.7 billion in April, when rates began to rise, and an additional $16 billion exited in May. 
 The smartest move may be to sit tight. Sure, bond values decline as rates rise, but the higher yields eventually offset the principal losses, assuming that you reinvest your income payouts. Brian W. Matthews, managing principal at Payden & Rygel, which manages $52 billion in bond portfolios, including the $520 million Payden Core Bond fund, took a look at what could happen to the Lehman Brothers Aggregate Bond index and to money market funds as rates rose. The Lehman index is an industry benchmark with an intermediate-term duration of about five years. Most fund advisers recommend sticking with intermediate-term funds; they provide most of the upside of a longer-term fund but with much less downside risk.
 To load the deck against the index, Mr. Matthews assumed an extreme situation -- which he does not expect to occur -- in which the federal funds rate kept rising from 1 percent all the way to 4 percent over 12 months. The index would lose 5.6 percent of its value with a rate climb of that magnitude; the money market yield would rise to 4 percent from 1 percent. 
 But after the first year, the index's higher income payout would push its total return back into positive territory, and in 2.5 years the index return would pull even with the money market; their cumulative gains would be 8 percent. From that point, the index would outperform the money market by 50 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, a quarter -- a significant amount in the bond world. ''You're paid to play in this game,'' Mr. Matthews said. Daniel Wiener, editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors and manager of $540 million in client assets, noted that even in 1994 and 1995, when the Fed raised rates by three percentage points in six months, prompting a broad bond sell-off, bonds rebounded within a year. ''Market timing doesn't work, and it's not necessary,'' he said. ''Rather than bail out, it makes more sense to pull in your duration if you're worried.''
 That is exactly what many fund managers are doing, within allowable limits. A vast majority of bond funds now require the manager to stick closely to the parameters of a benchmark index, and Eric Jacobson, a bond fund analyst at Morningstar, says managers today are leaning to the short end of their allowable ranges.
 At Vanguard, where $160 billion is invested in bond funds, Robert Auwaerter, head of the fixed-income division, said the funds were ''bearish across the board.''
 ''To the extent we can insulate a portfolio against rising rates,'' Mr. Auwaerter added, ''we are doing it.''
 Still, he is not looking for a repeat of 1994 and 1995. A gradual rise to a federal funds rate of 2 percent or so would effectively ''tap the brakes'' to slow down the economy, he said. Even at that level, he said, the real federal funds rate -- adjusted for inflation -- would still be near zero. 
 ''With some tightening, the Fed is still going to be quite accommodative,'' he said. As managers shorten the average durations of their funds, financial advisers are becoming more creative in finding income plays. High-yield corporate bond funds and Treasury inflation-protected securities, or TIPS, offered good value last year, but both areas are now considered to be played out. 
 With the easy money gone there, Louis P. Stanasolovich, president of Legend Financial Advisors in Pittsburgh, is turning to bank loan funds like the Eaton Vance Floating-Rate fund. These portfolios own corporate loans that are tied to a short-term interest rate that resets every 90 days. The fund can benefit even if rates rise, because it is continually reinvesting at the higher rates without having to worry about a big loss of principal. The main risk is whether the companies will pay off their debt, but in an improving economy, Mr. Stanasolovich said, that should not be a big concern.
 FOR investors willing to ride out short-term speed bumps, Mr. Jacobson of Morningstar recommended the Harbor Bond fund, a no-load fund run by Mr. Gross of Pimco, and the Vanguard Total Bond Market Index fund, which aims to mimic the return of the Lehman Brothers Aggregate Bond index. On the conservative end of the risk spectrum, he likes the Fidelity Short-Term Bond fund.
 ''If you can't assume the volatility it takes to be an investor, you don't belong in bonds, period,'' Mr. Jacobson said. ''But if you assume a little volatility and stick with it, you will get higher returns than a money market over time.''

HEADLINE: In Times of Trouble, the Founding Fathers Sell Well

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: Washington 

 BODY:
IN 1998, Ron Chernow, who had written successful biographies of J.P. Morgan and John D. Rockefeller, told his publisher he planned to write his next book on Alexander Hamilton. He got a chilly reception. 
 ''They said books on the founding fathers did not sell well,'' Mr. Chernow recalled in an interview last week. ''They said books on the Civil War and World War II were much more popular.'' 
 On this Independence Day, Mr. Chernow's book, ''Alexander Hamilton,'' is No.6 on the New York Times nonfiction best-seller list, and Cokie Roberts's ''Founding Mothers'' is No. 13. Eight other hard-cover books about the Revolution and the early days of the country are also on the ''new nonfiction'' display at the Borders on L Street in downtown Washington.
 Nor is this a short-term fad. Joseph J. Ellis's ''Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation'' and David McCullough's ''John Adams'' won Pulitzer Prizes in 2001 and 2002 and were among the biggest-selling history books of the last decade. 
 Many writers of history who once concentrated on different eras have switched their attention to the founding fathers. For example, Jay Winik, whose acclaimed book about the Civil War, ''April 1865: The Month That Saved America,'' came out in 2001, is now writing a book about the 1790's.
 ''It's not coincidental that this vogue arose now, in probably the most bitterly divided time since the Civil War,'' said H.W. Brands, a historian at Texas A&M University and the author of , ''The First American: The Life and Times of Benjamin Franklin,'' which was on best-seller lists in 2000.
 ''When the country is divided along cultural, economic and partisan grounds,'' Mr. Brands said, ''people look for a time when we were all together.''
 Mr. Winik agrees with that analysis. ''Americans are looking for an anchor,'' he said. ''What better anchor can you get than the founding fathers, who made something out of nothing. What is so critical to understand is that they really differed in a number of ways. They had tough, hard debates, jealousies and rivalries. But they came together, and the sum became greater than the individual parts.''
 As Mr. Ellis toured to promote his book, which is a series of essays about the relationships between and among the founding fathers, he said he realized that people were impressed with the civil, respectful correspondence that Adams and Jefferson, bitter political enemies, conducted for years after they left office. 
 ''It's difficult to comprehend Bill Clinton developing a correspondence with George W. Bush,'' Mr. Ellis said. 
 Over the years, views about the founding fathers have risen and fallen with the public mood. In the early 19th century, Americans ''spat on the graves of the founding fathers,'' blaming them for having saddled the country with seemingly irreconcilable problems, Mr. Brands said.
 Northerners ''called the Constitution a covenant with hell because it allowed slavery,'' Mr. Brands said. ''Southerners thought 'all men created equal' was a glittering generality that meant nothing in everyday life.''
 But during the Reconstruction period, which coincided with celebrations of the country's centennial, people began to look at the founders in a different light -- as great men of a golden age, beloved in the North and South alike.
 Disdain for the founders was expressed once again at the turn of the 20th century, when some scholars argued these men were guided more by personal financial motives than patriotic impulses. During the days of the civil rights movement, Washington, Jefferson and others were sometimes seen as hypocrites for having owned slaves.
 But in times of national crisis, like the two world wars, when Americans ''especially wanted to feel unified and good about themselves,'' Mr. Brands said, the prevailing view of the founders tended to be uniformly positive.
 The reputations of individual founders also fluctuate with the times, just as they do collectively. Mr. McCullough has said he started out researching a joint biography of Jefferson and Adams. But as he got into it, he decided Jefferson was overrated and Adams underrated and decided to stick to Adams.
 Edmund Morgan, whose latest book is a collection of essays called ''The Genuine Article: A Historian Looks at Early America,'' said new details of Jefferson's relationship with the slave Sally Hemmings was now tarnishing the name of the third president. For most of the 20th century, Mr. Morgan said, historians had disregarded the significance of that relationship.. 
 Another reason for the popularity of books about the founding fathers is that they themselves wrote so well. ''They expressed themselves at great length with exceptional depth and eloquence that would do credit to any politician or thinker,'' Mr. Chernow said. ''They are so quotable. We actually can know them better than we can know our own politicians.''
 Peter Osnos, publisher of PublicAffairs, said the books about the founding fathers were popular, and profitable, in large part because they are so readable. ''The writing of history has changed dramatically,'' he said. ''The old versions portrayed the founders as deities, which makes them dull. The new portraits are much richer and show them as people.''
 ''These writers are great storytellers telling great stories,'' Mr. Osnos said. 
 What today's historians have learned, Mr. Chernow said, is to ''take figures who once seemed dry and remote and bring them to life in narrative biographies.''
 Mr. McCullough especially is regarded by his peers as a master of narrative writing. ''My Benjamin Franklin book could never have done so well if the path had not been blazed by David McCullough,'' said Walter Isaacson, whose ''Benjamin Franklin: An American Life,'' was a best-seller last year. 
 And the first chapter of Mr. Ellis's book, ''The Founding Brothers,'' about the duel in which Aaron Burr killed Hamilton, is widely regarded as one of the finest pieces of narrative nonfiction in modern literature.
 Mr. Brands, who is now writing a biography of Andrew Jackson, said he was delighted books about the founding fathers were doing so well but was not sure fawning over these figures was healthy for the country.
 Writing last year in The Atlantic Monthly, Mr. Brands put it this way: ''In revering the founders, we undervaluing ourselves and sabotage our own efforts to make improvements -- necessary improvements -- in the republican experiment they began. Our love for the founders leads us to abandon, and even to betray, the very principles they fought for.''
