HEADLINE: Sightseeing in Oman? You Mustn't Miss the Smugglers

BYLINE: By OTTO POHL

DATELINE: KHASAB, Oman 

 BODY:
The Iranians come at daybreak, buzzing across the green water in small boats packed with goats. They deliver their livestock to Omani traders, idle away the hot midday hours and, as darkness sets in, return to Iran, this time loaded with cigarettes, tea and clothing. 
 Aside from the starkly beautiful rocky fjords, tourist attractions are scarce on this remote tip of the Arabian Peninsula. Watching the Iranian smugglers come and go is about the best local travel operators can muster. 
 ''We do it as part of the city tour,'' said Abdul Khalique Ahmed, the managing director of Khasab Travel and Tours. ''People like to see the smugglers.''
 The boats speed across the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow shipping lane that connects the Persian Gulf to the Arabian Sea and beyond. About 15 percent of the world's oil passes through this vitally strategic sea lane, closely guarded by the United States military. 
 But the goat and cigarette trade, running perpendicular to the oil tankers, is the only commerce the locals care about. It is said to represent over half of the economy here on the Musandam peninsula, a small outpost of Oman north of the United Arab Emirates. The trade is illegal in Iran but legal in Oman, which means that the Omani government collects taxes and grants de facto visas to the Iranians, as long as they do not stray far from the port or stay overnight. 
 The smuggling started after Iran closed its borders after the 1979 revolution, and exploded after the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988. Trade grew further after completion of the first paved road from Khasab to the United Arab Emirates in 1997. 
 These days, however, traders like Abdullah Sadani, a 33-year-old Iranian, complain that reform in Iran is ruining business. An import deal that Iran signed with international cigarette companies in 2002 has decimated that trade, which was by far the largest and most lucrative. Between 50 and 80 boats currently make the crossing each day, perhaps a quarter of the number two years ago, merchants say. Mr. Sadani earns only a few dollars a day, while a large load of cigarettes could have made him up to $30 a few years ago. 
 Sitting in a cafe near the port, Mr. Sadani, grizzled by sun, cigarettes and several days of beard growth, explained that despite the lower pay, this was the only way he could support his wife and four children back in the Iranian port of Bandar-e Kong. 
 Over the years, he said, he has been robbed by pirates, shot at by the police and occasionally forced to dump his cargo overboard to avoid arrest. Once, when his outboard motor broke down, he drifted for five days without food or water amid the cargo ships, oil tankers and naval vessels that ply the Persian Gulf. 
 Problems with the Iranian authorities are solved in time-honored fashion. ''Baksheesh,'' Mr. Sadani said emphatically, using the Persian word for tip or bribe while making a circular motion with his hand over his head. 
 A translator interpreted the gesture. ''Baksheesh makes the world go round.'' 
 Like other traders, Mr. Sadani carries a cellphone with two SIM card phone chips, one for Iran and one for Oman. He switches chips halfway through the journey, so spotters on the Iranian side can easily reach him on his return trip to warn him of police activity. 
 Cigarettes are still smuggled to avoid the taxes the Iranians levy on the newly legal trade, but other products, including tea, clothing, soft drinks and even electronics, have gained importance. Goods worth $250,000 to $500,000 cross the strait each day, in the estimation of Munavvar Shuaib, a manager at Abdul Fatah Mohamad Noor Trading in the center of Khasab's small marketplace. At the height of trade, two or three years ago, volumes were up to five times that. 
 Even at that reduced level, it is an enormous amount of business to the roughly 30,000 Omanis who live in the region. And for young men like Hassan al-Kumzari, 22, smuggling is clearly the option of choice. Dressed in the traditional flowing white gown and white cap, he oversees a fleet of 10 trucks that shuttle his goats from the dusty port to Ras Al Khaimah, the northernmost city in the United Arab Emirates, and then returns with goods destined for Iran. 
 He used to help his father, a fisherman, until he learned about the traders in the port of Khasab. He says his father is proud of his new line of work. 
 ''My son is doing something better than just smelling of fish,'' Mr. Kumzari said, summarizing his father's reasoning. 
 He buys about 300 goats a day, paying 10 Omani rials, about $26, for each one, and reselling them at a 50 percent markup in the United Arab Emirates. He then ships back whatever his business partners in Iran need that afternoon. He estimates that for a good month he can clear as much as $10,000.
 Mr. Kumzari said he still longed for the stability of a government job, but they were not hiring. As he described his workday, which consists largely of supervising others for a few hours and making a few phone calls, he stopped, as if suddenly struck by a revelation. 
 ''It is already like a government job,'' he said, ''but with goats.''

HEADLINE: Twin Beams to Return to Skies, but Costs Are Daunting

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Intended originally as an ephemeral memorial, the twin-beam ''Tribute in Light,'' which simultaneously marks the presence and absence of the World Trade Center, has been guaranteed a place in the night sky every Sept. 11 for at least the next five years.
 The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board voted yesterday to give $3.5 million to the Municipal Art Society, which helps produce the memorial. The society will buy and maintain the 88 searchlights needed for the display, two square columns of light whose proportions and placement echo the twin towers -- colossally yet ethereally.
 ''The public's enthusiasm for the lights is evident,'' Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris said yesterday. ''And bringing them back one day a year, on 9/11, is beautiful and respectful.'' 
 ''Tribute in Light'' was first illuminated March 11, 2002, six months after the attack. By design, it ran only until April 14, though popular sentiment seemed to favor extending it in some way. 
 Last August, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki said the tribute would be brought back each year. It returned for one night on Sept. 11, 2003. But the logistics behind the display were becoming increasingly complex and expensive.
 The rental costs were going up. It was difficult to find suppliers who could furnish 88 lights at once. And donors who would underwrite the $700,000 cost of a one-evening event were few and far between.
 ''No matter who's paying for the lights,'' said Kevin M. Rampe, president of the development corporation, ''it makes sense to buy them.''
 Mr. Rampe added that ''Tribute in Light'' might be incorporated some way into the permanent memorial that is being designed for the trade center site, so the fixtures, which can cost up to $20,000 each, ''are going to have value in the long run.''
 Board members supported the project but expressed concern about the dwindling amount of money available for rebuilding Lower Manhattan. Though the federal Housing and Urban Development Department has given the development corporation $2.783 billion in grants, there is now less than $900 million to allocate.
 ''There's no fat remaining,'' said Roland W. Betts, a member of the development corporation board. Money is needed for the memorial and the infrastructure at the trade center site, he said. Other board members, Paul A. Crotty and Thomas S. Johnson, said the authorization for ''Tribute in Light'' of ''an amount not to exceed $3.5 million'' meant just that and that they expected the Municipal Art Society to contain costs below $3.5 million if possible.
 But the spending was then approved unanimously. ''To know now that there's the opportunity for it to continue for the next five years is very gratifying,'' said Frank E. Sanchis III, senior vice president of the Municipal Art Society. 
 The searchlights have a 40-year lifespan, said Anita Contini, a development corporation vice president. They would probably be stored at Gateway National Park on the 364 days a year that they are not needed in Lower Manhattan.
 One daunting challenge that has yet to be resolved is finding a staging area for the searchlights after this year. Almost three-quarters of an acre is needed to create two 50-by-50-foot arrays that are related to one another and the surrounding street grid as the twin towers were. And the site has to be as close as possible to ground zero.
 The current spot set aside for the searchlights is in Battery Park City, at West and Vesey Streets. But this is where Goldman Sachs is planning its new headquarters.
 In other actions yesterday, the board approved spending up to $6.5 million for the planning and preliminary design of the cultural center and performing arts center on the trade center site. Last month, the corporation offered space in these buildings to the Joyce Theater Foundation, the Signature Theater Company, the Drawing Center and the Freedom Center. The initial planning should be completed early next year.
 Also yesterday, Robert P. Balachandran took his seat on the corporation board, replacing Christy Ferrer. He is a managing director at Bear Stearns and the former president and chief executive of the Hudson River Park Trust.

HEADLINE: Down Day Leaves S.&P. 500 With a Loss for the Year

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks fell after disappointing reports from technology companies and retailers, erasing the final few points of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index's gains for the year.
 A 3.2 percent rise in oil prices renewed concern that higher energy prices would stem spending by companies and consumers alike. Crude oil for August delivery rose $1.25 to settle at $40.33 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 The S.&P. 500 fell 9.22 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,109.11, leaving it with a loss of 0.3 percent for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 68.73 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,171.56. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 30.76 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,935.32. All three benchmarks dropped for the fourth time in five days. 
 The Dow has dropped 2.7 percent this year, while the Nasdaq has declined 3.4 percent amid speculation that earnings growth will slow more than forecast.
 ''This quarter, expectations were building that we would have 20 percent growth in earnings,'' said Brett Mitstifer, a money manager at Value Line Securities, which has $3.5 billion in assets in New York. Recent profit reports ''indicate that that momentum, that upside in earnings surprises, is not going to take place.''
 Nearly two stocks fell today for each one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. Some 1.4 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board, 4.3 percent less than the daily average this year.
 Yahoo, the owner of the most-visited group of Internet sites, slid $2.52, to $30.08, after second-quarter profit failed to beat estimates. Net income more than doubled to 8 cents a share, matching the average analyst estimate in a Thomson survey. Yahoo shares have risen 71 percent in the last year, and they trade at 120 times earnings.
 Other Web stocks also declined. EBay shed $3.22, to $83.65, while Amazon.com fell $1.50, to $49.50. Info-Space lost $2.96, to $32.24.
 BMC Software, a maker of mainframe and server programs, lost $2.51, or 15.1 percent, to $14.16, for one of the largest percentage declines in the S.&P. 500. Late Wednesday, the company said that first-quarter sales would be $318 million to $328 million, missing its forecast of $345 million to $355 million.
 Siebel Systems, one of the world's largest makers of customer service software, sank $1.23, or 13.4 percent, to $7.98, another one of the steepest declines in the S.&P. 500. The company said second-quarter sales fell to $301 million from $333.3 million a year earlier. Siebel had predicted that revenue would rise to $340 million to $365 million.
 The S.&P. 500's software and services index dropped 2.3 percent, with 27 of the 29 companies in the index declining. 
 Many retailers reported disappointing sales for June. Shares of Big Lots, the nation's largest retailer of discontinued and overstocked goods, dropped $1.42, to $12.52. The company said it would post a loss in the second and third quarters because of declining sales. 
 Talbots, the clothing retailer, shed $5.91, to $33.28. The company predicted it would earn 33 cents to 35 cents a share in the fiscal second quarter, less than the 38-cent average estimate in a Thomson poll. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 0.9 percent in June, short of forecasts.
 Treasury prices were little changed yesterday. By late in the day, the price of the benchmark 10-year note was 102 6/32, up 1/32. The yield was unchanged at 4.47 percent.

HEADLINE: Outsourcing Comes to Summer Camp

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN

DATELINE: WINSLOW, Me. 

 BODY:
ONE by one, the young men streamed through the gates at Logan International Airport in Boston and scanned the crowd with bleary eyes. A man held up a red pennant that read ''Camp Wigwam.'' Right church, wrong pew. Farther down the receiving line was a yellow plastic sled with ''Camp Caribou'' written across it. This was it.
 Soon, the Camp Caribou vans, filled with their roughly two dozen passengers, were cruising up Route 95. The evening traffic thinned out, the pine trees thickened and the questions began. How big was Maine anyway, wondered Richard Cotter, 20, a volleyball instructor from New Zealand. ''Say you get a night off, how hard is it to get anywhere in Maine?''
 Forget it, said Lynton Dawson, a soccer coach from England and the only nonrookie in the van. ''Maine is massive. It takes like an hour to drive to any other town.'' 
 Andrew Bourne, an 18-year-old wakeboarding champion from South Africa, asked about the fauna. Were there alligators? They had stared across the lake at him the other time he had been to the United States, at a competition in Tampa, Fla. Bill Lerman, behind the wheel of the lead van, told him not to worry. ''We have some good-sized snapping turtles, but they don't want anything to do with you,'' said Mr. Lerman, the camp director.
 Summer sleep-away camp is still a quintessentially, even peculiarly American institution. Color wars are seldom fought on foreign soil, and in most countries, scions of the middle and upper classes do not associate summer with name tags sewn on underwear and enforced dips in freezing lakes.
 But in a shift reminiscent of the outsourcing trend in corporate America, the fresh-faced role model teaching your child to paddle a canoe is increasingly likely to be from overseas these days. According to the American Camping Association, international counselors, as the visiting workers are known, now number 25,000 and make up one-fifth of all counselors. (The number rose as high as 35,000 in recent years, but has fallen since visa rules were tightened after Sept. 11.)
 Over the 36 years that his family has run Caribou, a boys' sports camp three and a half hours northeast of Boston, Mr. Lerman has had to become an expert in cultural translation: this year, more than half of his 80 counselors have been recruited from other countries. Many are in the United States for the first time.
 The notion of Mr. Lerman being the first American someone from another country gets to know is an interesting one. A hyperactive 52-year-old with a lion-colored mane of shoulder-length hair and a thick mustache, Mr. Lerman resembles a cross between the rocker Joe Walsh and the rocker-outdoorsman-television personality Ted Nugent, spends most of the summer tearing around the grounds on a mountain bike, an A.T.V. or a golf cart, and speaks in a working-class Boston accent thicker than the sludge at the bottom of a can of baked beans. (His two favorite words are ''dude'' and ''sweet,'' the latter of which he pronounces ''swaaate.'') 
 While there are no long-term statistics tracking the change across the industry, two of the largest agencies that match foreign workers with American camps, Camp Counselors USA, of Sausalito, Calif., and Camp America, of Stamford, Conn., each place about 8,000 international counselors a year now. Camp America placed 1,100 counselors in 1975, and Camp Counselors placed 120 in 1986, its first year.
 For a generation of young Americans, camp work seems to have lost much of its appeal, mostly for economic and professional reasons. ''A lot of Americans who'd like to work at a summer camp can't afford to work at a summer camp,'' said Martha Lerman, 45, Mr. Lerman's wife and Caribou's co-director. Often, they need to pay off college loans or get on a career track by obtaining resume-building internships at law firms and investment banks.
 The good part, Mr. Lerman said, is that the international counselors are often more mature than their American counterparts. ''It's much easier to find a 25-year-old qualified Australian or New Zealander who can come to the U.S. and work,'' he said. ''At 25 in the U.S., unless you're a teacher or a guidance counselor, or a bum, you don't have the summer off to work at camps.'' Many of the Caribou counselors are accomplished or even professional athletes -- tennis players from Mexico, baseball instructors from Australia, hockey teachers from, of course, Canada.
 And the campers, who range in age from 8 to 15, don't seem to mind the accents, even when it means being taught how to field grounders by a coach who hails from a place where ''short hop'' is something baby kangaroos do. Andy Qualmann, the camp's baseball director and a former member of the Australian national baseball team (yes, there is one), said his credentials were occasionally challenged at first, but added, ''It only takes one time where you fix one little thing in his swing and it really works, and they go, 'Oh, he knows what he's talking about.' ''
 Outside Kennebunkport that first evening, June 17, the caravan stopped at a rest area. Over a veggie patty at Burger King -- the only seemingly safe entree on the menu for someone who follows halal practices -- Tahir Rakmatullah, a riflery teacher from South Africa, confessed concerns that his charges, due to arrive in another week, might lack discipline. ''I've heard they're rich and spoiled,'' Mr. Rakmatullah, 22, a former police officer who runs a security company in Johannesburg, said of American youngsters. But he was confident he could keep them in line. ''I have my ways,'' he said.
 (Spoiled, perhaps. Rich, definitely, at least some of them. Caribou charges $7,150 for a full seven-week session and $4,450 for a half session.)
 Finally the vans turned down a long dirt road and pulled up beside some lodge-y wooden buildings surrounded by 200 acres of freshly groomed playing fields, forests and a lake.
 The two dozen counselors checked out their quarters -- long bunkhouses with particle-board floors, fluorescent lights and a line of skinny beds on either side of an aisle. Matthew Cockcroft, a baseball instructor from South Africa, was in heaven. ''It's beautiful,'' said Mr. Cockcroft, 19. He wasn't kidding. ''I can tell it's going to be a great summer.''
 ORIENTATION did not officially begin until the next morning. Unofficially, it began that night with a trip to Pete & Larry's, the bar in the Holiday Inn in Waterville, where it was ladies' night and the counselors found that life in the backwoods was not quite so isolated after all.
 There are three camps in and around Waterville, a town of about 15,000 (Caribou is actually in a neighboring town, Winslow). Two are boys' camps and one is a girls' camp, and the bar was pretty much taken over by young, fit, good-looking people of many nations (though the girls' camp counselors were mostly, but not entirely, American). Julie Seltzer, a counselor at Camp Matoaka and a sociology student at Northeastern University, said she found the summer camp scene in Waterville so fascinating she was writing a paper on it.
 ''What is more sociological than 50,000 societies crammed into one square mile for two months?'' Ms. Seltzer yelled over the pounding dance music. ''You become part of each other's culture.''
 Outside on the smokers' sidewalk, the sociology was getting even more complex. Chrissy Gamage, a local woman, was fixated on Damien Sanders, a Caribou counselor and former diver for the British Navy with biceps and cheekbones to die for.
 ''Damien,'' Ms. Gamage, 27, cooed, ''you're my friend now.'' Their bodies collided in an awkward tipsy cross between a hug and a handshake.
 ''How do you . . .,'' Mr. Sanders began.
 ''How do we do it in Maine?'' Ms. Gamage asked. ''We actually have sex in Maine.'' Mr. Sanders, 21, managed a wince that passed for an adorable smile.
 Ms. Gamage, a recently divorced social worker, explained that the annual arrival of the male counselors is a much-anticipated event in the calendars of Waterville's single women.
 ''We check our watches,'' she said. ''In summer, it's the counselors. In fall, it's the hunters.'' With that, she beckoned Mr. Sanders behind a pole for a private word.
 The next morning, the counselors were summoned to the ''chapel,'' a clearing under some hemlock trees by the lake, to talk about themselves and what mattered to them. They had come from at least eight countries, including Mexico and the Netherlands. About 20 of the international counselors were first-timers.
 Mr. Lerman urged the counselors to heed the example of a climbing instructor, Chris Davidson, 19, a red-crew-cutted bruiser whose all-New Zealand soccer hooligan looks were enhanced by nine stitches above his left eye, a souvenir of a recent run-in with some locals outside Bootlegger's tavern in Waterville. ''He's also into barroom brawling,'' Mr. Lerman said, ''not necessarily winning.''
 Mr. Dawson, the soccer coach from the outskirts of Liverpool, said he missed the comforts of home -- ''a meat pie on a tea cake'' and a bone-smashing game of rugby. His goal for the summer, he said, was finally to win color war.
 Ernesto Medina, 37, a petrochemical engineer from Mexico turned college professor who was at Caribou to teach swimming, said: ''You reach a time in your life when you have to decide how you want to live. I wanted to find out about myself, and I thought, 'What do you hate?' and I thought, 'I hate teaching; it's boring.' So I have spent the past six years of my life doing that. And I love it.''
 At the evening barbecue, Mr. Medina said that to be an effective teacher, he had to set his ego aside completely. 
 He offered an illustration. ''Who do you thank for your dinner?'' he asked a visitor. The fish for giving its life, the farmer for growing the vegetables, it was suggested. 
 ''What about the fork?''
 The fork?, the visitor responded, holding up the plastic utensil. Never thought of it.
 Mr. Medina leaned forward slightly. ''I am the fork,'' he said.
 The next morning, the counselors got a taste of their director's high-octane leadership style. Mr. Lerman had brought in a motivational speaker to address the theme of ''Achieving Excellence.'' But the counselors, tired and maybe a bit hung over, were barely achieving consciousness. Mr. Lerman, uncharacteristically dressed in a suit (he was on his way to a funeral), stopped the show.
 ''You're all kind of flat-lined right now,'' he said. ''We need to do something about it.'' He then led the counselors through a set of calisthenics, topped off with a quick lesson in the basics of the peekaboo boxing style made famous by Floyd Patterson: three left jabs, a right cross and a left hook. The counselors paid considerably closer attention for the rest of the morning.
 Basic training for counselors is mostly pretty basic. ''All campers should shower at least once daily,'' reads one rule in the Caribou manual. ''This process should include the use of soap, shampoo and warm water.''
 But some international counselors also need to be instructed on the finer points of the American way of surrogate parenting.
 ''I used to have to sit down with the Aussies particularly,'' Martha Lerman said. ''Most of them had stern, distant fathers who wouldn't think twice about smacking them. One time I had this guy from Australia -- a camper in his bunk loved him, just worshiped this guy. And one day the camper jumped on his back, and the counselor threw him to the ground and grabbed him by his neck and said 'Don't ever, ever do that to me again.' The same counselor threw away a kid's baby blanket.''
 Needless to say, he was not invited back. (Ms. Lerman said that the current crop of Australians seems a lot more sensitive.)
 Every January for the last few years, the Lermans have gone barnstorming through the Southern Hemisphere to job fairs, set up by the placement agencies, in Sydney, Brisbane, Johannesburg and elsewhere. Mr. Lerman peppers the candidates with probing questions: ''How were you disciplined as a child? What would you fire someone for if you were director of the camp? How do you handle no privacy?''
 The counselors do not get rich working for the camps. For about 10 weeks' work, they receive $800 to $1,800 -- usually just about enough to cover their airfare. They also get 30-day travel visas to use after camp ends, which for many counselors is the best part of the deal.
 The process of getting cleared to work in the United States has gotten more cumbersome since 9/11 and has discouraged some applicants.
 But the director of Camp Counselors USA, Ruthie Develle, said that there has been a positive side effect: the American government has given her the power to cancel the visas of the small percentage of counselors who would play the system by disappearing after arriving in the country. ''People would bolt before they got to camp, after they got to camp -- we got everything,'' Ms. Develle said. ''In the past, we'd tell them their visa would get canceled, but we didn't really know if it did.''
 The United States' recent geopolitical adventures have also hurt recruiting, but only a little. ''In certain countries,'' said Dennis Regan, the senior vice president of Camp America, ''the Iraqi war had some impact -- countries like France and Germany, as you might expect. But the U.S. remains a huge draw.''
 BY the end of orientation, most of the counselors were anxious for the campers to arrive; the rest were just anxious. In any case, June 26 rolled around, another bunch of vans drove up the dirt road, and Camp Caribou rang with the shouts of 225 little and not-so-little voices.
 Just a few days later, the place was in midseason form. At morning announcements by the flagpole, three distracted boys watched an earthworm writhe at the end of a stick. Three more clustered around the rabbit cage, poking their fingers in. Mr. Davidson walked up. ''I shoot bunnies at home,'' he told them. ''Come on guys, got to sit down.''
 Over breakfast, the counselors said things were going well. Mr. Davidson, a repo man and police cadet back home in New Zealand, said he was winning the battle to behave himself. ''Last year I was wedgy-ing a lot of the kids,'' he said. So far this year, he had lapsed just once.
 After breakfast each day, the campers must spend 45 minutes cleaning their bunks, most of which they spend proving how little work you can do if you set your mind to it. As the 11-year-olds of Bunk 7 listlessly pushed dirt around on the floor, Mr. Medina lifted up the bed of a boy named Jake to inspect. ''What's this here?'' he asked, pulling a pair of shorts from underneath the mattress. ''I have no idea how that got there,'' Jake said.
 On the shooting range, Mr. Rakmatullah tried to be patient. ''Don't argue,'' he said to a boy named Sam who was resisting wearing his shooting sling in the prescribed way. Sam finished and gave his target sheet to Mr. Rakmatullah, who scored it a 30 out of 100. ''You messed up,'' he said. ''But don't worry, you'll get it.''
 Down by the lake, first-period swim class was almost over. Mr. Medina took three of the slower learners over to the corrugated-concrete boat launch, faced them away from the class so they would not notice their fellow campers getting out of the water, got down on his kickboard and demonstrated the breast stroke, s-l-o-w-l-y.
 After 10 minutes, the boys began coordinating their arm sweeps with their kicks. The period ended. ''Ernesto,'' the waterfront director, Corky Brandt, called over. ''We've got to send them out.''
 ''O.K,'' Mr. Medina said, but told his students, ''Twenty kicks before you go.'' Mr. Brandt pulled Mr. Medina aside and pointed out some students from the next class who needed a hand. ''I use Ernesto as a troubleshooter,'' Mr. Brandt said. ''I got a counselor that's not too strong in teaching butterfly, so I use Ernesto to help out.''
 Mr. Medina said the secret of teaching is asking the boys how they wanted to be taught. ''If you listen to them, you will have all the answers, and you apply them,'' he said. ''O.K., guys.'' He blew his whistle and waded into the lake to begin another class.
 Articles in this series are looking at the experience of summer through the lives of people who create its traditions. Previous contributions:
nytimes.com/escapes

HEADLINE: Former Official in Nassau Is Charged With Misconduct

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, July 8 

 BODY:
A former deputy executive of Nassau County was arrested on Thursday on charges of official misconduct in billing personal expenses to the county, engaging in sexual abuse in his county car and forcing a county aide into political activity. 
 The former deputy, Peter T. Sylver, pleaded not guilty, and his lawyer accused prosecutors of conducting a political witch hunt. The lawyer, Stephen Worth, is a longtime political ally of the county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, who befriended Mr. Sylver and appointed him the deputy for economic development. 
 Mr. Sylver resigned under fire last November. Earlier this year the County Legislature conducted investigative hearings into his conduct and irregularities at the agencies under his domain. Separately, a United States Department of Housing and Urban Development audit ordered Nassau to refund nearly $1.2 million in aid that his agencies had spent in violation of federal rules; the county is disputing the findings and the order. There have also been three multimillion-dollar lawsuits filed in connection with the scandal.
 Despite the federal audit findings and critics' accusations of wrongdoing by Mr. Sylver ranging from nepotism to pressuring a contractor, the criminal charges were limited to three misdemeanors and one felony. The Nassau district attorney, Denis Dillon, said, ''There were other possible charges,'' but the evidence for them was not as strong.
 The whole episode proved a major political embarrassment for Mr. Suozzi, a Democrat who ended decades of Republican rule in 2001 when he won election as a reformer vowing to clean up mismanagement and corruption. If he runs for re-election next year, the Republicans say, they will hammer away at these scandals.
 Mr. Suozzi called the Sylver case an aberration and has imposed tighter controls to prevent a recurrence. ''It's a very sad day for the people of Nassau County,'' he said on Thursday. The arrest ''brings this to a close,'' and ''now we need to move forward,'' he said.
 But the official who first questioned Mr. Sylver's actions, the Legislature's Republican minority leader, Peter J. Schmitt, is not about to let the issue die. ''These people, Suozzi and his administration, handled this with denial, obstruction, stonewalling and lying,'' he said.
 Mr. Sylver, 35, of Westbury, a former dean at Hofstra Law School, was a rising star in the Suozzi administration. Now he is studying for the ministry, his lawyer said.
 Announcing the charges, Mr. Dillon accused Mr. Sylver of filing false documents for reimbursement of a $3,462 trip to London for himself and his wife in 2002, and billing $772 in personal expenses to an unauthorized county credit card.
 Mr. Dillon also charged that Mr. Sylver coerced a county aide to join him on a tour of polling places on Election Day last year. 
 Mr. Sylver was also charged with touching a woman sexually without her consent in his county car outside his office at 400 County Seat Drive here last August.
 Citing privacy concerns, Mr. Dillon declined to identify the woman. Other officials previously disclosed that Mr. Sylver's assistant had accused him of firing her after she refused his advances. She then dropped her complaint in return for being promoted to a higher-paying job in another agency. Mr. Schmitt called that deal a cover-up.
 That woman has since sued Mr. Sylver and Mr. Suozzi over the way she was treated and Mr. Schmitt for publicizing her case. In another suit, two former county officials claim they were fired for being whistle-blowers after complaining that grants were used improperly to pay some of Mr. Sylver's workers. And the Crowe Deegan law firm of Glen Cove, where Mr. Suozzi was mayor, is suing Mr. Schmitt for defamation after he said the firm had back-billed for legal work. The firm received $750,000 in fees from the county for legal work -- some of which was done before Mr. Suozzi took office -- that was not put out to bid, a violation cited in the federal audit.
 Mr. Worth said, ''It's all about politics.'' He said that after months of investigation, ''the charges are at most $5,000, which of course we maintain was properly spent.''

HEADLINE: Weekender Sag Harbor, N.Y.

BYLINE: By ELLEN MAGUIRE

 BODY:
WITH its narrow, salt-swept streets, centuries-old homes, and bustling wharf, Sag Harbor at first glance looks more like a New England fishing village than part of the tony Hamptons. Indeed, if the Hamptons could be described as wealthy sisters, each more beautiful than the next, Sag Harbor would be the brainy one with glasses. Sure, quaint cottages go for $1 million-plus, but residents include E. L. Doctorow, Betty Friedan, the playwright Joe Pintauro and a slew of weekenders who would rather work on their latest books-in-progress than their tans. 
 In 1789, this two-square-mile village nestled by a bay on the south fork of eastern Long Island was one of the busiest whaling ports in the nation. A rowdy and culturally diverse community sprang up (a fact that current full- and part-time residents mention frequently and with pride) and evolved into a haven for writers: James Fenimore Cooper arrived in 1818 in search of whales and left with notes for his first novel, and when John Steinbeck won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1962, he lived in a modest house by the water on Bluff Point, where he spent the last 15 years of his life. 
 Today that literary legacy is kept alive by novelists, playwrights, at least six writers groups and a phalanx of journalists -- many of whom participate in a weekly softball game presided over by John Leo, a columnist for US News & World Report. 
 A passion for old houses and buildings unites residents, no matter their professions. Ninety percent of Sag Harbor is on the National Register of Historic Places, including Azurest, a vacation enclave created in 1947 for middle and upper-class black families, and exterior changes to buildings in the historic district must be approved by the local Board of Historic Preservation and Architectural Review.
 The biggest controversy this spring involved the vintage sign for the Sag Harbor Cinema, which the owner, Gerald Mallow, had taken down and planned to replace. Without Mr. Mallow's permission, Brenda Siemer, a Sagaponack resident, moved the sign to the back lawn of the Sag Harbor Whaling Museum for safekeeping (the sign ''documented the heartbeat of the town,'' she said), and Mr. Mallow reported it missing. The two have since resolved their differences and Ms. Siemer, a documentary filmmaker who is married to the actor Roy Scheider, has raised $20,000 for the sign's restoration.
 ''It's all about the history,'' said Chris Connor, 38, a banker-turned-contractor from the West Village who lives part-time in Sag Harbor with his partner, Steven Gambrel, 34, a designer, and their brown Labradoodle, Dash. Four years ago, they bought a 2,500-square-foot Methodist church built in 1810 that had been turned into a residence and spent a year and a half restoring the original siding, mantelpieces, and fireplaces. ''We're just the custodians,'' Mr. Connor said. 

The Scene
 While the pace of life is lively (without the 20-something party houses found in some Hamptons communities), many annual events have a charming, small-town appeal.
 Each July the Eastville Historical Society, which is devoted to the early African American and Native American settlements, holds a fish fry. Every August the volunteer fire department sponsors a fund-raising carnival. HarborFest Weekend in September celebrates the village's maritime history with a clam chowder cook-off and a beard-growing contest.
 Those who want to join the softball game, on Saturday mornings, should bring patience along with their mitts; participation is based on regular attendance and an unpredictable attrition rate. Players frequently include Ken Auletta of The New Yorker and Mike Lupica of The Daily News -- but they have been showing up for decades.
 On weekends, restaurants like B. Smith's (a 600-seat seafood place on the water) and the sleek New Paradise Cafe are packed with people eating Prince Edward Island mussels and roast Long Island duck. Patrons at the American Hotel bar can get the local gossip as they study the extensive wine list. More casual spots include La Superica, where surfers fresh from Sagg Main Beach in Sagaponack pick up Mexican food, and the Dockside Bar & Grill in the American Legion building, which has a patio with harbor views and where diners can listen to the Sag Harbor Community Band perform on Tuesday nights in July and August. 
 In winter, when many restaurants close, social life centers on dinner parties. ''If you live in New York, your weekend house may have the first great kitchen of your life,'' Mr. Connor said. ''Twelve people over, two fireplaces going, that's a pretty good Saturday night for me.''

Pros
 Weekenders enjoy big-city amenities in a picture-postcard setting. Canio's Books, the oldest of four independent bookstores, holds weekend readings, and the Bay Street Theater produces four plays each summer. The Sag Harbor Cinema draws independent and foreign film buffs from across the Hamptons. Antiques hunters browse a topnotch selection of shops, including Youngblood on Madison Street. 
 Despite skyrocketing land values, the village atmosphere remains mostly down to earth. ''Nobody's putting on a show when they go to pick up a cup of coffee or a newspaper,'' said Olaf Olafsson, 41, a novelist and an executive vice president of Time Warner, who has a weekend home in town. ''That's why we like it.''
 ''There is a heart in this town,'' said Priscilla Dunhill, 74, a part-time resident and a writer of gardening books who bought an 1840 Greek Revival house in 1991. ''When I took my bicycle in for repairs, the clerk refused to take my money. So I pulled a pineapple out of my bag and paid him with that.'' 
 The village is buffered by two nature preserves with good hiking: Barcelona Neck to the east and Long Pond Greenbelt to the south. With about five miles of coastline, two bay beaches and eight marinas, it's easy to get on the water. ''I step out my front door and into my kayak,'' said Joan Schmitz, 61, a retired television commercial producer who lives on the Upper East Side. Twenty-two years ago she bought a 1930's two-bedroom bungalow on Morris Cove with sunset views. ''There's original flamingo wallpaper,'' she said. ''I keep thinking I'll renovate, but it's kind of wonderful the way it is.''
 Sag Harbor residents east of Division Street pay taxes to the Town of East Hampton, which entitles them to a free permit for East Hampton town beaches. Village residents west of Division pay taxes to the Town of Southampton, which allows all Sag Harbor residents (regardless of where they pay taxes) to use Southampton town beaches.

Cons
 Getting to and from Sag Harbor on the crowded Long Island Expressway can undo the relaxation the weekend affords. And once you're in the village, beware: parking is not for sissies. In summer, the population can swell to 9,000, and the free spaces on Main Street fill up by 9 a.m. ''I saw two women in fancy cars headed for the same spot,'' Ms. Dunhill said. ''They got out and shoved each other. Right in the village in the middle of the day.''
 Rushing traffic on Route 114 (which cuts through the village to East Hampton in one direction and to the Shelter Island ferry in the other), is ''a disaster waiting to happen,'' said Bette Lynch, a Brooklyn resident who has been a weekender since she was 16. To escape the crowds, she and her husband, both retired state government administrators, leave their Sag Harbor house and head to the marina where they sleep on Dreamcatcher, their 36-foot powerboat. 
 Weekenders seeking seclusion should keep on looking: homes here are cheek-by-jowl, with most lots less than a quarter of an acre. ''My neighbor is 20 feet away,'' Mr. Connor said. ''Some people get that, others are dumbfounded.''
 The high cost of real estate threatens to destroy the economic diversity that Sag Harborites say they prize. Many village workers can no longer afford to live there. 

The Real Estate Market
 ''Three years ago, an entry-level home was in the $300,000-to-$400,000 range,'' said Ted Seiter an agent with Harbor Cove Realty in Sag Harbor. ''Now it's upward of $500,000.'' Low interest rates and a steady stream of buyers from New York City have created a boom, he said.
 Earlier this week, there were 48 homes on the market, ranging from a four-bedroom cottage on less than half an acre for $575,000 to a four-bedroom farmhouse on an acre and a half with a beach for $5.6 million.
 ''When a property becomes available, if the price is within the realm of reality, it goes,'' said Cee Brown, a broker with Allan M. Schneider Associates, which has offices throughout the Hamptons. ''Sometimes within days of being listed.'' In May, a 1,600-square-foot three-bedroom, two-bathroom 1895 home on a tiny lot with a cottage sold for $695,000 after one day on the market. 
 This week, Schneider Associates was offering a five-bedroom, 1790's house on almost half an acre with a pool and three fireplaces for $1.7 million and a 1950's three-bedroom waterfront cottage on a third of an acre for $1,395,000.
 Listings at Harbor Cove Realty this week included a four-bedroom house on just over a half acre with a pool for $895,000 and a four-bedroom waterfront house on a half acre with a dock for $2.5 million.

LAY OF THE LAND
New England In the Hamptons

POPULATION -- 2,342.
SIZE -- 2 square miles.
NUMBER OF HOUSES -- 1,971.
MEDIAN HOUSE PRICE -- $675,000.

The meticulously maintained 1891 Guest House (14 Oakland Avenue; 631-725-1396) has three rooms with a common kitchen and deck for $75 to $150 a night.

HEADLINE: Justice and Family Planning

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Expendable Women'' (editorial, July 5):
 As a Catholic, I value social justice, and I believe that access to affordable contraception is necessary to help disadvantaged families lift themselves from poverty and to prevent devastating diseases like H.I.V.-AIDS. 
 Denying family-planning services to any family, let alone families in developing countries, is to deny them social and economic equality and basic dignity. These services are not denied to our own citizens (because it is not politically feasible), but only to the world's most vulnerable families, because they are assigned a lower value in terms of political consequence to this administration. 
 The United States has a moral obligation to renew financing to the United Nations Population Fund and to stop denying vulnerable women essential information and services they need.

DAWNE DEPPE
Lanham, Md., July 6, 2004

HEADLINE: At the Helm and Ignorant of Company Troubles

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Ignorance is Kenneth L. Lay's defense.
 The man who founded the Enron Corporation, even choosing its name, pleaded not guilty to fraud charges yesterday and insisted that he had not known of the fraud that brought the company down.
 The Justice Department, which sought his indictment, and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which filed a related civil suit, appear to accept a large part of Mr. Lay's defense. He is not charged with organizing the fraud, or even with knowing about it while it was flourishing in 1999 and 2000. 
 Instead, the government says he took part in covering up fraud and misleading investors in 2001, starting early in the year but with most of the actions coming in the months before the company collapsed in December of that year, as Mr. Lay -- by his account -- was trying to save it.
 The only crimes that Mr. Lay is charged with before 2001 concern a failure to tell banks that money he was borrowing would go for the purchase of Enron shares.
 In the civil suit filed simultaneously by the S.E.C., Mr. Lay is accused of violating insider-trading laws by selling stock when he knew of the fraud. But that suit makes clear that the S.E.C. does not think it has evidence that he knew of the fraud until early 2001.
 The Justice Department filed criminal insider-trading charges against Jeffrey K. Skilling, who briefly succeeded Mr. Lay as Enron's chief executive, and against Richard A. Causey, the former chief accounting officer, contending that they sold shares while knowing of the fraud. But it did not file such charges against Mr. Lay.
 For the Justice Department, getting any indictment of Mr. Lay may have been the goal. From the beginning, he was the symbol of Enron, the man who was close to President Bush -- who called him ''Kenny Boy'' -- and had influence during the early days of the Bush administration.
 At the peak of his fame, he wowed fellow chief executives at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. To many, it seemed outrageous that the man at the helm would walk away while underlings went to prison.
 ''We can go to the top,'' said Linda Chatman Thomsen, deputy director of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, ''and the fact that we do, I hope, deters others from engaging in illegal behavior. It is our sincere hope that others who might be tempted to dissemble to the investing public will be deterred.''
 Mr. Lay asserted his innocence yesterday and blamed Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron -- who has pleaded guilty and agreed to testify for the prosecution -- for all his problems. He said he wanted a trial as soon as possible.
 Mr. Lay answered questions from reporters, a highly unusual thing for a defendant to do. He had only praise for President Bush, although he said he had been closer to Mr. Bush's father, the former president. He said his net worth, once hundreds of millions of dollars, was down to around $20 million, after setting aside reserves for legal fees and court settlements, and that his liquid assets were less than $1 million. 
 What may have gotten Mr. Lay to this point in the legal process was the disclosure that as he was trying to reassure Enron employees that the company would be saved, he was secretly selling his own shares. To accomplish that, he used what came to be known as the ''Lay loophole'' in federal securities laws.
 This provided that stock transactions between an executive and the company itself did not have to be disclosed until the following year. What Mr. Lay did was to repeatedly borrow $4 million from the company and then satisfy the loan by tendering stock to the company. Then he borrowed more money and tendered more stock.
 In the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, Congress closed that loophole with a vengeance. First, it required that all insider transactions had to be disclosed within days. Then it barred corporations' loans to executives.
 Mr. Lay's defense against that charge will be that he was not a willing seller.
 He had borrowed heavily against his stock, and needed the cash to meet margin calls as Enron's share price fell. Indeed, his transactions indicate that he believed the stock was cheap and that he was doing all he could to hold on until the price recovered -- something that it never did.
 Mr. Lay could have disclosed what was going on and explained that his sales were forced, showing how he was putting in all his available cash to minimize the number of shares sold. But it may be understandable that he thought such disclosures would only make the situation worse.
 Since Enron went under, Mr. Lay has had to give up defending much of the image that he worked hard to create. He was seen as a brilliant executive -- he has a Ph.D. in economics -- who was both skilled at corporate infighting and had a visionary ability to see business trends before others did.
 As the chief executive of Houston Natural Gas, he warded off one hostile acquirer in 1984 by paying greenmail -- buying back the stock owned by the raider at an above-market price -- but concluded that consolidation in the gas pipeline business was inevitable. In the spring of 1985, he agreed to have his company acquired by InterNorth, with the merged company to be based in InterNorth's hometown, Omaha, and known as HNG/InterNorth.
 Mr. Lay was not supposed to become the top executive until considerably later, but he moved up well before the schedule as other executives quit. He moved the company to Houston and announced that it would be renamed Enteron. It turned out that name was already established in medical circles -- having to do with intestines -- so the company name was shortened to Enron.
 In the 1990's, even as energy businesses bored investors, Enron became a Wall Street darling. It did that by pioneering in energy trading and then expanding into trading access to broadband communications. By then, it was considered a leading ''new economy'' company.
 In February 2001, Mr. Lay handed over the chief executive reins to Mr. Skilling, and settled into the role of nonexecutive chairman. But then, Mr. Skilling quit in August -- it is still not clear just why -- and the board that Mr. Lay had largely chosen rewarded him with a $10 million bonus for again becoming chief executive.
 This money wound up going to the banks to pay margin calls -- something Mr. Lay now cites as proof that he did not know the company was going under. But the government contends that he also misled investors in discussing Enron's financial prospects.
 In late August 2001, before it was clear that the company was in serious danger, he brushed off a reporter's question about the partnerships that turned out to be at the heart of the fraud. ''You're getting way over my head,'' he said.
 That statement turns out to be the basis of Mr. Lay's defense -- that the visionary corporate leader with the doctorate in economics simply did not understand what was happening at the company he created and ran.
 It is a humiliating way to end a business career, but may also be his best hope of staying out of prison.

HEADLINE: Satisfaction and Sadness at the Sight of Handcuffs

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO; Jayna Desai contributed reporting for this article.

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 8 

 BODY:
Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of the Enron Corporation, called Thursday a ''tragic day'' after he was handcuffed and led to a courthouse here where he pleaded not guilty to charges that he had deceived Enron's investors and employees. 
 Tragedy, however, was not the first word on the lips of many Houstonians on Thursday as they absorbed the news of the indictment of Mr. Lay, who was once considered the city's most influential business executive and power broker. Other words spilled forth, not all of them printable. Some of the words were: vindication, amazement, sorrow and schadenfreude. 
 Many of Enron's former workers were especially vocal. John Sides, a longtime Enron employee who said he lost $700,000 in retirement savings after the company collapsed into bankruptcy proceedings in December 2001, said he watched television broadcasts of Mr. Lay's surrender to authorities on Thursday with quiet, almost subdued, satisfaction. 
 ''The money's not coming back,'' said Mr. Sides, a former budget analyst at Enron who now makes ends meet with two jobs, one planning budgets for public schools and another operating a private photography business. ''But he made a bundle at the top and should pay for what he did.''
 Houston has a reputation as a city that prides itself on forgiving and forgetting the misdeeds of its residents, with a determined emphasis on economic advancement.
 Those in the city's energy industry, for instance, revel in tales of wildcatters who built and lost several fortunes, sometimes crookedly, but nonetheless contributed to Houston's prosperity and influence. Not many were willing to go that far for Mr. Lay, but some were more understanding than others.
 ''Personally, I think Ken Lay was not an active participant,'' said Darlene Kilburn, an administrative assistant who works in an office building in downtown Houston, not far from the futuristic towers -- now mostly empty -- that once represented Enron's stated ambitions to become the biggest company in the world. 
 ''It was sad to see him in handcuffs,'' Ms. Kilburn said. ''But I didn't lose money in Enron, so I'm sure people who were involved with Enron have different opinions.''
 Enron's collapse and Mr. Lay's stewardship of the company shook Houston to its core, according to Stephen L. Klineberg, a professor of sociology at Rice University. Mr. Lay went from being an admired father figure of the city's elite to an ostracized symbol of corporate excess.
 ''There's a fascinating and bittersweet mixture of emotion that has accompanied Ken Lay's indictment,'' Mr. Klineberg said. ''There's a feeling of just deserts, even as Houston evolves into a place where corporate stardom has been exchanged for institutionally shared responsibility.'' 
 Many former Enron employees spent much of Thursday talking on the phone and sending e-mail messages or instant-messages to each other after watching Mr. Lay speak in a televised news conference.
 Karl Klicker, a former intelligence officer in the Marines who lost his job as a training manager at Enron, said, with intentional irony, that he ''felt pretty bad for Kenny Boy.'' 
 ''I'd rather be living in poverty than heading off to jail,'' said Mr. Klicker, who has started his own consulting company and has been painting murals, baby-sitting and training for marathons since losing his job at Enron. ''It's amazing that it took two and a half years to indict him. It took way too long.''
 Mimi Swartz, a prominent local journalist who wrote a book on Enron with Sherron S. Watkins, the former Enron executive who warned Mr. Lay about the company's accounting problems, said that Houston remained divided over Mr. Lay.
 ''It's sort of a class thing, with the wealthy friends of Ken Lay ambivalent about it and the ordinary man on the street who wants to see him strung up,'' Ms. Swartz said. ''Houston's a place with a very short memory. And it will work hard to forget about this, but that hasn't happened yet.''
 Mr. Lay is not the first Enron executive to be indicted for involvement in the company's fall. He is the 31st person to face charges over the corporate debacle that resulted in more than 6,000 people in Houston losing their jobs. Mr. Lay's indictment follows those of the former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, who faces multiple charges of conspiracy, fraud and insider trading, and Richard A. Causey, the former chief accounting officer. Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, faces up to 10 years in prison after pleading guilty to two conspiracy counts. 
 ''These people need to go to jail for 20 or 30 years,'' said Jorge Ospina, a waiter at a restaurant that once catered to many Enron employees, as he left a public library downtown. ''This whole case is a joke because Fastow will probably be out of jail in a couple of years. Justice needs to be served.'' 
 But some of those hurt the most by Enron's downfall were more saddened by Mr. Lay's indictment than vengeful. 
 ''He was not a bad man,'' said Rod Jordan, who runs a group representing more than 1,100 former employees, ''just a weak man.'' 
 ''We know seeing Ken Lay in handcuffs won't return what we lost,'' he said. ''At least it's a milestone in terms of putting this chapter of our lives behind us.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Rod Jordan, left, runs a group representing more than 1,100 former Enron employees. He says Kenneth Lay, the former chairman of Enron who has been charged with 11 felonies, is a weak man, not a bad one. (Photo by Michael Stravato for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Coalition Job in Iraq

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re Paul Krugman's June 29 column criticizing the Coalition Provisional Authority: 
 I was in Iraq for seven months as director of private-sector development. My biggest challenges were restarting state-owned and private businesses, restoring credit and investment, and reforming outdated laws and policies -- not privatization. These required management and problem-solving skills and financial expertise, not a narrow privatization background. 
 My M.B.A. from Harvard, years of experience at McKinsey and Citigroup, and 15 years owning and managing businesses were ideal for this role. One of my first hires was Jacek Kwasniewski, the former deputy minister of privatization in Poland, to oversee the privatization effort.
 Mr. Krugman includes my appointment in his charge of ''cronyism.'' If the administration wanted to reward a friend, it would have come up with something better than seven months of 16-hour days and seven-day workweeks dodging rockets and mortars and living in a trailer. 
 Economic growth and the promise of better lives will in time secure Iraq's stability and the adoption of a modern representative government. Tyrants and terrorists can delay this historical trend, but they can't stop it.

THOMAS C. FOLEY
Greenwich, Conn., July 6, 2004

HEADLINE: A Dark View of U.S. Strategy

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

IMPERIAL HUBRIS
Why the West Is Losing the War on Terror
By Anonymous
309 pages. Brassey's Inc. $27.50.
 ''Imperial Hubris,'' the scalding new book by a current Central Intelligence Agency officer -- who was able to publish the book on the condition that his real name not be revealed -- is an assessment of America's war on terror that is bound to provoke large heapings of controversy, on both the right and the left, among hardliners on Iraq and critics of the administration alike. Readers will doubtless contest some or many of the things Anonymous has to say, but he pulls few punches in this book and gives us a fascinating window on America's war with Al Qaeda -- at least as framed by one senior analyst, who seems to have put all bureaucratic niceties aside.
 It is a book that not only slings all manner of arrows at America's political, military and intelligence establishment (going back to the mid-70's, with the qualified exception of President Ronald Reagan and his C.I.A. director, William J. Casey), but a book that also calls for a complete re-evaluation of the nation's foreign policy toward Muslims and the Middle East.
 In its pages, prescient analyses of recent developments in the Persian Gulf and Middle East (informed by the author's experience in the mid-1990's as head of a C.I.A. unit assigned to tracking Osama bin Laden) jostle for space with incendiary calls for a Shermanesque exercise of American military power in a potential war with the Muslim world; maverick assessments of Islamic attitudes toward the United States, with shrill exhortations for America to adopt a neo-isolationist stance based on narrowly defined self-interest.
 If the country's foreign policy remains status quo, Anonymous warns, ''America's military confrontation with Islam'' will broaden ''with escalating human and economic expense.'' He predicts that Al Qaeda ''will attack the continental United States again, that its next strike will be more damaging than that of 11 September 2001, and could include use of weapons of mass destruction.''
 In addition, Anonymous accuses United States leaders, elites and media of being in denial about the nature of the Qaeda threat and the balance sheet on the war on terror: he argues that America must stop using the terrorist paradigm for Al Qaeda and accept ''the fact'' that the group is ''leading a popular, worldwide, and increasingly powerful Islamic insurgency,'' and he asserts that United States victories against Al Qaeda have thus far been tactical ones that have failed to slow ''the shift in strategic advantage toward al Qaeda.'' 
 In the course of this book, Anonymous excoriates American leaders for not having had an immediate military response planned for an event like 9/11: ''None had been planned in the eleven months since the attack on the U.S.S. Cole, or in the five-plus years since bin Laden declared war'' on the United States.
 And he assails American generals for passively accepting their civilian leaders' directives for waging light, fast operations (of the sort favored by Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld). ''Fight and win quickly; do not kill many of the enemy, destroy much of his property, or kill many of his civilians; and, above all, lose the barest minimum of U.S. soldiers because the soft American public will not tolerate high casualties'' -- this sort of cautious, fastidious war-making, Anonymous contends, is ''a recipe for disaster,'' invariably leaving behind ''half-finished or, more accurately, half-started wars that will be refought later.'' 
 Anonymous argues that the ''high-profile role'' of the F.B.I. in America's counter-bin Laden campaign lends it ''too much law-enforcement color,'' promoting an ''international version of the saga of the American West, where U.S. intelligence officers and soldiers are sent out, like the storied Texas Rangers'' to get their man. This approach, Anonymous says, will never work ''against a large and talented insurgent organization like al Qaeda'' because ''the procedure neither kills nor captures fast enough to outpace al Qaeda's astounding ability to replicate.'' 
 When it comes to his own organization, the C.I.A., Anonymous accuses its leaders of ''moral cowardice'' for ''falsely assuring policymakers and congressional overseers that cooperation'' with the F.B.I. was ''seamless.'' He also describes the overall intelligence community (the I.C.) as being ''risk-averse'': senior officers, who are clear, concise and unbiased among staff, he says, become ''more selective when deciding what to tell policymakers, including the president.'' 
 Although Anonymous does not explicitly deal with intelligence about Iraq possessing weapons of mass destruction (which some C.I.A. analysts questioned, but which the agency's chief, George Tenet, termed a ''slam dunk'' in Bob Woodward's book ''Plan of Attack''), he adds this biting aside: ''Substantive selectivity can exclude subjects in which policy makers are uninterested or those that will stir anger, such as intelligence showing a specific U.S. policy is cocked up. This process also yields the deselection of data that would spur policymaker requests for action that, if taken, might yield an IC failure -- and so criticism from Congress, policymakers, or the media -- or expose the IC's unaddressed systemic failures.'' 
 Anonymous has little to say about the performance of the bin Laden unit he headed from 1996 to 1999 -- a unit that the veteran intelligence writer James Bamford criticized in a recent book (''A Pretext for War'') for failing to penetrate Al Qaeda's leadership. According to a staff report by the Sept. 11 commission, leaders of the bin Laden station were frustrated when a plan to capture the Qaeda chief in 1998 was not recommended by C.I.A. leadership for approval by the Clinton White House; the following year, Anonymous was transferred to another C.I.A. position.
 Drawing upon nearly two decades of experience in national security issues related to Afghanistan and South Asia, Anonymous draws a bleak picture of America's post-9/11 engagements abroad. As he sees it, Afghanistan has become ''a classic lose-lose situation'' in which an American pullout means that the Taliban and Al Qaeda ''will resume control of much of the country,'' and a decision by America to stay means that ''the Islamist insurgency will intensify'' and ''ultimately triumph whether or not the United States massively increases its occupying force and takes the war to the enemy as did the Russians.'' 
 ''None of this had to be,'' Anonymous writes, citing what he sees as a series of crucial missteps, including a failure to attack immediately after 9/11 (before Al Qaeda had a chance to disperse); a failure to close the country's borders; a failure to draw lessons from the British and Soviet experiences in Afghanistan; and a failure to understand the difficulties of trying to transplant an American-style democracy to such a culturally alien land.
 Although Anonymous regards Afghanistan as a necessary war, he sees the American invasion of Iraq as ''an avaricious, premeditated, unprovoked war against a foe who posed no immediate threat but whose defeat did offer economic advantages.'' For Osama bin Laden, Anonymous argues, the American invasion and occupation of Iraq were like ''a Christmas present you long for but never expected to receive'' -- a gift from Washington that ''will haunt, hurt, and hound Americans for years to come.'' He sees Iraq becoming another breeding ground for Al Qaeda, and the postwar insurgencies in Iraq and Afghanistan as magnets for anti-American fighters. 
 ''U.S. forces and policies are completing the radicalization of the Islamic world, something Osama bin Laden has been trying to do with substantial but incomplete success since the early 1990's,'' he writes. ''As a result, I think it fair to conclude that the United States of America remains bin Laden's only indispensable ally.'' 
 In this volume, Anonymous tries -- as he did in his last book, ''Through Our Enemies' Eyes'' -- to show how Muslims regard Osama bin Laden. He argues that the Qaeda leader should not be dismissed as an irrational terrorist or an avatar of an Islamic lunatic fringe. Rather, he describes Mr. bin Laden as ''the most respected, loved, romantic, charismatic, and perhaps able figure in the last 150 years of Islamic history'' -- someone seen by many Muslims as waging a heartfelt defense of their faith, ''a practical warrior, not an apocalyptic terrorist in search of Armageddon.'' 
 Anonymous contests the argument put out by members of the Bush administration that Mr. bin Laden wants to destroy America because he hates our values, freedoms and ideas. In Anonymous's view, the Qaeda leader hates us ''because of our policies and actions in the Muslim world'' and Al Qaeda's attacks are meant to advance a set of clear, focused and limited foreign policy goals: namely, an end to American aid to Israel: the removal of American forces from the Arabian Peninsula; an end to the American occupation of Afghanistan and Iraq; an end to American support for repressive, apostate Muslim regimes like Saudi Arabia; an end to Amerian support for Russia, India and China against their Muslim militants; and an end to American pressure on Arab energy producers to keep oil prices low. 
 If current American policies toward the Muslim world are not changed, Anonymous writes near the end of this harrowing and often deliberately provocative volume, America will be left with only a military option for defending itself -- an option he says that should be used not ''daintily,'' as it has been in recent years, but with the sort of bloody-minded ferocity used ''in France and on Pacific islands, and from skies over Tokyo and Dresden'' during World War II. 
 The war on terror, he warns, ''has the potential to last beyond our children's lifetimes and to be fought mostly on U.S. soil.''

LENGTH: 923 words

HEADLINE: China Agrees to Phase Out Tax on Imported Chips

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8 

 BODY:
The United States said on Thursday that it was dropping its first case against China at the World Trade Organization after settling a dispute with the country over its tax on imported semiconductors.
 Under the settlement, China agreed to a gradual elimination of the tax advantage given to its domestic semiconductor industry, which has increased the price of United States imports by 14 percent.
 ''This is another step toward real results,'' Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said at a news conference here. ''China is a voracious consumer of semiconductor chips and this will give us a level playing field.'' 
 With the record trade deficit and the outsourcing of American jobs to China growing as significant election-year issues, the administration is casting its trade policy as a success built on practical negotiations and settlements of disagreements.
 ''With the help of our Chinese colleagues, this problem-solving approach often works,'' Mr. Zoellick said.
 Behind him was a banner with the phrase ''real results'' repeated again and again in rows, a rebuttal to accusations by Senator John Kerry, the Democratic candidate for president, and his running mate, John Edwards, that the administration's trade policies favor multinational corporations and fail to protect American workers.
 Roger Altman, an investment banker and former deputy Treasury secretary under President Bill Clinton who is advising the Kerry campaign, said that the Bush administration's real results were a record trade deficit and the loss of 1.9 million jobs despite the opening of more global markets.
 ''President Bush's record on trade is dismal,'' Mr. Altman said. ''He is on track to be the first since President Hoover to see net exports go down during his term.''
 The Chinese agreed to phase out the tax advantage over the next nine months, ending it in April 2005. The United States filed a complaint with the W.T.O. in March, contending that China's value-added tax on imported semiconductors violated international trade rules prohibiting tax policies that favor domestic manufacturers. 
 The $70 billion semiconductor industry in the United States hailed the settlement, saying it was critical if the United States was to continue to lead the field.
 ''We're very pleased with these results, absolutely,'' said George M. Scalise, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, who attended the news conference along with other industry representatives.
 The American semiconductor industry sells $2 billion in chips to China every year, making it the largest foreign supplier. But that is still a small share of the $25 billion Chinese market. Mr. Scalise said he hoped the settlement would mean that foreign competitors would be more competitive and increase their sales in the coming years.
 Some Democratic lawmakers said the settlement was vindication of their demands over the last two years that the administration take stronger action against the Chinese on trade issues.
 Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said the agreement was a ''step forward, but much, much more needs to be done.''
 ''We've got a $120 billion trade deficit with China -- a 50 percent increase since 2001 when the administration came into office -- and it is growing,'' he said. 
 Mr. Zoellick said at the news conference that the United States trade deficit was a sign of a dynamic economy, not of poor policy.
 ''The overall trade deficit, it reflects that the United States is buying more than others do,'' he said. ''The solution is a combination of opening more markets and enforcing trade laws.''
 As an example of the administration's approach, Mr. Zoellick cited China's agreement in April to abandon a plan to impose its own standard for wireless technology, essentially agreeing to join the rest of the world rather than dividing it up.
 The Semiconductor Industry Association applauded that decision as well, which gives it even greater access to China, the world's third-largest semiconductor market.
 Several contentious issues remain with China like textile exports, currency controls and labor rights. The administration rejected calls by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to punish China for the commercial advantage that the group said the country gained by violating workers' rights.
 The representatives of the American semiconductor industry said the resolution would help the United States economy. The chip industry employs 255,000 Americans, according to the association, and United States companies have a 50 percent share of the world market. B. Anne Craib, the association's director of international trade, said that a majority of semiconductors were manufactured in the United States, but she could not be more precise.
 But like other industrial products, semiconductor chips are increasingly being manufactured overseas, especially for the export market. Eamonn Fingleton, a trade expert based in Tokyo, said that factories in Japan, Taiwan, Singapore and Korea would profit as much from this settlement as those in the United States.
 Most trade experts had said that China would be unable to defend the tax before the W.T.O. Indeed, the settlement was reached just days before the United States was prepared to ask the W.T.O. to form a panel to adjudicate the dispute.
 Frank Vargo, spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers, said ending the tax was crucial to ensure that China did not discriminate against other American industries through its tax system.
